description:
This is one of those places that you didn't really MEAN to become a regular at but it's Thursday night and we're tired and you can't decide and I can't either so " 'Jima we go!". 

It's comfortable, familiar. A fifth home? Maybe twelfth. You walk into the small restaurant and they either escort you to your table or point at the one you are now assigned to and return to their business because you clearly interrupted their Do Not Disturb settings. 

You are pleased to see they still came through with  the Tonkatsu Curry Udon + Gyoza for $15.95 deal. Score! You order and usually less than 15 minutes later they come slam the food on the table and scurry back to the kitchen. 

Y'all ready for this?!? 

BOMB! The food is great, you are enjoying every bite and they bring you more whatever/beverages but you don't push for anything else because you learned your lesson at the front door. You eat up, get the handwritten bill. You get up and pay thinking "do they really deserve this tip?" And still hit that 20% anyway because this is your investment in the next time you didn't mean to be there and also that chef is back there working magic with that spatula so you don't event feel bad about it. I love this place. Everything else is 'charm'.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Enjoyed the place. I tried the Unagi don and my wife tried the chicken katsu curry. By the end of the meal, we were both fully satisfied and full. The Unagi don was a little on the sweet side and could have had a little less sauce but otherwise it was great. Very buttery and delicious. The curry was on point and also came with a mini udon. 

It's slightly pricey for a fast casual Japanese restaurant but not horrible given the fact that you're in the heart of Downtown SF. I'd go back!
author: Jonas E.

description:
Quick Summary
- Food is 5 star, service is what brought the star rating down
- Second time visit, both times uncomfortably unfriendly service 
- Good food portions, can leave with a full stomach
- Recommend the nabeyaki and the niku udon set (if you eat a lot)
- Prices are good for the portion
- Wait time is due to fewer chairs

This is the second time I visited the udon place, after so many years. We decided to go because we were hungry and wanted to eat a light tasting Japanese cuisine in the middle of the financial district (so we weren't feeling ramen). 

The food is very delicious. I ordered the niku udon set, which came with the mini eel don. The beef slices were paper thin, so it was very easy to cut and chew. It was great to eat with the udon noodles. The noodles were cooked just right, so it was chewy but also tender. The broth was delicious too and I almost drank the whole thing. 

The dinner experience would have ended with a good note, except for the service. 

There was a young couple who sat next to us, who apparently have been there before us. One of them have ordered a nabeyaki udon, which was also what we have ordered. Less than ten minutes after ordering the older waitress came in with a nabeyaki udon and served at our table and left. We were surprised at the speed of arrival, but moments after taking two photos of the dish and taking a bite of a vegetable, the same waitress returned realizing she made a mistake. The order was for the neighboring couple.

This, of course, brought a strange little tension between ours and the other table. 

The waitress then came by the couple's table three times, once to deliver a free potato salad (in which the awaiting and probably hangry customer didn't even touch), second to apologize and to let them know that the food was coming soon, and the third to apologize yet again because it ended up that all of our orders arrived before theirs.Each time, however, the waitress gave a head nod toward our table. 
For our point of view, it gave us an impression that it was our fault that they didn't get their dish in time. Would we supposed to apologize to the couple and give the nabeyaki udon that we have eaten a bit of the Chinese cabbage over to them? Surely, they wouldn't have liked that either. Throughout the time, the older waitress gave us no attention. 

Either way, the service here gave an uncomfortable time. We felt a similar unfriendly experience on our first visit here too. 

This will probably be a place I will return maybe five years or so, around the time when I have forgotten about this event.
author: Mito I.

description: This is a fairly busy place! Usually that's a good sign of great food but I think I ordered the wrong item. I got the sashimi combo and everything but the salmon tasted kind of old. My server didnt even explain which kinds of fish were on my plate (some of it was very obvious but the rest could've been anything to me lol). I probably ordered on a bad day but I'll try sticking to chicken or beef the next time I come back!
author: Peter H.

description: In my opinion they have the curry gyu in San Francisco. Can be very busy at lunch time, but this place worth the wait.
author: Madhu J.

description:
For our last night in San Fran, we wanted to go out to dinner and try something new. After being overwhelmed with yelp reviews of the area, we decided to venture out of the hotel and search on our own. Dojima-Ann was the first restaurant we saw and after perusing the menu, we decided to give it a try. We were very, very happy with our dinner!

This Japanese restaurant, while small is very cozy and welcoming. We were immediately seated and served by 3 waitresses who were all very friendly. There is no AC in this restaurant, but a lot of fans which kept the temperature very comfortable.

I ordered the Tonkatsu Don and my boyfriend ordered the EBI Tempura soba noodle bowel. We were both very happy with our meals! The food came out fast and each was delicious! The prices were also very fair, especially for San Fran!

Overall, we were very happy and would recommend!
author: Sarah L.

description: We always make a point to dine here every time we come to visit San Francisco from Arizona. We are the regular customers for the last 7-8 years. Food has always been consistent and they never let us down.
author: Twee W.

description: The sushi was fresh and delicious. Service was excellent and price was very reasonable. Nice place for lunch or dinner.
author: Tiziano B.

description:
Fast, casual. I have mixed feelings about this place. First time I came here, awesome. Hit the spot. Felt fresh. Second time, there was a piece of saran wrap left on one of the rolls we got. Really felt like they were tryna squeeze out these rolls in the back as fast as they could without seeing the end product. Didn't like the feeling of it being mass-produced with no quality control. How does that speak to their other dishes if they can't even notice something so obvious? 

The dons are decent. Have had the katsu and the oyako. The breaded katsu wasn't that fresh (known after the fact) as I felt super indigested. 

Weirdly, it has this calming and casual vibe that I would probably revisit it if I'm shopping around the area.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
I like this small, casual Japanese restaurant.  San Francisco is an eating town, but sometimes I don't want a big meal or want something smaller late in the evening, so I pop in for an udon or a tonkatsu don.  The nabeyaki udon is actually large.  Been coming here for years.

The place is small and fills up at lunch and dinner and lines do form.  

The prices are average for SF.

The service has always been very good/excellent.
author: Jaime C.

description: I like this type of food, casual Japanese food. The food here is not more delicious than exactly what you would expect, but it is in a great location. The prices are reasonable as well. What I like the most is that the portions are universal -- if you require more food, your order will be generous enough to fill you up; and if you aren't hungry, the portion will be just right for you if you don't finish it. Long story short, their portions are very generous.
author: Andrea T.

description: This sushi  was authentic, fresh and tasty. I enjoyed all the rolls I tried, and the appetizers were all very delicious. The place was a bit crowded, and service was a bit delayed, but it was a busy night. It looked like many locals enjoyed dining here, and the atmosphere was warm and inviting. I'd definitely visit again
author: Jessica G.

description: Every time I've come here there is never a line which is surprising because its right by Union Square. Super cheap sushi that is actually good.
author: Jorge P.

description:
Decided to take a chance on Dojima-Ann since my usual neighborhood sushi spot was closed (Akira!). Much regret. 

Expectations weren't high to begin with, we just wanted to go somewhere for a chirashi that wouldn't cost an arm and a leg. For $18.50, there was a decent amount of variety and good portion of fish. It wasn't bad, but wasn't amazing either - 3/5. 

The real treat was the sake sashimi that obviously wasn't done being defrosted. It was super cold.. way too cold to be enjoyable. 

Super packed due to their location, but don't trust the tourist trap hype!
author: Laverne N.

description:
I really enjoyed this casual Japanese restaurant.  Seems I'm always eating at off hours on the West Coast so the first tier restaurants are often closed.  

I ordered the salmon bento box and was pleasantly surprised when the server says the bento box comes with two proteins.  I added chicken katsu.  The salmon was outstanding.  Really fresh and well cooked.  I enjoyed the chicken katsu too.  

Service was quick and efficient.  Just what I expect in a casual restaurant.  Prices seemed reasonable.  

Will return.
author: Jeanne T.

description: Stopped in at 4:35 pm and ordered Shrimp Tempura that comes with a salad and miso soup.  The tempura was very greasy--tried blotting and finally gave up.
author: Lyn T.

description:
My favorite little casual Japanese food just like the way my mom use to make it.
Another plus is you can get a small side order of udon for a small fee with your rice bowls if you can decide between a rice dish or noodle dish!
author: Julianna H.

description: We needed a quick snack while shopping and stopped in. It's a great location, and we were sat quickly. We ordered the soba noodles, 12 piece combo sushi, and uni. It was ok, not the best sushi I've had, but not bad.
author: Ha D.

description: Happened upon this place while walking around Union Square. Being from Hawaii we eat lots of sushi and Japanese. The sushi was fresh the rolls were perfect size the teriyaki chicken wasn't over dressed. The food was great!!! And the service...they seated us right away and had our hungry mugs eating within minutes. Would definitely return!
author: Jamie P.

description:
Pretty decent Japanese place in the heart of downtown SF. It's small, cozy and feels pretty authentic, but in the evening you could be waiting up to 20 minutes for a table. 

All the dishes I've had here have been pretty good, but nothing really spectacular. My go-to dishes here are the Spicy Tuna Tempura Roll and the Tonkatsu-don. The main grouse my friends and I have with this place is just the lack of variety in the menu, compared to other Japanese places in the city. 

If you're looking for some affordable Japanese food, in a comfortable and convenient location, that won't knock the socks off your tastebuds, but will satisfy them nonetheless, definitely stop by.
author: Sahil S.

description:
THIS PLACE IS SHADY about their price! Don't order off the menu otherwise you will get ripped off!!!!

I came to the restaurant yesterday and asked if I can order uni sashimi instead of sushi, because I didn't like sushi rice. The server said yes, so I confirmed the price with her ($8) before ordering. It came with about 4 piece of uni (picture 1).

So I was pretty happy about the food and the price yesterday, and I walked to the restaurant after work today. I said I wanted to order uni sashimi instead of uni sushi again. I received the same portion as what I got yesterday (picture 2).

Now comes the interesting part - the bill said the uni sashimi was $28. I called one server and asked about the number. She said I gotta ask "the boss". Apparently the restaurant owner decided to charge me 20 dollars more for the same item I got yesterday.

This is not cool at all!!!
author: Dai C.

description: Service is hit or miss, but I've been coming here for 3 years and the food is always on point. Fresh sushi, fantastic flavors, and wasabi that is out of this world.
author: SiouxFalls T.

description:
3.5/5
I came by because I  was too lazy to walk too far from my study spot and honestly my expections were pretty low for a Japanese place located in one of the touristiest parts of SF. Honestly the prices weren't too awful considering the location and they did have some diversity in their menu.

I got the unagi don with the mini udon bowl for $3. Also got a hamachi maki roll for my insatiable sushi fix.

-Unagi don: I can't say I've had a bad unagi don before but this over was particularly good. Nothing fancy or unique besides a very very tender piece of Unagi and a good ratio of sauce and rice. No complaints, a safe bet.

-Mini udon bowl: I knew it wasn't going to be good but when I see noodles I want noodles. I should've just resisted. It's not bad in the same way a prepackaged bowl from your local Asian grocery store isn't necessarily bad. Just very meh. But I guess it's $3 so can't complain.

-Hamachi Maki Roll: Hamachi itself was average but I was pleasantly surprised by the rice. Texture wise it's a bit overcooked and mush but flavor-wise they go for it.

Overall I'm pleasantly surprised by my meal and if I'm in the area again I'd consider coming back.
author: Vivian C.

description:
I bookmarked this Union Square spot as it was recommended by some Japanese folks I met as a pretty legit spot for Japanese food in the city. My friend and I arrived a little after 7 pm on a Tuesday evening and were able to get seated immediately, though I think we might have grabbed the last open table. It's not a big place so I can see there being a short wait during peak times on the weekend.

I love oyakodon (chicken and eggs over rice) and hadn't had it in a while, so when I noticed it was on the menu here, I knew I had to get it. But first, I decided to give their cream croquette ($8.95) a try as I was familiar with potato croquettes but not cream ones. One serving came with three pieces and were perfectly crispy on the outside and deliciously creamy on the inside. I loved the cream filling and tried to figure out what it was made of but it didn't taste like anything I recognized. Definitely recommend this appetizer even though it's a bit pricy, as it's a very unique dish I haven't seen elsewhere.

The oyakodon ($11.50) was a huge bowl of chicken with sort of runny eggs, and while it was enjoyable, the flavor was on the blander side. The chicken and eggs were good to eat on their own but with the rice there just wasn't enough flavor to make the dish work. A little bit more salt would have gone a long way here. They give you a lot of rice, but I ended up eating only a little over half of it.

Service was a bit slow here as I didn't see too many servers. That was fine for us as we weren't in a rush and could use the time to catch up, but if you're in a hurry that's something to take into consideration.

The shape of the restaurant is long and narrow, so everything feels a little bit cramped together. I also didn't like the narrow path to the bathroom in the back as I constantly felt like I was about to run into someone.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Excellent nigiri with just the right amount of rice. Only reason for four stars is it was a rather long wait for 2pm and the beer wasn't cold and the sake wasn't hot. 

Definitely recommend for locals and tourists alike.
author: Salina R.

description: Must try tonkatsu curry豚カツカレー, it also came with a bowl of salad and udon soup. It was so good!! I'll come here again :))
author: Aileen L.

description:
I have been a regular for many years since before the management changed about 3 years ago to this present one. The standard of food has dropped. I had vegetable and shrimp tempura with udon. Tempura came in separate bowl which was not the issue. There was no sauce, udon came in a runny broth with no garnish at all. Vegetable tempura were plentiful but the shrimp tempura were 2 tiny ones. I was not offered a cup of tea which was the norm before. 
I miss the old place. I will not be going back to eat under this sloppy management. All I will do is poke my head in to see if they change hand again in the future then I might go back and try it again.
author: Eve M.

description:
Experience from 1/3/18~ Found this cute little place while roaming around SF with cousins. Came during lunch & we were seated right away. The 3 of us ordered bento boxes from the lunch special options while my other cousin ordered a selection of sushi/rolls- tuna avocado rolls, salmon sushi, & octopus. 
I ordered the salmon teriyaki with vegetable tempura & it came with a side salad, rice, & fruit. The other bento box had fried oysters & California roll, while the other consisted of fried ebi and chicken karaage. 
Overall, food & service were good & place is good for a quick/casual lunch/dinner. Only wish that the portions were a little more even if it's lunch portion since price was a little bit much for the amount you get for lunch. Might try this place for dinner next time.
author: Carla L.

description:
I visited San Francisco and really wanted to eat Japanese dishes.

To be honest, I don't give 5 stars. I just picked up some foods and not ate inside. 

Foods were home style dishes. If you are looking for luxuary one, you might be disappointed. But if you want to eat soul Japanese food, it's good. I ordered Katsu curry. I was satisfied with this taste and volume. Udon as side of curry, good taste. Soup was traditional taste in
west part of Japan.

Price were neutral. Inside of this restaurant, it was not new. Really old and crowded like a diner in Japan.

Totally, I give 4 stars.
author: Daimon R.

description: A wonderful place for a great taste of authentic Asian cooking in San Francisco.  IVery friendly staff and clean atmosphere.  The portions are very generous and the food was very good.  Will definitely stop here again when in the area.
author: Victor D.

description: Good food, decent prices and nice service. Not a high-end place but great if you want a relaxing, good meal. There may be a line at busy times. I'm definitely coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Rocklin M.

description:
This was my very first time ever eating at a Japanese Restaurant at the San Francisco Downtown Area... I was here yesterday just to eat lunch on my day off from work!!! As I got here to the Dojima - Ann it wasn't quite that busy yet as I got in and was greeted by the friendly Waitress right away as she took me to my table... As I was looking through the Dojima - Ann Menu Book and this what I always like to eat when eating at a Japanese Restaurant!!! 

And that would be Croquettes and Tonkatsu Donburi!!! After eating it all up this Dojima - Ann Japanese Restaurant wasn't to bad at all!!! And my 3 piece Croquettes and Tonkatsu Donburi came out really good and I really liked eating it!!! As I left Dojima - Ann it started to get realy crowded I guess the people do like coming here for lunch!!! If going back to Dojima - Ann I definitely would want to try another yummy Japanese Style food!!!
author: William B.

description:
I heard they had good udon here and we wanted something hot and soup, so I came here for the udon and I'm so glad I did.

We got sansai udon (vegetarian), chicken and egg w/ shrimp tempura udon, some seaweed salad, and avocado/cucumber rolls. It cost $38 and took only 10 minutes of me waiting for carry-out. 

Food was super yummy and I'm so happy that the soup stayed super hot even by the time I started eating it about 20 minutes later. Between 2 people, we ate everything and felt pleasantly full, so they have good-sized portions for their soups (about 32 oz plastic container). 

I also noticed they charge 10 cents for a bag, which I heard is an SF thing. I'm from Chicago and large retailers charge 7 cents for a bag, but not restaurants, so the bag charge was new but acceptable to me. If I had known, I would have brought my reusable bag with me since I try to be eco-friendly and bring a reusable bag with me everywhere and maybe I wouldn't have needed to use one of their bags? Hmm, not sure.

Restaurant was pretty full when we got there but wait was short, so I'm glad we got carry-out. Thanks for the quick, yummy dinner! :)
author: Kari H.

description:
Not my favorite but i keep returning to this place!
Decent casual japanese sushi-roll and home style foods. 

Notes:
- combo menus costs fairly cheap for the quality! 
- it smells near the restroom area. (Further side of the entrance) 
- plates and cups are not too clean. I usually wipe it with my napkins with water 
- if it was cleaner, i would give it a 4 star 
- baked rolls are tasty!
author: Eli K.

description:
10/20 update to this review: this place is consistently the BEST Japanese restaurant for UDON in Union Square. I covet this place and visit EVERY month when I am in town for work. Today was another amazing udon experience!!! Thank you Dojima-Ann!


This place is actually under-rated! It gets 5stars because they are the BEST little Japanese place on Union Square! Their Udon Noodles -a favorite of mine- is just like how mom makes it. Flavorful, consistent, and delicious! 
The place offers all sorts of traditional Japanese dishes and is always busy as it's popular with the tourists.....but the dead giveaway that this place is good: it's always filled with Japanese tourists! I used to eat lunch here several times a week when I lived & worked here. Now, I visit this place monthly and ALWAYS look forward to eating here.
The owner of this place is always accommodating of groups and even if there is a line, it's never too long. It's also SO WORTH THE WAIT! 

I LOVE eating here. It's my comfort food made just like my Oka-san's (mom's in Japanese)
author: Kristy S.

description:
Visited for a late-night dinner on a Sunday and the place was still quite packed. The interior is extremely small, so tables are placed very closely together. I do not recommend coming here if you are claustrophobic! I am not very claustrophobic, but still felt a bit uncomfortable.

This is the most expensive bento pricing I have seen. For close to $20, you can order a 2-item bento box. You do get a hefty portion with your two items, plus it comes with salad and miso soup. The main item entrees tasted quite fresh as well. I also enjoyed that the tempura udon was not overly salty. Nonetheless, other places serve up better tasting food at a lower price point. This place does win with location, being only a short walk away from Union Square.

Walk or take public transportation here. Service is friendly when you are able to flag someone down, which will be pretty difficult when they are busy. Also, expect a wait for your food to arrive. Not a horrible place for Japanese cuisine, but I probably won't be dining here on a regular basis either.
author: Kristi T.

description: I used to work down the street from Dojima-Ann about twenty years ago and used to eat lunch there ALOT because the food was delicious and fair priced. I recently went there for lunch and guess what...the atmosphere, food, and owners are the same as twenty years ago. The tonkatsu don was exactly how I remembered it being...oh so , especially with the running egg. I compare all other tonkatsu don against Dojima-Ann's. None have come close to the same intense and delicious flavors. Eating this dish made me happy and warm inside and out.
author: Stella G.

description: We have been eating at Dojima-Ann for the last 11 years.  Its services were never too great, but at least the foods were good.  Lately, the foods have become quite disappointing.  The last time we ate there in May of this year, the tempura tasted like they were fried quite a few hours ago ... much worse that those in the bento boxes sold in the market.  I think we need to explore some other Japanese restaurants near Union Square.
author: Akihiko Y.

description: Dirty cups, mushy warm fish on the rolls. Service was okay but definitely wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
The first impression: Place smelled stuffy. I was starving and the first three attempts at getting lunch had failed. I was seated immediately. Order taken quickly and food came out fast. Service was great even though the place was bustling for 2pm. About half the customers were Japanese. 
I got my usual- edamame, miso soup, salmon sashimi, and eel sushi. Food was fresh; loved the salmon and meaty eel.
The miso was good but tofu inside a little squishy like. The edamame were very good; I added a little more salt. 
I thought it was funny that one of the staff was taking a break at the sushi bar and eating a hamburger and drinking a Starbucks!
author: Maria-Elena T.

description:
I love this place! We found it by staying next door at the Villa Florence Hotel and I was so glad to find it. The food quality is great! The food itself is very good. I loved the sushi, tempura, and curry dishes they had. I liked this place so much that now, each time we go to SF, we go to Dojima Ann for a meal. The service was very good.

You can tell this is a real gem - at dinner time it is crowded with locals. You should try this place!
author: Heidi O.

description: Unpretentious, affordable, reliable lunch spot with fast service and a reasonably diversified menu featuring sushi, bento boxes, and udon/soba noodles.
author: Nat Z.

description: I'm always skeptical when a Japanese restaurant that offers donburi and udon also offers sushi, but Dojima-Ann does a pretty good job. I'd skip the sushi though, just because there are so many options around. The showstopper is their donburi. My mouth waters every time I think of their gyudon, katsu don and unatama don. Be prepared to wait if you come on weekends for dinner, but otherwise the wait is not too bad.
author: Carl W.

description:
I've come back quite a few more times due to its proximity to the Powell shopping area. My go-to dish is now the UNAGI DONBURI. The eel is still cooked perfectly and their rice texture is really good now! I also enjoyed their complimentary MISO SOUP -- it comes with so many tofu bits. 

My boyfriend recently ordered the TONKATSU DINNER SPECIAL and I had a bite. It was also very tasty! The pork cutlet was moist and well fried, and I enjoyed the Worcestershire dipping sauce on the side. This dish also comes with a complimentary miso soup and green salad.

I still feel the food is a good portion, you just pay a slightly higher premium due to its downtown location.

Just a quick note on the SERVICE -- we walked in around 5PM on a Saturday night and looked like we beat the dinner rush. However, it still took the hostess a few minutes before greeting us and taking us to a table. Our food arrived ~25-30 mins after ordering, so they do take some time in preparation.
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Very busy and convenient location but super slow for to go orders. The restaurant is pretty small and super tight inside
author: David B.

description:
I've eaten here twice now. I can say that (i) their food is good and reasonably priced, but their service (or lack of it) deserves no more than 1 star. 

First visit:
My girlfriend and I stopped in here for a quick lunch (see http://places.singleplatform.com/dojima-ann/menu?ref=google for their menu on a third party website). I had the fried aji (horse mackerel) lunch special, and my girlfriend a bento with pork katsu and croquettes. All the food was fresh, authentic, and more than adequate in quality for the price. The breading of the fried aji was too thick to my liking, but it's a small issue. If anything, I had more issue with the service or lack of it. It's probably a cultural issue, but I found the staff to be all VERY unfriendly. So, no more than 3 stars even with the decent quality of food and the reasonable prices. 

Second visit (December 2017):
Same with the first visit: decent food but the service was terrible/unfriendly. This time, we had to wait for about 15 minuets before being seated (see my practical tips below). My son ordered the kakiage ("stirred" tempura) udon. I liked that they served the kakiage on the side, which is normal served on the udon.  

Practical tip:
If there are more than 2 people in your party, be ready to wait to be seated. Most of their tables can seat only 2 people. Unless you're willing to sit at different tables, you would have to wait until two tables next to each other become available. Don't forget to put your name on the waitlist.

Note: I found their food to be very authentic. However, this place is run by Chinese people in case you care about authenticity. I'm Japanese born and raised there, but I thought their food was very authentic.

******************************
If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful." Your feedback helps me improve my future reviews. If you love food or traveling, don't forget to follow me! Thank you and happy Yelping!
author: Masanori D.

description:
I finally got a chance to try Dojima-Ann.  It's a place that I've been always curious to try because every time I walked by it, there was always a long wait line.  I came in for lunch with fellow yelper Elena N. on a Monday and it wasn't too busy when we arrived so we got seated right away.  But as expected, the place got crowded just a few short moments afterwards.

I came in pretty hungry so I started with their Sake Nigiri (http://bit.ly/2e9SYrP) and then since I've been on a mad hunt for awesome beef bowls lately, ordered their Gyu-Don (http://bit.ly/2e9PHIO).  The Sake Nigiri was fine I guess.  I don't really have much of a distinguished taste when it comes to sushi, but the pieces did look a little underwhelming to me.  They tasted fine in the end though.  The Gyu-Don though I really enjoyed.  It was a huge bowl of simmered beef and onions and it definitely filled me up to get me going for the rest of the day. 

Being that Dojima-Ann is in Union Square, I guess you can call it somewhat of a tourist trap, but the food is pretty decent, moderately priced and it's probably one of the better Japanese food options in that area.  The proof is in the long lines.  I'm just glad to know that there's a decent spot in Union Square where I can enjoy a hearty beef bowl.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Met up Rodney H here for lunch a couple weeks ago. We stopped by on Monday, September 26th around 12pm. They don't take reservations, but luckily, we beat the rush and got a table for 2 right away.

*Uni nigiri: sea urchin ($8)
*Toro nigiri: fatty tuns ($8)
*Hamachi nigiri: yellow tail ($6)
*Miso soup ($2.75)
*Small salad ($3.25)
*Sake nigiri: fresh salmon ($5.50)
*Gyu don: beef and onion on rice ($10)
*Iced green tea ($2.75)

I got the uni, toro, and hamachi nigiri as well as the soup and small salad. The soup and salad were standard. I find salad dressings at japanese restaurants a little sweet for my tastes, but this one wasn't too bad. The fish itself was good, but the size of the pieces were a little small. Since I don't like a lot of rice in my nigiri, I didn't mind the baby pieces of rice. The fish itself was cut a little thinner than I'm used to, but the price of the nigiri wasn't too bad for the items I ordered. I tried a bite of Rodney's bowl and it was pretty good. He seemed to enjoy it.

Overall, an average sushi experience. The restaurant is tiny, so make sure to get there early for lunch as it filled up while we were there.
author: Elena N.

description:
This is the first time in my life being told this: tips minimum 10%. And the amount on the receipt is tax included. They are cheating by adding tax to total on receipt and requiring 10% min tips. 
I tip based on their service, I will NOT go there any more.
author: Jasmin C.

description: This was a good lunch spot to drop into if you're in the area. Rolls were tasty, good amount of fish too. What made this place better was that the food came out quickly. Overall good experience and budget friendly.
author: Rocky M. S.

description: This place is kind of a Japanese diner. The food was just ok. Conveniently located by Union Square.
author: Susan S.

description: Long wait for a table but so worth it. Loved the miso soup and Chicken/Beef combo
author: Rick T.

description:
I was on the 38L Muni returning from viewing The Madeleine Albright collection aka "Read My Pins" at the Legion of Honor when the hunger hit me real hard. I was in the mood for Japanese food and need to eat like ASAP--like NOW. When the 38L made one of its limited stops, there was Dojima-Ann right there and I was near the rear bus exit. I immediately hopped off of the bus and rushed inside. I was taken aback by the small size of the establishment when I briskly walked in. Even a bit more jarring, there was a sign-in sheet. Okay, the heck with claustrophobia and the sign-in sheet, I am hungry, dammit! Yup, definitely hangry. So I signed my name in on the sheet. 

Fortunately, I did not have to wait long. I was escorted to a table for one and I caught sight of a corner table. I inquired if I could sit there instead. So I got my choice of the corner table. Not a good choice as the first seat against the wallI sat in, it was tres smelly. Must be a plumbing or ventilation situation between the building and the street. I chose to sit on the other side and all was all right. I was lucky to be situated near a pokestop to load up to catch them all. And I caught a few of the pokemon critters too that popped up on my screen.

I looked at the menu of the various offerings ranging from bowls to bento box combinations to sushi and sashimi dishes. I decided to combine the litmus test with avocado sushi, pork tonkatsu and shrimp tempura bento box accompanied by a side of tamago sushi. My order came out in a reasonable amount of time as Dojima-Ann was getting less crowded. I was finishing up the miso soup when my order arrived. The tonkatsu and the tempura were virtually not greasy--crisp to the bite and to the teeth. The tamago was moist and juicy on a mound of perfectly cooked sushi rice.

What bugged me a tad was waiting quite a bit in having to have my water glass refilled. Along with air, water is an essential for me--a definite le must while eating. Should have just left a water pitcher and carafe for me.

I had to wait a bit at the till to pay the bill. I was feeling a tad bit claustrophobic along with my usual self being in a royal hurry to leave. The manager was a tad bit gruff with a server at the till yet when he rang my bill up, he was pleasant to me.

Dojima-Ann sure killed my hunger/hanger pangs and pains, I felt like I was restored and refreshed to my civilized self. The food was pretty good and the service was all right. Just did not quite like having to wait to have my water glass refilled, short four-ounce glasses. And while I was contemplating about Japanese food and restaurants, Dojima-Ann seems to resemble authentic Japanese restaurants I have read about and discussed with people who have travelled to Japan--something I still have yet to do. If there is another opportunity to come back to Dojima-Ann and if the hunger is really killing me on the way back from my museum trips, I definitely shall return. Domo Dojima-Ann!
author: Chiara A.

description: Overpriced. $15.00 for average rolls of sushi using fake crab. The cuts of fish are small, and aren't the freshest, though they're not the worst. Not a large selection of exotic fish; most rolls are made with either tuna, salmon, eel, softshell, or imitation crab. Soba soup and udon entrees are a better choice here.
author: Alexandres M.

description: I have been eating here for almost 5 years, but im very disappointed and I think I should let people know so they can be aware. I found an extra protein(cockroaches) in my bowl of rice .
author: Peiling L.

description: this was so awesome. the dragon roll had a piping hot fresh tempura shrimp and their tonkatsu was so lightly breaded and fluffy it was like biting into a flaky croissant. the salad did not have a sweet dressing and their miso soup had diced fried tofu. im glad i came here.
author: Dustin M.

description:
Reasonably priced for Union Sq. 

But the soba lacked dashi. The natto and Tina was a bit too hard (recently defrosted). To be fair, the fried appetizers (kaki fry) is very good.
author: Ryo I.

description: My wife and I have lunch here every time we visit the City. She always has to have a Bento Box. Recently, I tried the Sashimi Sampler and the Fish was of excellent quality! We highly recommend this Resteraunt!
author: Scotty B.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite Japanese restaurants when visiting San Francisco. Fast service, tasty food, and good prices. But I emphasize "used to be".

What the heck happened? I think they are under new ownership or something. The service was super slow; one lady who was waiting for her takeout order was waiting for over 30min! And the food quality is just not there anymore. Prices went way up, too.

Will not be returning. Now I need to find a new Japanese restaurant to patronize while visiting the city.
author: Lureen K.

description:
This is a small, cozy Japanese restaurant right next to Union Square! The prices are better than some of the other Japanese restaurants in the area, and for downtown SF and the quality, seem pretty reasonable! 

I got the Mariawase Sashimi dinner special, which came with about 15 pieces of a variety of sashimi, a bowl of rice, an appetizer salad and miso soup for only $22! The fish was cut really thick and was so fresh and smooth (Is that the right way to describe sashimi?)

They have some really fresh sashimi, and from looking at the menu, they have a lot of pretty nice combos for good prices! There seems to be a lot of really expensive and classy Japanese restaurants around here, but I wouldn't underestimate Dojima-Ann!
author: Austin T.

description:
Portion sizes here can definitely be improved-- the special roll I had was considerably smaller than what I've seen at other restaurants. Would love to try the donburi next time, since it seems like it would be considerably more filling and satisfying.
Service was prompt, and everything was fine except for the fact that they kept forgetting our waters. The restaurant got pretty busy around 6 and since the tables are so close together, it began to feel a bit cramped. However, overall atmosphere was still pleasant.
author: Amy C.

description: Absolutely perfect. Small and cozy with limited seating, although we lucked out around 12:45 last Sunday and walked right in.  I had tempura udon and the tempura was outstanding, crunchy and light. We did not have to wait long. My guest had a few pieces of sushi and a bowl of a different udon. She loved both. We realized as we left that we were the only non-Asians there, which I take as a very good sign of authenticity and service. They did not disappoint! Will return!
author: Carol W.

description: For a chicken katsu curry which comes with a side salad AND udon. Really tasty curry, friendly service but way too much rice and not enough chicken for the price. The udon was okay. The salad it comes with is so delicious! I also got edamame and I thought it was a fair price.
author: Lena S.

description: 2 weeks ago my Filipino friends wanted to eat here despite my warning that everything was mediocre at best. Well, they learned their lesson. After being seated, we waited 20 minutes and had to call over a waitress to take our order as it was packed.  I had the feeling they were ignoring us.  The manager or owner at the register was glued to his phone the whole time.
author: Ken K.

description:
Dirty, slow and inattentive...and there was barely anyone in the place! Three orders. Two meals came out and the other ignored. Ok, so the green tea was drinkable but how can you mess that up?
Bathroom was like an outdoor latrine. I'd give no stars if it were an option.
author: Brian W.

description:
This place is a nice place for takeout or a quick meal. It has the basic Japanese - American dishes you would expect at an affordable Japanese resturant.  I came  here for lunch after shopping and the wait wasn't long especially on a weekday. The prices on yelp need to be updated because they've definitely increased the prices on their menu. I got the unagi (eel) bowl for $13.50 and potato croquettes ($8-9) on the side.
The ungai bowl was delicious. You can not go wrong with eel. I was a bit disappointed with the potato croquettes because one of them was soggy. Pretty expensive for three prices of croquettes when one wasn't cooked properly.
Service was okay, not too attentive and kind of slow. I sat in the corner back, so it was kind of hard to get their attention unless the are serving the table next to me.

If you are craving for Japanese food on a budget and you're around the area, this is the place to go. If you want authentic Japanese food, try some place else.
author: Grace Z.

description:
I was here before a few years ago and remember being happy with the food, atmosphere, and service. Things have changed.   :(

This time I didn't eat in, I got takeout, so no comments on service but the atmosphere in passing looked the same (small and simple interior). The rest is food related.

The first thing is that the prices are completely different than their menu that is posted on thier website (examples: Sashimi combo online $14, what they charged me $23.50; sushi dlx combo online $19.50, what they charged me $26.50). 

The other problrm was the fish. It was gummy, ill-textured, and fishy. The seaweed salad also had an off flavor. It was terrible food.

This was my last time here.
author: Amy F.

description:
The tonkatsu don no longer tastes as good as it used to be... The recipe totally changed... The sauce is gone... The eggs were over cooked...even the rice was mushy... 

I guess this is no longer a good place...

But I give it 3 stars because this place is known for udon, and I did not review that
author: Jason W.

description: Again a time i need a half star. This is a solid 3.5 but I'm rounding up because of price. Just got to to the SF, our rooms wasn't ready we where starving and craving Japanese food, this place was close. Very happy we stumbled in. The prices are perfect for the whole menu. Ordered the udon set 13.95 for a large beef udon and eel donbori. For the record this is the first time I have felt full on Japanese food. The service was good.
author: Doug J.

description:
The only reason I would give one star is that the food at Dojima Ann is not the worst. 
First off, attitudes given by the waitress when we first entered were absolutely horrible (already bad first impression). My mom and I visited this restaurant with high expectation since there has always seemed to be packed with people. However, we constantly felt "pushed" by the waitress-- as in she seemed to want us to leave and always cut us off when we spoke to her. 
Also, when us customers consider the concept of tips, it is with our choice to give them how much we want at a reasonable amount. Instead, tips were ALREADY added to our receipt as we were about to pay. Normally, we give really good tips to the employees at restaurants because of how hardworking they are, however, this time, their attitudes were horrible and still think they deserve the $6 tips? Don't be ridiculous. If this restaurant wants better reviews from other people, they better fix all of their issues. We will never come back again.
author: Hana L.

description: I was charged 32 dollars for an unagi don at Ryoko and that made me appreciate Dojima-ann so much more. Very reasonably priced Japanese food in downtown.
author: K Y.

description: A small Japanese restaurant by the shopping area and there was no line on Thursday night for dinner. The prices are very reasonable and it was pretty cheap for the tourist area. The food was ok. I order the chicken teriyaki bowl and it was pretty simple and nothing special at all.
author: Isabelle L.

description: Pretty good place! Ordered the Katsudon as well as a rainbow roll and some spicy tuna. Great portion wise, service was overall pretty good too. The sushi does leave a little to be desired, especially the 6-piece rolls. however, still a nice cozy place to eat
author: Terence T.

description:
I went here for lunch, I had the Saba Shioyaki with miso soup and rice.  I also ordered a salmon skin handroll and o-toro sashimi, however I was given a salmon handroll and o-toro sushi instead (this world have been 4 stars of not for those mistakes).

All the food read good and tasty, and not too long of a wait.  They did a decent job refilling my water and tea as well.

Worth it for the price, I'd eat here again for lunch sometime if I lived in the area.
author: Mark G.

description: I've been coming here for years and it feels like a great local joint right in the epicenter of touristy Union Square. The food is excellent and the service is sufficient. It's a small space and it fills up pretty quickly, but I've never had to wait too long for a table. I highly recommend the soba soup bowls!
author: Lisa F.

description:
We tried to go to the place across the road but it was closed and we were craving sushi so we decided on this spot.  What I was really craving was a poke bowl, but I had to settle for tuna.  We settled for sake and runs nigiri and the shrimp and cucumber appetizer.  It was all just mediocre.  Probably due to the fact that my craving wasn't satisfied by the sushi we had.

However the place was really small and the menus could probably do with a good wipe down.  Other than that the place was clean and decent but I probably wouldn't go back.
author: Nyla K.

description: I had an udon soup as my dinner. It is quite native and has no difference from that in Japan.
author: 鈺婷

description: One of the best places to get udon. Fair prices as well. Got the curry tonkatsu udon and it was fantastic. Udon noodles were soft silky and less starchy than any udon i ever had. Definitely a place that I would visit again if I'm ever in union square.
author: F K.

description:
Solid Japanese restaurant near Union Square and Powell Station! They have all the normal rice bowls (donburi), noodles, curry bowls, sushi you would expect of a typical Japanese restaurant and the rice bowls come with the option of adding a mini udon to your meal for a $3 extra. Overall, the quality of the food is pretty good and I especially liked the karaage-don (fried chicken bowl), where the chicken was crispy on the outside but still juicy and moist on the inside :P. There is also a decent quantity of food, as I had half my chicken and lots of rice leftover from my donburi after finishing off the mini udon. 

The only downside is that their service is a bit slow, both in terms of the kitchen's speed to churn out food as well as the waitresses response to requests (took them 10 minutes to refill my tea).

Overall, great location with great Japanese food, and there's lots of foot traffic given it's proximity to the shopping areas in SF, so it fills up quickly. They also have a pretty small store front, so you might have to wait (especially so if you are a big group). I've also seen a quite a few people stop by for take out too.
author: Jennifer W.

description: This place is very small and tight. If you see a long line outside, it might just be the tourist looking at the plastic food displayed on their window. However, it can actually mean it's packed. You need to put your name on the list for a table.
author: Monica Colleen D.

description:
I ordered the Oyaku Don and it's good.
I gave this place two stars because of the rude and sucks service.
The boss/ owner was rude and mean!
We were 10 people and expecting to have a bigger table.
The owner insist not to merge the table so we ended up sitting in 3 separate tables!!!
So lame!
The point of having lunch here was to chit chat and talk with long-time-no-talk/ see friends, but instead we sit in the separate tables! wth!
author: Candice L.

description: The tonkatsu don buri here is really good. Unfortunately, I burned my tongue on the miso soup that came out beforehand, so my experience was not as good as it should have been, but that's on me for being impatient. The service and prices were good as well. I recommend you try it out if you like Japanese food.
author: Eric F.

description: This is literally a hole in the wall.  It is a very small restaurant.  When you get there put your name on the list.  We didn't have to wait long to get a table.  The place was full.  The service is about taking your order, serving your food and paying the bill.  The tea is good.  The edamame was warm, salty and good.  Miso soup was very good.  The side salad had a unique ginger dressing...very good.  The Chirashi was REALLY REALLY GOOD.  Fresh pieces of fish and tamago over perfect sushi rice.  YUM!  And the cost was reasonable for what I ordered. I love little places like this.  It's no thrills but they do it right.  I went to a "fancier" sushi restaurant and paid more for meh sushi.  If you get the chance visit this little place.
author: Kimba L.

description:
I have been to Dojima-Ann twice now and I finally decided to write a review! Been here once during lunch time and once during dinner. Beware that dinner time the wait can me as long as 30 mins! 
It pretty worth it for the price of food you get at this place for the amount they give you. I would recommend getting the sets that are listed on the signs posted on the walls of the restaurant. You can get a bowl of udon and a bowl of chicken teriyaki don for $13.50! Which is the same cost as some of the items on the menu! Sometimes food can take a while to come after you order it.
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
I just reminded of the days that I were in Osaka.
I had Tonkotsu don here, and the taste is really like it and like the Don in Osaka.
The pork is soft and good combination with the half-baked egg.
author: Yuichi E.

description: We stay nearby during our visit.  The place is small but the food was delicious.  My kids like it that they ask to comeback second time.  The udon was soft and chewy.  Must order Kari Fried (deep fry oyster). It was crunchy, sweet and moist.  Price is reasonable consider that this is located near Union Square.
author: Thuy H.

description:
Dojima-Ann wasn't great, but it wasn't bad either.  Service is quick and efficient with little personality.  Some things are better than others.  I can't imagine why anyone would wait in line to get in here though with other great alternatives in the vicinity.

My honey and I ordered a sashimi plate, saba (mackerel), uni (sea urchin), two miso soups and two salmon skin handrolls.  The sashimi plate was okay.   The portion sizes were nice but not the freshest.  It's probably why we got more saba with also which was very fresh.  I usually get uni with a quail egg, and she asked if I wanted sashimi style.  I opted to try it this way sans quail egg.  It arrived with generous portions on an orange and was fresh and tasty.  Our miso soups were hearty and loaded with green onion, seaweed and tofu puffs.  Regular tofu would have been better.  The puffs were like pieces of mushy bread in the soup.  The best thing here was the salmon skin hand roll.  It arrived hot, considerable amounts of salmon skin, meat with less rice and cucumber.  It was delicious!

I would'nt pass Dojima-Ann up completely in the future.  Their salmon skin handroll is so yummy.  Who knows how their ramen or udon is.  Like I said, some items are better than others.  I may return for a small bite.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Stopped in for a solo dinner.  Saw donburi on the sign so took a shot at my childhood fav, katsu-don.  It was fkn killer, great, like legit authentic that I don't find in NJ. Had a Kirin ichiban. Waitresses were rushing around, no biggie, served me fine.  I'll be back to try the soba and sushi
author: P H.

description: I'm in San Francisco looking for some good sushi. Well I found the one place in the entire city that you should not go to. Walgreens down the block has better sushi than this place. You couldn't chew the seaweed wrapper. The tuna was filled with cartilage lines. They got my order wrong.I asked for and paid for avocado in my tuna roll and didn't get it. The only good thing about it was the ginger and wasabi and soy sauce. I wish that I could give this place less than one star but Yelp won't let me. Stay away if you want anything except a stomachache and tapeworm.
author: Neil P.

description:
Oh my god I've never had such an...interesting (?) dinner?? At first I was really happy to be seated in 5 mins despite the line but weird things happened. First off, the restaurant is EXTREMELY tight and cramped. I wouldn't be surprised if we were over the maximum capacity because I see a huge fire hazard problem. The guy sitting with his friends behind me had to squeeze through the chairs to get all the way to the bathroom! Later on in the dinner, a waitress spilled hot soup on a child which was kinda sad but more an annoyance because of the kid's yelling. Plates were broken 5 minutes later in the kitchen. The waitress (I think she's the owner actually) yells at customers for not listening to her...omg

I'm very tempted to just give 1 star but the food wasn't bad. I got the eel and rice donburi which tastes really yummy and my bf's beef rice was good too! We got the mini udon but it wasn't very flavorful. The fried chicken was really crispy but honestly we couldn't finish it because the rice and udon were very filling. 

Bottom line, I wouldn't come back. I'll never forget the dinner though hahaha
author: Tiffany E.

description:
This place is small, and feels like an off-beat Japanese place in Japan. Food is awesome. Everything from sushi, donburi, curry, udon/soba is awesome. 

Definitely a great stop in SF!
author: John P.

description:
Came here for lunch (for 1), waited 2mins for seat, fast service, ordered:
Una Tama Don (come with free miso soup): Sooooo Good, at least 3 big pieces of Unagi and the rice taste super soak with Tama juice, is a bit on the salty side but it's yummy, the miso soup have tofu puff instead of regular tofu.
Tekka & Avocado Maki: ok not good or bad, Tekka is good and avocado is fresh, the Nori is a bit chewy.
Overall a very good experience, I'll be back!!!
author: HL W.

description: Typical but tasty. No bells, no whistles, no flair, no pizzazz - just good taste, which is enough. I love that San Francisco hosts that kind of variety in its eateries.
author: Xavier A.

description:
Delicious authentic food and affordable price! This is it, there is no need to search further for another Jap restaurant in this vicinity! 

Was yelping for Japanese food and found this near to where we were at. From past reviews, we were expecting to queue but thankfully we were seated immediately. 

We ordered a Tonkatsu Don and two Beef Don. They came with a miso soup which was absolutely yummy, perhaps a little too much MSG though as we all felt really thirsty after.

The Dons were fantastic!! The eggs covering the Don was done so well, they were super juicy! The meat were also really very delicious, every bite was so good. The meat portion were huge and plenty of rice too.

For three dons set and green tea, it cost us a total of $34 (excluding tips). Really reasonable for the qualifying and portion! Highly recommended!
author: Cindee T.

description: Great Food! I just love their Set Options (Don + Noodle - Soba or Udon) Come here every time I come to SF and the food is always great. Got Sushi Sashimi for the First Time and the fish quality was very fresh.
author: Kevin C.

description:
First meal right off SFO. Udon was good. Geso age was great. Kids enjoyed their curry with pork cutlet.
I was a bit disappointed with vegetable tempura. The batter was bland. 
Service was awesome. The broth was kansai style which I love.
Will return!
author: Ayako H.

description: Popped in here around 1 pm on a rainy weekday. There were 3 or 4 names ahead of me on the wait list. I didn't check my watch but I'd guess that I waited around 15 minutes to be seated. Most people waiting for a table tried to squeeze in around the hostess table to stay out of the rain - it's a small restaurant so there wasn't a lot of space for us. The place was full of dudes in suits but it had a very casual vibe. I ordered the udon soup with tempura and thought it was pretty good! Would return. I believe I saw a sign saying that there is a $10 minimum to pay with credit card.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Combo sushi was about $21 for 7pieces, fish pieces are so thin and not taste flesh.
Nabeyaki Udong was too salty, the broth was only taste like soy source. Tempura was ok but in general too pricey for the poor quality. Just get the lunch special for kinda affordable price, other than that it is not worthy to try.
author: Lee J.

description:
Located in Union Square so was skeptical about trying this place. I figured it would be subpar food at exorbitant prices with tiny portion sizes, but it was the exact opposite! There always seems to be a line but the restaurant is super tiny and they already pack in as many people as they physically can. 

Menu has plenty of options and everything sounds tasty. Prices are pretty cheap for Japanese food (especially in the city), and portions are pretty big. You can also add a side of udon to the donburi! Sushi/sashimi also looks fresh and come in decent cuts. Specials on their board are unique and combos are worth it. 

Definitely a good spot for some Japanese comfort food!
author: Maryann S.

description:
Nigiri was ok, sushi rice has too much vinegar. Onigiri lacked salmon (big rice ball with a very tiny amount of salmon). Miso was ok, non traditional. Ordered a salmon skin roll which is a pretty basic roll and the chef barely managed to keep the roll together. I can't imagine ordering a large or complicated roll. 

Service is ok - but slow. Overall I gave it two stars because of the slow service, and overall substandard food.
author: Jared D.

description: Amazing casual but authentic Japanese food. Expect a short wait. Highly recommend the chicken katsu
author: Christopher W.

description:
I've been here twice.

First time was OK. I thought its a touristic place to eat, but actually its not bad. Price was reasonable, and service was fair.

OK here's the thing. I came here again with friend after work. We've been waiting for almost 20mins for the food, and the server didn't seem like really care, just saying "the food its coming, its coming!"and left. We were starving at all time.

The food this time were bad, not tasted anything at all. I got the tonkatsu curry udon, its just like a curry colored udon soup. And my friends ginger pork rice didn't has taste too, that's so disappointing.

That's not the worst part, after we were done, we asked for the check. The check was hand written, and wait a second...60BUCKS!?FOR REAL? For two dinner set. How can you make this calculation? I didn't order alcohol, and I was so sober. I heard that some shady restaurant they will scam you if you go with a big party. I was so disappointed at them, I m not sure if there's mistake or what, I told them to double check, and they gave me the printed receipt at the end. 

Based on the food, mostly the service, I m not sure there's next time. Will see.
author: Natasha L.

description: I was touristing around when hunger stuck and this place was around. I was dying to have some SF sushi, and this place was the perfect spot to go. I got the salmon don and oh man was it delicious!!!! So many fresh pieces of thinly sliced salmon on top of sticky sushi rice, perfect. The meal was a lunch special and came with miso soup and a small ginger salad. A great lunch!
author: Ally T.

description:
Gave this place 3 stars because service was a bit weird. I ordered a Nabe Yaki (udon with shrimp tempura, chicken, egg, veggies, etc.) and asked for the tempura to be placed on the side because I don't like it soggy. 

Waitress brought out my dish. There was one tempura placed to the side but then one tempura placed in the udon so obviously it was soggy. I proceeded to take out the soggy tempura and placed it to the side. As I began to eat, the waitress came back and straight up told me I was only allowed one tempura....I looked at her oddly and was confused as to why she told me this. 

This is where it gets weird, because she then asks if I had eaten any of them and I said I touched them. With that, she takes her chopsticks and proceeds to take one of the tempuras away into a bowl and into the kitchen. 

Whether she threw it away or gave it to an unsuspecting customer, I will never know.

Regardless, that was a bit off-putting and uncomfortable.

Food was good though
author: Alice C.

description:
Dojima-Ann is not the fanciest Japanese restaurant you'll ever dine in, but I guarantee that you'll eat very well! It is located right in downtown, very close to Union Square. There were lots of Japanese tourists and locals flocking to this place, so we had to check it out. To be quite honest, it is not spacious at all and if you go with a group with more than three people, it will be difficult to find a place to sit.

I ordered a Dragon Roll, a few pieces of sushi, two dishes of salmon sashimi, and an Ito-en Cold Green Tea. Everything came in big portions! Even the sashimi pieces were huge! This place surpassed my expectations, and I was satisfied with everything I ordered (even though I couldn't finish half of it). If you like sushi served in generous portions, this is your place!
author: Steve N.

description: Was staying across the street and got a delicious soba soup to go late at night. Quick takeout process and stayed tasty even 20 minutes after leaving. Yum!
author: Alit E.

description:
The food is pretty standard for a Japanese restaurant. They have a wider selection of items varying from udon to sushi to donburi. I had the tonkatsu curry rice and my friends both had the una tama don (unagi with egg on rice). The food was as expected from any Japanese diner. The tonkatsu was a little tough but was fried nicely and was not greasy.  The tonkatsu came with a small side salad with a tasty vinaigrette. The una tama don was on the sweet side but was still tasty, it came with a side of miso soup.

Service was standard however I wished the waitress would have been more attentive to our drinks. I did have to repeatedly ask for water refills. The waitress also weirdly asked one of my friends to pay with cash but allowed the other to pay with card. I was unsure if this was because they split the check or if there was a miscommunication between my friends and the waitress.

Prices are normal for a place in SF. A meal was around 12-18 dollars. They are located right off of Union Sqare. We passed a few times and there seemed to always be a group of people huddled outside. The restaurant is quite small inside but seating for groups of 2-4 should not take long.

Overall the food was good and the restaurant was a nice break from the overly touristy, sub-par food that surrounds Union Square.
author: Michelle K.

description: GROSS--I found a "vein" (intestine) in the tempura shrimp.  Waitress said "customers don't care".  I told her that I care "oh, sorry".  That's it !!  If you "CARE"...I would go somewhere else.
author: D O.

description: Good quick bite. Sushi was decent (Alaska roll) and reasonably priced at $6.50. Salmon dish was tasty, asked for no teriyaki. Rice was flavorful. Salad was nice.
author: Dal G.

description:
Sat at the bar didn't have to wait for the table.  The bar seat probably 5 people but it was only 2 of us...so we were fine!  Enjoyed the two rolls we ordered.  
The uni&yam cold soba was special on their board which turned out to be very special and yummy dish.  The menu options were good enough being in the middle of the hotels.  It sure is convenient and cool spot for Traditional Japanese restaurant.  We shall return next time we're in town!
author: Warunee G.

description:
Average sushi, great donburi, utilitarian dining room.

The dining room is crowded and has a mild mildew like smell. It's probably just an eco-friendly cleaning solution, but the overall impression was nasty enough for me to decide on takeout instead.

Like many Sushi restaurants, they don't give you little soy dipping bowls, just the takeout soy sauce pouches. This is unfortunate when you are staying at a hotel. How do you get that perfect blend of soy and wasabi, when you don't have little plastic bowls? My lord, even the little sushi stand at SFO Terminal 2 gives you little dipping bowls with your takeout.

The Sashimi Combo was good, but my favorite items on their menu are the Donburi. The Una Tama Don in particular is awesome. Broiled eel, raw quail egg, white slimy mystery stuff, onions, and eel sauce on rice. Ok, I'm a self professed eel addict, but this is still Slimy Eel Heaven.
author: David T.

description: I've so far only ordered the salmon-don, which is just salmon sashimi over sushi rice. The first time it came with what I felt was a really good amount of salmon, where I didn't even have any leftover sushi rice. The second time however, I had a lot of leftover rice, so I guess their generosity in salmon sashimi is a little inconsistent. The price wasn't too bad for SF though so I was pretty satisfied with my meal both times. There are quite a few other items on the menu that look pretty good, like their katsu curry or their teriyaki. I haven't tried any sushi yet so can't really speak to that. Next time I'll probably look to their specials menu to try something new, but I feel like the salmon-don is still a pretty good way to go.
author: Wayne H.

description:
I think my mistake was ordering nigiri here, when the sushi chef wasn't even visible in the dining room.  The sushi took 40 minutes to come out, and when it did, the rice was warm (eww) and the fish not fresh.  

The restaurant was packed at 2PM on a Saturday though, and most other people were ordering the noodles -- so I may come back again and try something else.
author: Robbie B.

description: the food was not so good . The waiter told us the bill is not included with tax , they force us to give the tip more with so unpolite manner and angry face ! they said to us how much tip we should give . We will not come back again
author: Valerie A.

description: Awesome place with a decent price tag. Forget the menu read and order from the specials board.
author: Eric A.

description:
Delicious Japanese food @ less than $15 per item? You have to check it out. 

Upon walking by Dojima-Ann yesterday, my roommate exclaimed "This place looks exactly like the restaurants I saw in Tokyo last week!" Her remark plus the long line outside convinced me that this was a promising dinner opportunity.

Our wait was around 20-25 minutes but fortunately there were plenty of shops around the block to peruse as we waited. Note: They don't take your cell phone number so you have to make sure you're around when you expect your name to be called.

We ordered an Oyako Don, Alaska Roll, Spicy Tuna Roll, and Ebi Tempura Udon to share among three people. Everything was both delicious and filling! Only change I would appreciate is for the egg in my Oyako Don to be more runny. 

Restaurant is a bit cramped due to the small space. Moreover, sushi rolls menu is also fairly limited if you're looking for a diverse sushi-centric meal but the menu is comprehensive in terms of other Japanese items (soba noodles, donburi, etc.)
author: Arushi S.

description: Walked in to place takeout order and they refused saying too busy. Tried calling and they just said no takeout and hung up. Pretty rude the way they communicated.
author: J. L.

description:
I have stopped in here several times when walking back to the Hilton from the Powell BART station.  I like this place because within 10 minutes, I can be back on my way to my hotel with my sushi to go.
I'm a pretty basic sushi lover... I generally get the salmon sashimi and the shrimp tempura roll.  
Service is good; they actually seem to like my to-go orders (maybe because I don't take up a table just for one person... As the restaurant isn't very large).
author: Ann J.

description: Super slow service. Don't go there if you are in a rush. The curry Katsu udon touched the spot! (Taste is comparable to Shin Sengumi's - a little spicier, but katsu is too hard)
author: Kittyanne h.

description:
Yamakake cold Udon-taste rubbish
water cup still have soap or soda taste lasttime
author: Yoshi S.

description:
Popular San Francisco restaurant a few blocks from Union Square. Generally patronized by locals and tourists. I have always enjoyed their food and this visit was no different.
Service was friendly and good despite restaurant being busy. 
I ordered a hot sake and their Shioyaki Kama. Order came with a salad, and miso soup. I had forgotten that their salad and miso soup is the weak link to a great meal.  

Salad consisted of head lettuce, tomatoes and miso dressing. No flavor, no imagination, or taste, presentation zero.  
Shiro miso soup was similarly flavorless; salty. No umami. 

The Kama however was great. Perfectly grilled, fresh, delicious, and satisfying. Served with perfectly cooked white rice. Lacking was a beautiful presentation that the Japanese are well know for. 

The beauty and presentation of Japanese food is as important as the taste and demonstrates the passion for the food. I only hope on my next visit the passion is found.
author: Glenn M.

description: Welcome, present, and fast service. A great place for a stop in even if you're only coming in for hot sake and edamame. If you're from out of town, and love Japanese like I do, this is your new favorite spot!
author: Cayenne P.

description: Good basic foods such as udon or beef curry but their age Dashi tofu was not good.   They use potato flour so it's very chewy and the flavor doesn't get inside to the tofu.  It's like eating under cooked flour and get to a bland inside.
author: vivan c.

description: This place was near the Curran theater so we decided to have a quick lunch before the show.  We ordered the two item bento box. I think they cost $14.95 or $15.95. My friend had the salmon with tempura and I had the chicken teriyaki with tempura. Came with soup, salad and orange slices. All items were a good portion size.  Both salmon and chicken were tender and flavorful. Service /staff were very attentive. We were also provided with free tea. But I took off two stars because the windows facing the street as well as the mirrors in the back were dirty and filthy. Every time I looked up that was my view. All I could see was dirty street windows and mirrors full of hand smudges. Secondly, while I was presented with the detailed bill originally, the charge slip that came back did not have the detailed receipt. This annoyed me because I want to be sure the charge total is correct before I add in the tip. Despite these two comments, I think I would still return if I was in the neighborhood. I would sit facing a different direction.
author: Sylvia O.

description:
This restaurant is not worth going. They have terrible service and waited 30 mins for udon and soba and several table that came before us received their food before. Mainly their foods aren't good. The soba noodle tasted undercooked and the tempura and egg tasted frozen. Inside the udon I had this small plastic unknown thing which was disturbing. I would definitely not recommend this place. Dirty glasses too. 

They have a hidden food safety record of 79 behind the dirty wall that separates the dirty stairs.

Disgusting
author: Cathy L.

description:
This restaurant is very close by to my place of employment, so naturally it's a go-to for when I don't feel like eating the cafeteria food.

I've eaten inside the restaurant just once before during the day on a weekday so there was no wait, and the service was sub-par, nothing too fancy but not underwhelming as well. 

I normally order the ebi udon to-go. That's udon with shrimp and vegetable tempura (~$12). My boyfriend enjoyed his bento box that he ordered with chicken katsu and all the fixins (miso soup, rice, salad, etc.)

Definitely a place that I'll keep visiting when I crave for udon, which is pretty often! 
***But I think i'll keep it as a to-go restaurant, not so much a dine in.***
author: Kathleene E.

description:
Be prepared to wait in a line to get a seat.
This place is always packed as its ryte next to union square. The foods not too bad cuz I've had better in San Francisco. But the price is really sweet! The staff are efficient and the service is fast too!
author: P K.

description:
Small place we stumbled upon to get a quick bite. Place is small and it was packed. The tables were packed in that chairs from different tables would hit yours. The service was rude and inattentive. I asked for things several times to different people before I got what I wanted (straws and water). 

I ordered the soba noodles with tempura. I've had soba noodles elsewhere and usually they have sesame seeds with some flavorful oil. These soba noodles had no flavor once so ever. The tempura, however, was lightly battered and was tasty. The rock 'n roll sushi was salty, but you can tell the eel was fresh since it was warm. My friend ordered the udon which also had a salty broth. 

The waitress did split the bill without us having to ask which was convenient. I would not recommend this place nor would I come back here again. I can eat somewhere else that is cheaper with better service and food.
author: Jenna T.

description:
Wow great little Japanese place in Union square with tasty Donburi! The egg and sauce with grilled onions makes for an amazing and filling dish! I ordered the tonkatsu donburi with a mini udon and couldn't even finish the udon. 

The udon is soft and chewy but I definitely didn't need it. I will be back to try more dons!!!

Yum!
author: Jessica C.

description: Very cute and quaint place. Came here during the San Francisco heat wave. No air conditioning. Miso soup is good. I got a donburi dish, wasn't anything write home about. Tempura was also all right. The gyoza was ok. I probably just did this wrong.
author: Bryant E.

description: Prob one the better Japanese curry places outside of japan town. It's a little more costly than other places ~$15 for a oyakodon or katsu curry over rice. Great food and there's always a line outside which says something. 4 stars because the prices are a bit on the higher side for Japanese curry...
author: R T.

description: Decent Japanese restaurant, had a pretty long line outside but the wait was ~15 minutes. Had beef teriyaki and sushi combo, both tasted fine. Also tried their maguro yamakake, saw videos of that dish in Japan at Izakayas, been wanting to try it out. Not sure if I was expecting anything else from yam + tuna but wasn't really that out of the world.
author: Michael Z.

description:
Divey, sure, but crowded in the best way and wonderfully satisfying. I can't speak for the sushi,  apart from the excellent inari (sweet bean curd skin stuffed with seasoned rice--an all-time favorite of mine!) but the unagi donburi was delicious and filling. The table next to ours had a ramen bowl that made me want to stay for second lunch, but that will just have to be a next-time order. If the miso soup is any indicator--rich, salty, but spot on--the broth-laden soups must be tasty as well.

Definitely quick and easy, as long as there isn't a wait, and worth every dollar, even though you could hardly spend more than $13 an any one thing beyond a large sushi meal. If you are looking for an elegant and delicate Japanese meal, this place is not for you, but for anything else, give it a go.
author: Joss K.

description: Food, drinks, services are all good but don't like how small the restaurant is and how I felt/am very squished in there surprise they can make a restaurant out of this tiny store probably used to be something else before was restaurant building itself.
author: Lorrie T.

description:
I found wonderland! I'm not much for words or details. However, I will say it's exceptional! Bento Box for your busy days during a conference, hungry and needing good food quickly. Hamachi (yellow tail) to fill the hunger void while on the go! (It's SOOO good and protein, protein, protein and Delicious and fresh) UDON bowl to keep warm during a foggy night!

Ambience: Japanese
Food: Japanese
Service: Japanese

*NOM NOM!
author: Angel E.

description:
I had been a regular customer, getting dinner here about once a week when I stay late at work. However tonight's the last time I would be here for a while if ever. 

The restaurant had some scattered empty seats.  the hostess ignored us for about 10-15 minutes before we finally stopped her and ask if it would be possible for us to sit at the bar. To that she asked "what, so you sit across from each other with a person in between?" We asked her "is it possible to combine the two empty seats so we can sit by the bar?" the waitress extended her hands in the air "you know what, I don't want to bother him."

I like the food but it's not good enough for me to take the attitude from the staff or to pay a cent more to people who make me feel bad in general. 

Dojima- you just lost a regular customer. Recommend you to think about your customer service quality and fire the staffs who can't hold up the standard.
author: Isabelle E.

description: happened to park on the street right near Dojima-Ann and decided to stop in and check it out.  we only had an hour to eat before we had to be at our show.  so besides this being convenient it seemed like a better option than Chipotle which is directly across the street.  Thankfully it was much better than Chipotle and I would absolutely stop here again!
author: Kim F.

description:
Delicious Katsu / Curry, great customer service! 

I used to drop by here every time I had training for work in San Francisco. They never fail to impress!
author: William C.

description:
A great spot if you're looking for something that is not overpriced nor overly touristy.

They aren't known for their sushi - they are known for their donburi and noodle soup dishes. Curry katsu is my usual order - and this comes with a bowl of udon, rice, miso soup, and a salad. This is a lot of food for the price (~13). I've on occasion had their sushi rolls, too - definitely above average. 

A 10-15min wait is fairly common for groups as they are right by Union Square. There are often empty seats at the bar area, however, if you're willing to sit there. Service is decent.
author: Elisa L.

description: Small place and it was packed when I got here Sunday evening.  Kind of amazed me after eating the sushi.   Ordered the giant role with Salmon on top and it was of quality 1/5. The fish seemed stale and the preparation was just poor. Save yourself and try a different sushi place in the area given there is one at every corner around here.
author: Bay L.

description: Simply delicious food and good service.  Went in late and had best teriyaki chicken and rice I have eaten in a long while!!! And they have my favorite tea!!!
author: Nicole k.
