description:
I love getting sushi and udon at this place when I go shopping in union square. It's gives me fuel to keep shopping without being heavy in my stomach. 

All the sushi is great. The rolls have good prices too. Their fish is very fresh, I recommend getting a roll that features just that. I love the hamachi roll and the rainbow roll. 

Their udon is delicious too. I love the curry udon. The broth is spiced perfectly with curry and filled with udon noodles, onion, and beef. They also include a few slices of delicious fish cake. Yum!

They serve sake, beer, and other imported soft drinks- ramune sodas, bottled teas, canned coffee, yogurt drinks, and more! 

This place is small and packed with tables. It may not be a place for a big group, but the tables have plenty of space for all your food. 
Though it's small, the servers work hard and the tables turn around quickly. Even with a few groups ahead on the wait list, you can get seated quick, and get out quick. Back to the stores!

There's so many chain restaurants around union square, but go to this unique sushi bar instead. You won't regret it.
author: Marisa W.

description: The food was good and the service was quick. We are here after walking by several times during our stay. The place was crowded during lunch and the tables were closely arranged but our waitress was friendly and the food was enjoyable. The food was reasonably priced and the atmosphere was pleasant.
author: Robyn Y.

description: Came here with my friends for lunch. I was craving some food Japanese food. I happened to be at union square buy I've never quite found delicious food nearby except for elephant sushi which is very delicious but it's not exactly described to be something near Union square. I ordered a bento box with terriyaki chicken and California roll. I was disappointed by it. The total price is 13.95 not including tax and tip. The portion was severely small, chicken was pretty dry, terriyaki sauce was good but I mean.. It's like putting ranch in fries, there's nothing wrong with the ranch. There was quite an abundance of rice, two slices of orange, and some small California roll. The wasabi that came with it was definitely not enough. I had to ask for more, service wasn't quite that great either. I had to ask a couple of times for more tea and they didn't come by willingly except at the end to collect the money. Overall, okay experience, wouldn't go back for the food nor service.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Dojima Ann is a casual Japanese dining on O'Farrell. I love the ease of just popping in for a quick meal when I'm running errands in town. The value for money is pretty good here. Although it's not exactly a mind-blowing culinary experience, there is a real value in having a quick and authentic Japanese food available right at the city centre. This place reminds me of cafeterias in Japan in many ways. I guess it's the casual vibe and the pretty generic and all-encompassing menu. You get noodles, sushi, tempura, rich dishes from the same place. It sounds like a good deal to me. They have sushi too but I usually go for rice dishes for the value of money. (Calorie intake per dollar, basically) 

If you study the menu carefully, you will find that there are many ways to get some extra carbs for hungry bears; like extra mini udon noodle for $2.95, or go for a mega combo for $17.95. 
I ordered a tempura rice with mini udon noodle. Both tempura and udon were good! I would have liked just a little bit more sauce on the rice. But it's just my weird personal thing. I like my rice drenched in sauce :) Udon broth was warm and refreshing. 

On a completely separate note, I've believed this establishment was called "Osaka" until very recently, because that's what it says outside the entrance in Japanese! I only know this now because I wrote this review. It was kind of a clue when a search for "Osaka, San Francisco" didn't get me any relevant result. I still think Osaka would have been a catchy name though.
author: Leo U.

description: The food was nice! I enjoyed the ambiance of this place. I would like to come back. :)
author: Abigail S.

description: Quality Japanese food at affordable prices. Had unagi tororo don. Unagi slice is big n the sweet sauce is just the right amount to make it not too sweet nor too dry. Miso soup taste great as well. Not too salty or bland like some joints. Will definitely return to try other dishes
author: Jeremy K.

description: Great for a quick bite when you're exploring Union Square and a need a place for quality Japanese food. I recommend the tonkatsu curry.
author: Adolphus C.

description: I got Bento for my lunch. It was ok to get lunch around downtown also, for me the food was a lot - i could not finish it.
author: Pinarat S.

description:
Don't let the dumpy atmosphere turn you away.  

If you are craving pretty tasty Japanese food that feels like "japan" Japanese food, you should come here.  I had:

tofu
natto 
beef bowl

They were really good.

Don't half step.  I'd suggest coming in small groups.
author: Brendon D.

description: First time here. The chicken and egg udon was unbelievable. The broth was complex, buttery, and delicious, and the noodles were just as they should be. If you're in need of comfort food then try this dish.
author: Christy F.

description: Been here twice, once for dinner and another for lunch. Both times weren't too crowded. The gyu-don and salmon don are decent. Other reviews talk about the pee smell, which I thought was due to our table being outside the toilet during the first visit. But the smell lingered for the second visit. Maybe they need better circulation. You will get used to the smell after being inside for a while though. I will still continue to visit as it's one of the better mid-range Japanese restaurants in downtown.
author: Lindt C.

description:
Chicken katsu was pretty good, rice and miso soup were very authentic taste, which is rare in Bay Area! While California roll was pretty bad, I give just one star for California roll.  
All in all, it was good. I'd like to come back here to try other meals.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
The basis of my review is solely on customer service. I wish I would have gotten a chance to try the food but we had to walk out of this establishment due to the crass and rude nature of one of the female waitresses (black hair, ponytail, with glasses).

And let the record show that if I could give this restaurant a rating of lower than one star, I would. Customer service is key anywhere and everywhere!

We walked in and the waitress seated us quickly. We got less than 2 minutes to look over our menus before the waitress rushed up to us asking if we were ready. My mom had a couple of questions about the portion size of the meals. The waitress let us know that the bento box was large, and pointed to another customer who was eating that very meal. The box was huge! So we decided to just order a soup and a bento box to start off our meals, and we asked to keep one menu to order more later into the dinner. For some reason this pissed off the uppity waitress and she let us know that we all had to order our own meals. My mom was confused and asked the waitress why, if she had just stated that the bento box was large. The waitress dismissed what she had just said a mere 5 seconds ago and began to belittle us claiming that they were "running a business" and that by ordering a bento box and another entree item for starters was apparently "not acceptable". My mom continued to try to reason with the waitress letting her know that we would order other items but wanted those for starters (hence why we wanted to keep one menu). The waitress clearly didn't like our dining plan and sauntered off before taking our drink orders. At this point we were all ticked off. The waitress was so hostile, rude and generally unpleasant overall (she radiated negative energy). I don't know why she was so upset with us. As the customer we have the right to order what it is that we want to eat. There were no signs in that particular establishment that claimed that we all needed to order four plates to start off our meals. Eventually we flagged her down for our drink orders (four teas) and she came back five minutes later with ice waters. We let her know that we ordered four cups of tea and this irked her even more as she rolled her eyes and walked away. After another five to eight minutes of waiting for our teas it became clear to us that our waitress had no intention of bringing them to our table. We hailed down another waitress for our teas and after a couple more minutes of waiting, we decided to cancel our order and leave the establishment. We understand that the waitress is "running a business," but as a customer we have a right to take our business elsewhere. Although I don't know much about business, all logic points to not pissing your customers off. In the end, business is better than no business!

TL;DR - I wouldn't recommend this establishment to anyone. Unless you don't care about how you're treated, then go ahead and dine here. I hope this waitress manages to turn her nasty aggressive attitude around. Just because you're having a bad day doesn't mean you have to take it out on other people. You also can't dictate what people can and can't order or how they want to order. Management should deal with this issue before this particular waitress drives customers away.
author: Nicole M.

description: Their set menu is pretty good value. My husband ordered Niku udon set and it comes with a beef udon and unagi rice bow. They were delicious. I orderd ebi curry rice.  Nothing special and the ebi was over fried. Next time i will try the set  menu.
author: Remi M.

description: Sushi was great! Came for lunch on a Tuesday Not too crowded and my food was ready fairly quickly.
author: Brittany E.

description: Japan style food at it's best without having to travel to Japan. Hole in the wall restaurant that seats about 40. Worth the wait. If you have more than 2, expect a longer wait than usual.
author: Randy L.

description:
I was hungry and stopped by here with my friend. I got the tonkatsu donburi since it seems to be a popular item. A good amount of tonkatsu was given but the egg was a bit runny. Sauce lacked a bit of flavor to the point that I was wondering if there was sauce at all. However, the dish was quite filling and I definitely got my money's worth. The meal also comes with a miso soup.

The other dishes might be better so if I ever happen to be in the downtown area and craving Japanese cuisine, I might stop by here for another go. The soba at my neighbor's table looked good.

-Restaurant is a bit small so it's a tight squeeze sometimes as your table might be right next to someone else's table. 
-Prices are average around $10-$12 for dinner and I consider it from fairly cheap for dinner at a Japanese restaurant. Especially when you're downtown.
author: Diana C.

description:
I went here on a Saturday for lunch around 12:00, and surprisingly it was rather empty!

I ended up getting the first option for donburi, but I don't remember its exact specification. 

Food:
The food was really really good! My meal came with a cup of delicious miso soup and the donburi was incredible as well. Honestly, it was one of the most flavor-filled dishes I've had so far in San Francisco. Lots of different tastes, smells, and textures. The portion size was great too! I had enough leftover donburi to take home a box and eat the rest cold for dinner, and it was just as delicious. 

Service:
The service was pretty good! The waiters were accommodating and constantly available, and while it wasn't the level of service I saw at Lark Creek, it was definitely up there in terms of attentiveness, especially for such a cheap establishment. 

Environment: 
I'm not sure if some lights were off or something, but the restaurant felt unintentionally dark. It was a little below street level so the windows were smaller than normal, and there was very little additional lighting to contribute to a brighter environment. There was a TV mounted in the upper corner towards the kitchen side of the restaurant but it seemed to be more for staff entertainment than guest entertainment. It was also difficult to tell the intended ethnicity of the restaurant from the environment too! Most of the staff was Chinese even though it's a Japanese restaurant.

Recommendation:
Regardless, the environment was friendly and comfortable. Staff was nice, and food was great! I wouldn't recommend it if you care about the decor but if you don't care, I couldn't recommend it more. I'm definitely a fan, and will be eager to bring others there!
author: John B.

description:
I can't believe I never stopped here before!  My friend told me about this place recently so since I was starved after going to the gym, I decided to check it out.  I walked by Dojima-Ann a million times writing it off as a touristy average Japanese place - well, I was wrong!  And it's right there in Union Square!  Wow!  

It was busy today a little after noon time but I got a table soon enough.  I tried the bento with salmon teriyaki and tempura which comes with miso soup, salad and rice.  Good portions and a good value for about $13.  The salmon was tasty; the tempura was decent with shrimp and a good variety of vegetables: eggplant, sweet potato, green beans.  

Food service was pretty quick, but they were a little slow with bringing the bill.  It's forgivable though as I could see how busy they were.  For a relatively small place, they have a good amount of seating, but there was a line of people by the door.  They've got a paper waiting list to help you through.

I will be back!  

P.S.  I was planning to take a picture of my bento, but I was so hungry, I totally forgot and just dug in LOL!
author: Maile N.

description: It was aiite. just needed something to eat.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Hey, this was a pretty good place.
We hadn't read the reviews in-depth when we went past 2pm on a Saturday, and was surprised to find a pretty packed small place with a line out the door. It wasn't the poshest sushi restaurant, and not exactly what you could call "cozy" either since it was a bit cramped, too. But I care more about the food :)
They serve tea with the rainbow special. We also got the roll of yellowtail. I'm not an expert on sushi but the fish seemed tender, delicate and tasty, enough to satisfy someone with an amateur palate like me.
We also got a bowl of tempura udon. The vegetable tempura was warm, freshly fried and crispy. Yum. And the udon was slippery and soft but still had a springy bite. It's the best udon I've had in a while.

When we went home my sister and I fell into a coma and woke up with some strange hungover-sh headache. Maybe it was from drinking the bonito broth, which is pretty similar to MSG? Not sure, but overall it was pretty nice and I'd like to go back another time.
author: Electra C.

description: A very affordable, low key Japanese place with many local Japanese hanging around. Ordered nabiyaki udon for lunch. Actually tried to order something from the board of daily specials, but turned out they don't have it--perhaps they don't update the board very often. The noodle has miso based broth which I really liked. It is served in an iron clay bowl. The udon itself is tasty--soft with a little touch of chewiness. The tempura shrimp is pretty good. They also added some chicken breast chunks which were pretty well seasoned and juicy. A raw egg is also added to the bowl right after cooking stopped, so really soft even I waited till I fished most of the food. Veggies are not very well prepared in my opinion--cabbages were cut too roughly, so it is really hard to tear apart. And they added way too much scallions.
author: Yujie F.

description:
We came in after 9pm and the place was super crowded. So must be good right? Never mind the cramp seating arrangement, we were excited for the food. I went for Unagi Tororo Don, which is not inside the menu, but written on today's special write board. It came out really good. The grilled eel portion was pretty generous and it tasted good. The Salmon Sashimi was decent but I have had better. The texture was too firm. The tofu salad portion was generous too, but my friend mentioned the tofu tasted and smelled as if it had gone slightly bad. 

I would come here again, but would skip the Tofu Salad.
author: Zuhadi Z.

description: I grew up in Japan for 10 years & can say that this is literally the best Japanese food in the US. It's authentic & so good! The food tastes just like it does in Japan. It's not fancy, but a great place to go if you want great food. No reservations though, so you may have to wait 10 min for a table.
author: Mary M.

description:
FOOD:
This place is great for fast Japanese food! They have generic Japanese food such as udon, soba, sushi, donburi and curry. I usually get the chicken katsudon and I love it!

SERVICE:
Service is decent.

TIPS: 
The place can get crowded and is full of tourists.

WOULD I RECOMMEND IT? Yes
author: Kelley Y.

description:
Service was good and the food was decent. This place could become busy during the meal times. So either be prepared to wait for a seat or arrive early.

For sake, you may want to confirm the availability of the sake you want. Both of the promoted sake brands turned out to be unavailable on that day.

For credit cards, this place does not accept Amex.
author: Sydney C.

description: Being a tourist staying in Union Square, I was exposed several expensive tourist trapping or high end restaurants, which only people with SF tech salary can afford. Finally, I came across this very affordable restaurant near my hotel. The food is authentic  and has an extensive menu ranging from sashimi to udon, etc.  The price was actually really reasonable and the quality of sushi was excellent.  The fish did not taste any different than an expensive sushi place i tried the other night.  It would recommend getting sashimi appetizer, which is a very good deal.
author: Celia G.

description: there's a strong piss like smell in the restaurant, quality of food is way below average and I waited half an hour after I ordered... this is the worst meal I've had this year
author: Roy O.

description: Food took a while and came at widely different times. Food was very yummy though. I got the rainbow roll and it was very well done. The pictures in the menu and the walls of the restaurant don't match any of the food you get. From a Japanese household, and the food is very authentic.
author: Lucas M.

description:
They wrote tip on your recipe!! Very rude!! 

We were asking "why did you do this?" They said they usually do that. I have never seen any waitress do this thing!!

Watch out your recipe!
author: Leah C.

description:
This place is kind of small, but it's worth waiting for.
Their sushi, udon, and rice bowls are excellent. 
The eel rice bowl is amazing (as well as the eel roll)! Their beef udon is also satisfying. 
Great service. Great food. Great atmosphere. It's very cozy.
author: J G.

description:
This is my usual go-to whenever I work downtown SF. It's pretty convenient and the food is decent. The thing that makes this worst is the customer service and interactions with the servers. They are rude and usually ignore you even if they're not busy. You'll have to deal with their mood swings; You'll have to wait for quite some time before they actually pay attention and when they do they want everything rushed.

This happened today...
I called to order a meal for to-go and the woman who answered told me they were not taking orders for to-go. As I was asking if they're taking in-person she hung up on me.

I went in-person and saw that they were not busy at all. They had a lot of empty seats. I came up to the owner and ordered and I told him I want Ebi Curry for to-go and he said 'okay.' He was confirming my order and told me 'beef curry?' I reiterated myself and told him 'Ebi Curry' 'shrimp tempura curry' and he got mad and gave me the menu and asked me to point it out. 

It was overall a bad experience. They were all rude.
author: Juke J.

description:
Had a craving for Donburi, so a friend and I decided to give Dojima-Ann a try, especially since I've had other friends recommend it to me.  We shared a Rainbow Roll, which we thought was really good.  I tried the Oyako Donburi and my friend had the Tanin Donburi.  We both really enjoyed our lunches and felt we made some good choices.

We noticed other patrons "slurping" away at their Udon and Soba noodles.  Based on the sound they were making, I'd say they liked their lunches as well.  Will have to go back to try an Udon or Soba.
author: Lon H.

description: We had udon and tempera don , and the service is good , they have great food. But I really want to suggest them to change the sample show on the window side, because the food in their inside looks much more delicious than oustside
author: Grace Song-En C.

description:
The food was excellent and quick. The service was great and it wasn't too noisy. 

I had the tempura and salmon teriyaki combo. Both were very tasty and hot.
author: Tim G.

description: This was a perfect little place for our first night in San Francisco. Weather was a little chilly and a nice warm bowl of udon was spot on. Menu is simple but very tasty, just like Japan. Prices were very reasonable for being in San Francisco Staff was friendly and welcoming. We were lucky and got a table as soon as we arrived. But if we had to wait it would be worth it.
author: Lahela S.

description:
The restaurant is near the hotel we're staying, passed it on our way to Japantown for dinner, but too hungry to walk any further, since we planned to go for Japanese food, then why didn't we just walked into it?

We ordered 4 dishes, rainbow sushi roll, chicken udon with hot curry soup, chilled soba noodles with dipping sauce, and salmon roll. The curry udon was really good, it is usually served with beef, I asked for chicken instead. For the rest of three dishes...just okay, nothing special...
author: Shin-chi C.

description: There were 10 people in our party and only half of us received our food. After waiting an hour, the waitress finally brought out three sushi rolls but only one of them was what we had ordered. They also forgot our gyoza. The owner/manager guy was rude and unapologetic. Would not recommend this place.
author: Michelle G.

description:
I ordered shrimp tempura udon to go.

1. The waitress did not give me my change. Although it was only $0.12, it's very shady.

2. There was no shrimp. WTF?

I recommend that nobody ever go here.
author: Toro O.

description:
Nice sushi! Not that expensive... Recommend as light fast food, not something fancy.  
So, 
food-4 stars 
Service- 4 stars 
Atmosphere- 3 stars
Will I ever return? Probably not, but that's because there is to much to explore here(:
author: Elinor O.

description:
Udon, sukiyaki, sushi rolls, sashimi and more! 

This place offers delicious (oishii) Japanese food indeed!

Do order their udon! Their clean tasty broth and perfectly made udon noodles are spot on!  Remember to sprinkle some spicy hot chili peppers to add some zest to your soup and noodles!  I do also recommend their salmon sashimi over rice as well because their rice is actually made in the right Japanese manner!  It has a perfect sticky texture to it with enough volume of being cooked correctly. On top of that, they ADD a hint of vinegar to it!  That is what I am talking about on being the right Japanese manner of making rice!  That hint of rice vinegar makes all the difference when naming it Japanese styled rice!  

I love their sashimi - especially the salmon!  It is delightfully full of fatty, rich flavor and very smooth with every bite I took of it!

Their sushi rolls are also yummy and presented well!  Freshly fried tempura and warmly served, every piece of that roll is delightful to the palate!

Their staffing is adequate.  The crowd comes in during peak lunch and dinner hours.  Be prepared to wait for seats for about half hour!  They have these mirrors on the sides so the place looks bigger - it worked on me!

I do definitely enjoy the ambiance and real Japanese food that this place provides!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Nice original Japanese restaurant with a simple menu and translations in English. There are Japanese beers here you don't fund most places.
author: Ric B.

description: I really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere. It's at a great location and it's a great spot to grab food after shopping!
author: Stephanie A.

description: If you've traveled Asia then you'll be right at home. If not then you'll probably be uncomfortable with the crowding, service, and facilities. I loved it. Food was authentic and good. Soup, beer, sushi all very good. Seating takes awhile. It's good. Try it out.
author: Scott K.

description: The food is not bad, it's the customer service that is horrible!   Went for lunch ordered a 2 Bento boxes with chicken and tempura.   Waited about 10 minute to receive the soup.  After another 10 minutes one of the bento boxes arrived the other did not.  As we waited another 15 minutes the server not the one that took our order came over and presented a salmon bento box which was not ours. Apparently they gave that to another table who ended up eating it even though they ordered the salmon.   We waited another 30 minutes for the 2nd box to arrive.  Upon receiving the check we informed the server that took our order that we were not happy and felt that 1 order be complimentary.   She took the check back and then the server who made the mistake came over and started yelling at us that it was her error and we should have cancelled the order if we weren't going to pay.  We stayed calm but she escalated the situation to wear everyone in the restaurant was looking around. CUSTOMER SERVICE IS HORRIBLE!
author: CJ A.

description:
I used to work a couple blocks away and Mondays were always Doji-Mondays!  We'd always leave a little early (like 11:30) because the place seemed to always fill up by noon.

Almost always got the Katsudon Combo.  A decent size of tonkatsu mixed with slightly runny eggs over rice.  The combo comes with a side of udon.  The tonkatsu is usually cooked just right and is tender on the inside.  I love eggs in general and the runny eggs on top of the rice is a perfect combo.  The udon is not spectacular, just solid.  I've tried other stuff, but always went back to the Katsudon Combo.  Price is also pretty damn cheap for SF.

This place has to be pretty awesome or we wouldn't have had Doji-Mondays would we?
author: Ted K.

description:
Bad service and impolite waitress.
The food wasn't bad. I like it, but I wouldn't come back!
author: Immz N.

description: Straightforward japanese dishes right in touristy Union square. Katsu donburi set hit the spot.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Every time I visit, I stop by at least once a day during my visit. I try to be open minded and try offbeat dishes. I like that this place offers the rice bowls and curry, which you can't get at every Japanese restaurant. I've had the pork, chicken and beef bowl (donburi) with $3 mini udon. All excellent. I tried the chirashi (very pricey -- $18), which was not as good my local place, but was pretty close quality wise. I tried the tempura shrimp/veggie rice bowl. Not very good. I also tried an appetizer of shredded yam with raw tuna. They had the photo on the wall but it didn't arrive at my table looking like the photo. There was a raw quail egg on the tuna. I asked where the yam was and she said it was in there... looked like the white part of the egg. I tried it .... just slimy. Awful. I ended up just eating around the raw egg. 

It's hard to get a table if you're a big party unless you go during non-peak hours. I went with my family of four early for dinner (5:30) and didn't have problems getting seated. I've gone several times by myself (seems like many do) and never had to wait. When we left after dinner (after 6:30-7), there's always a line with young Asians. 

Service is very business like, which is fine by me.
author: C W.

description:
Came here twice in three days, mainly out of convenience (it was right near our conference).  The first time, my wife ordered curry chicken katsu and the rice was hard and the curry was cold in some parts.  My sushi was missing wasabi (I eat sushi often and this was a first for me) and was just okay, otherwise.  When asking for wasabi, the staffer was so cold, no apology, like I'd bothered him.

Second time, my wife ordered the same dish (I don't know why?) and the rice was again hard (as least the curry uniformly Luke warm this time).  I ordered unagi don and while the flavor was fine, the eel was like rubber, very chewy.

Really can't recommend this place.
author: Peter J.

description: I really often visit Dojima Ann and eat karaage don.. friday was my over 40times eating Karaage Don because I really love it! but Dojima Ann was changed the taste after 2013. It is getting lost crispness and feeling line seignant chicken fat. I really disappoint bout it... and they made mistake few times like double charged (included tip and not) even they didnt notice it.. I checked by myself.
author: Dong Kyu K.

description: Cute busy little place, smack dab in the heart of Union Square. Good prices. Great miso soup. Minus one star b/c they use crabstick/imitation crab. Otherwise, sushi was deec.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Decided to give this place another shot on our last day. 

Luckily! There was seating at the counter table for three of us and we were immediately seated. The lady who took our order and served us was much more pleasant than the one we saw yesterday! She was great! I didn't get her name but she was a young lady with glasses. She was much more pleasant which is why I'm updating my review. So thank you! :)

In the end, I am really glad we tried this place out. The place is still too small for their delicious food and but its great portions for their price and well worth it. 

Thank you again!

PS to the woman working Saturday night (our first visit) doing the seating, you could learn something from your fellow co-worker. Just sayin.
author: Paula M.

description:
Since one of my best friends and I both work in downtown SF now, we meed up for dinner quite regularly. Dojima-Ann has become one of our stables. I've tried more than few dishes here at this point and I must say, they still don't disappoint. I wouldn't say they serve the best japanese food I've ever had but everything is very comfortable. I love the gyudon(beef & onion over rice) and the udons. I thought the beef & onion don is far superior to the beef & onion noodle soup, but that might also be because i love gyudons. Their chicken kaarage is still a favorite if I don't mind eating deep fried foods =P 

This restaurant is also fairly decently priced for having an awesome location. The wait has also been never that bad. The most we've waited was around 15ish minutes and most of the time there's no wait at all. The earlier you come here, the less of a wait there is. Around 8-9pm I think there are a few more people waiting than at 6-7.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Their seafood udon is pretty decent and it's not on the menu. The portion is generous and the soup is not too salty. I also ordered their salmon and yellowtail sushi. Not too impressed with the portion size or the quality.

It's an average spot for quick Japanese food for people who stays around Union Square.
author: Xing M.

description:
My colleague and I choose this place only because the restaurant across the street had a waiting list for up to an hour. 

(Short version: until I learned how to eat my dish properly I didn't like the food so much.)

Though I didn't expect much from the moment we stepped inside, in the end I was pleasantly surprised.

The initial attitude of the waiting staff was a bit rude but as the meal progressed the lady became a bit friendlier.

I had the tempura donburi set (the noodles are served cold). I had the same dish once in Japan (but with different noodles) and I like it. So I thought why not be adventurous and have the same dish again with different noodles. 

The tempura was really nice. But the noodles were a rather disappointing, that is until a Japanese gentleman on the table next to me ordered the same dish and started eating the noodles they way you're supposed to. 

After observing him I used two of the 5 Japanese words I know to catch his attention and apologised for staring and told him that I was copying him, as I didn't know how to eat the dish. He then explained it to me step by step. 

You don't pour the soy sauce in the tall cup over the noodles, instead you put the spring onion, some wasabi in the cup with the soy sauce, add some noodles, eat the noodles from the cup and repeat. 

This made ALL the difference, naturally. I thanked the guy for explaining.

During the course of our meal the place filled up nicely, with a large percentage of people seemingly with Asian background, which I would say is never a bad sign for an Asian/Japanese restaurant. 

The things you can learn just from observing people.
author: Jan-Willem A.

description:
Bad service, and one particular female server was very rude to customers. If you're fine with coming over to get chided for the night... Then you should definitely come over. Poor service. Would never come here again.

If I could rate lower, I would definitely rate 0.5/5 stars.
author: Derek L.

description: Pretty poor services, we have waited so long to order food (they were just busy doing something else to ignore us), and NO smiles or services at all!! Wouldn't pay them service charge but they have just mandatorily added on our bill (too bad!!!)
author: Eric W.

description:
I love taking pictures of food. 

Sometimes for Yelp, always for Instagram, and an occasional guest appearance on Snapchat.

I took zero pictures at Dojima-Ann.

Plates of the most unappetizing-looking sushi were brought to our table. This was one of the rare times where my mom would be correct if she'd say, "I could've made that at home." And my mom would've likely done a better job.

Allow me to elaborate. The fish looked moist, not oily, but moist. And soggy too. The color of the fish was also off. It looked as if someone applied an Instagram filter to make the fish color look as dull as possible. One could see that the rice was steamed with too much water and it was way too soft to hold the sushi together. 

But perhaps the most disturbing image of all was how the fish was cut. The fish looked like it was cut with a butter knife by an angry frat boy with one too many beers. Somewhere in Japan the Sushi God shed a tear.

My camera lost all appetite.
 
Post on Instagram? 
I don't want to be the first guy to get negative-Likes.

On Yelp?
They'll surely revoke my Elite status.

On Snapchat?
If I snap this, no one will ever offer $3Bil to buy Snapchat again.

Maybe I'm exaggerating, but that was a horrible sushi experience for sure. The other tables who ordered the udon pot seemed to have enjoyed their meal though.

Service was another up point, as they were nice and friendly. They even offered to split the check for our convenience. The sushi chef was no where to be found though...(maybe that's why....)

I'll give a 3 star because of service and convenience (right where 38 stops at Powell). Hopefully, this was just an off (way off) day for Dojima-Ann.
author: Ringo M.

description: Not worth it small food and not even good. My friend had bone in her sushi. YIKES. Also bad service DOUBLE YIKES...
author: Anand B.

description:
At this place, you can eat what you will eaten if you come to Japan.
I am a tourist came from Japan, and I am Japanese.
The first thing that I noticed was that all of the waitresses are Chinese. I had a bad feeling about this place.
I ordered kitsune udon and 7-up.
Waitress brought me Sprite instead of 7-up saying "it's the same", obviously it isn't. 
Kitsune udon was good. Soup was kinda cheap compare to Japanese one, but still decent compare to other Japanese udon places in SF. Noodle was cheap too, but it was ok.
As soon as I finished eating kitsune udon, waitress kicked me out by bringing a slip, but I was still not finished with Sprite, so called "7up".
Maybe the food was average, but the service was terrible.
It was a Chinese restaurant where you can eat average Japanese food.
author: Kuma A.

description:
Someone swore by this place. So, I gave it a try. 

Ambiance: Very small restaurant. fit about 20 people. It was a bit trippy when I first entered because there is a huge wall mirror at the end of the wall... makes the place seem a lot bigger!

Customer Service: Eh. I wouldn't say it's the best. They are so focused on turning tables over to accept more customers that they don't necessarily gave zee best service. 

Food: Alright. let's get to the real meat of this (pun intended). I had the donburi and udon combo. cost was $14. Portion was generous. Tasted pretty good. I was pleasantly surprised. (And I was seriously straving.....plus it was raining so udon really hit the spot). If I go there again, I might try other items on the menu. Shrimp tempera udon? 

Anyways, overall, it's definitely a restaurant you need to try out!!!
author: Johanna S.

description: Kaki fried was a good value. Very large fried oysters. For about $60 we had a couple rolls, seaweed salad, the oysters, and we each had a beer. Seems like a good value for the area of town. There was a decent lunch crowd, seems like a popular place.
author: Taylor M.

description: Cute little store, they serve nice katsu and differnet kind of donburi. The staff was nice, wish they can have bigger place but this is still a nice place to eat some tasty japanese food.
author: James T.

description:
Common problem for vegans:

We can't have udon.
Usually.

The reason is simple. Most of the time, the broth is meat-based, and unless we want to pay $8 for water broth (and subsequently it tasting bad and still risk it having fish sauce or meat seasoning/bouillon in it), we just avoid it and happily eat our avocado rolls.

Well, I was on a quest to change that. Never have I eaten Udon in a restaurant before, but I was craving it. Dojima-Ann is near where I live so we went to check it out.

Here, they actually offer their miso broth as a vegetarian-friendly option to all their soups. so throw your hands up and eat that udon and soba!
You can enjoy it with vegetable tempura or Sansai (which is what I went for), which is described as 'Japanese Mountain Vegetables.' It is a combination of several types of mushrooms, and green bean looking stuff. It was actually quite enjoyable! Loved the taste of the miso and the textures of the vegetables put together. I bought the lunch portion, which was enough to fill me up!

Of course, they also have your standard basic veggie rolls and appetizers, if that interests you.

However, why the 'meh' stars? Because we received some of the worst service here.
We walked in, and they pointed to a table at the far corner, the only one open. We got excited and sat down and started looking at the menus. And that's what we were left to do for 10 minutes. No one greeted us or anything. In fact, they literally forgot we were there as they tried to seat ANOTHER party at our table! After that mistake, we assumed they were going to come around and take our order, but NOPE! In fact, the table next to us got up and left, and they started cleaning THAT table, when we had to flag them down and take our order.
We asked for water and waited. During this time, the 2 tables next to us were now empty and clean, and got re-sat. What happened next? Those 2 tables got greeted right away and the best part? THEY WERE SERVED WATER AND TEA BEFORE WE GOT OURS!
Once again we had to FLAG someone down and ask for water. Finally they got us water (not until I saw them serve a newer table water first!).
We brushed it off to the fact that it was busy. But we couldn't comprehend how they could serve the 2 tables directly next to us beverages first and overlook us.

After our [delicious] meal, our unhappy-looking server came around to clear our dishes. She never said a word, but we expected the check. We saw checks presented at every other table, but ours. Finally after waiting and basically being forgotten again, we came up to the register to pay.

They lost our ticket. In fact, it was as if we never dined there to begin with. we technically could've walked out, but instead they had to take out an order pad and ask us what we ate so they could charge us! Ridiculous.
I have absolutely no idea what happen, but we literally were forgotten and I felt invisible. I wasn't expecting stellar service, but being forgotten is a whole other issue.

They're lucky their miso broth redeemed themselves. Otherwise I won't be back.
author: Lanie L.

description: My absolute favorite Japanese place here near market! The fish and ingredients are always fresh and the price is on the cheaper end for market street. Absolutely suggest :)
author: Sophie Y.

description: You're lucky you got a star when your costumer service suck so bad. One of the your worker begged me to give them tips after making us wait an hour for the table when there was empty ones and one of the lady even said " I'm not nice " .
author: Christine P.

description:
The food is great with generous portions, but it seems like there usually is a wait and the restaurant size is quite small.

I ordered one of the specials: curry kyu with the mini udon. It came with a large plate of rice and curry with a size salad and mini udon. It was delicious and I had to take some of the curry home as leftovers. I don't have any complaints about my food.

The only con I encountered during my meal is that the restaurant itself is pretty small but quite popular. The queue begins to pile up but there is not enough room for probably more than 4-6 people to wait indoors since people might start blocking the door to the kitchen. It also kind of sucks when it's cold outside.
author: Jessica C.

description: This place is packed on the weekday since it's small and it's near Union Square.  The sashimi combo was pretty good ($19.95 for three pieces of salmon, mackerel, toro, tuna and whitefish).  The rolls were good and not too saucy.  The service was a little spotty but portions were good.  I'd come back.
author: Chris L.

description:
The best Unagi Tororo Don in the Galaxy!!!  And the miso soup is quite delicious too.

Come early or you will be waiting a little bit :)
author: Steve S.

description:
I liked this place the first two times I've dined here but never again. 

Waitstaff has no concept of customer service and I waited over 40minutes for my food while I watched other parties who arrived after me get served first.

Also they had extra items on my bill and when I alerted them about the extra charges the waitress scoffed me like I should pay it anyways.  And then another lifetime of waiting for the correct check.

I work in customer service so I was a little lenient and still tipped them anyways. I know some days are rough but when I look back they really didnt deserve it.
author: Becca W.

description:
Remember, this place's speciality is Noodles(Udon) although they serve sushi and other Japanese dishes. 
Their Udon(or soba) noodles are very good. I heard the owner learned udon in Osaka, Japan. So the soup is not tokyo(kanto) style but osaka(kansai).  I'm from kansai area, so it tastes so good to me:) 
Again, I would not recommend ordering other stuff such as bento, sushi, etc. I've tried but not good or as good as Udon. My 4 stars are solely for Udon !
I would give 2 or 3 star to bento and sushi.
author: Mii L.

description:
This goes more to their customer service than their food. I never got a chance to taste what food they offer because they berated me when I asked a simple question: how long will I have to wait before being seated?

They need to redesign the form they use for a waiting list. When I got there at 7pm on a Wednesday night, I went to sign into the waiting list. The page seemed to be full, so I flipped over to the next page and there were names and party sizes logged, so I added my name and number in my party to the end of the list and went on my merry way. 

We went back there after about an hour. When I went in to check our place in the queue, I saw that people had stopped adding their names on the page mine was on, but that they had added names to the page that I thought was full! I checked with wait staff and they said that they would work the problem out. 

So I thought things were worked out and went back to my party and explained things to them. I went back in about ten minutes later to ask how long my party would have to wait. 

When I asked a waitress she started berating me about why I entered my name on the waiting list wrong. I calmly explained to her that I was not the first person on the second page, that I was merely following what was protocol. She insisted that that was impossible and started to berate me on why I could not understand how a waiting list works. 

I was not born yesterday, and feeling that she nor the restaurant wanted my party's business, I calmly told her she could remove my name from the waiting list. I apologized to my party, but they understood what was going on and we dropped a ton of money at a Korean restaurant in the Rich.

So lesson learned. I will add this restaurant to my "banned for 12 mos" list. The misbehaving employee will have been dismissed by then and I *might* try it again. Another lesson: KBBQ ROCKS.
author: C S.

description:
Overall this is a decent place. 

Pros:
- The fish was very fresh. 
- The rice was well cooked. 

Cons:
- Anything that requires frying (tempura and pork cutlet) was overcooked. 
- The waiters seldom paid attention, even when you were the only customer.
author: Bob L.

description:
Ahhh So Desu...

Taking a scan at the reviews, no wonder people are disappointed.

They're ordering off the regular menu, and many of the ho of the hummest of items!

sushi and jive ass rolls
udon
donburi

OK the udon and donburi are pretty much their staples here. But at least be happy Dojima Ann is offering this stuff in reasonable quality. It is actually way better than the counterparts offered by Chinese and Korean run Japanese restaurants that are prevalent around the city (or should I say, "chitty"). And definitely better looking than what "Miyabi Tei" would offer in the food court of Mitsuwa Supermarket in San Jose. 

I did look at what customers were eating that day. The look and feel, and presentation and execution, at least looked pretty legit.

And the regular menu didn't seem terribly interesting to me.

Though the white board wall specials did look very tempting, so I went with them.

Anago tempura don - OK first of all we don't have a tempura donburi specialist place like Hannosuke in Los Angeles, but what I ended up with I would say is as close as we will ever get. Two humongous pieces of sea eel with several pieces of vegetable, all tempura battered to a very tasty consistency, and fried in sesame oil (yes you can smell it), along with a unique tempura don sauce that is very Japanese in look/feel/taste. Best of all, no vegetables that don't quite belong (e.g. broccoli....that does not exist in true Edo style tempura)

It doesn't look like much but once you take your chopsticks and dig in, then swipe some rice into your piehole, it hits da friggin spot. The problem is most of you have not been exposed to proper tempura, and got so used to eating crap being passed off as tempura, that this may taste weird to you (hopefully not). But rest assured that it is LEGIT, down to the smell and taste. Of course, don't compare it to high end Michelin star tempura restaurants in Tokyo that have lighter batters and super refined execution with high end seafood... 

And sharing is caring....so go check it out before they switch it up to something else!

Grilled Bluefin tuna collar - Toro sashimi? YAWN. Bluefin sashimi? Please. BLUEFIN TUNA COLLAR (salt grilled). Now that's a rare part!Hamachi Kama? It has been overplayed. How often do you come across part of a Bluefin tuna that is not used for sashimi? Hardly ever? At around $12 to $14 this was a steal. Though I was not enamored with the way they did grated daikon....it was way too coarse. Other than that, a very decent job with the gas grill (it was not charcoal for sure), and ponzu + lemon helped take off some of the edge.

Definitely worth your while exploring the wall specials when you come in...expand your horizons (and without the use of recreational drugs)!
author: Ken K.

description: If you're into waitstaff who snap at each other, udon noodle soup that takes like dishwater, and zero service, this is the place for you!
author: Doreen S.

description: It was halfway sugoi. My friends and I had the una tama don and the Katsu curry. The food was standard Japanese food. The service was alright. The Una tama don was a little sweeter than I expected but that was probably due to the unagi sauce. The Katsu curry was normal the Katsu was crispy and not oily and the curry was average. I would come back if I was in the area for the prices but not for the food.
author: Rachel H.

description: My Fav for Japanese!! Clean, Fresh & Authentic!! I absolutely Love this place, I have to go at least twice a month. However, I went twice this week already lol. So close to all my shops in Union Square also, A+ in my book. The hours of operation are awesome too because several other Japanese restaurants close-down between 2pm & 5pm. Not Dojima Ann, they're OPEN STRAIGHT THROUGH THE DAY so go ENJOY!! Mmmmmm
author: Tee S.

description:
One piece of tamago nigiri was a lot smaller than other piece
So we complained, and received two small pieces.
Lol
author: GiTae H.

description: Service was rushed and not very polite.  Prices were more on the steep side and portions small.  I ordered a Miso soup, a spicy tuna roll and a New York roll (shrimp and avocado).  My total, with no drink, before tip, was just under $18.  I gauge sushi value as follows: how much did I have to spend to get full? The answer is yet to be determined because I left still sightly hungry, but I think if they had at least filled my Miso soup halfway up the bowl (it was filled 1/4 way up the bowl, and the bowl was small, total rip off for $2.75) , I would have been satisfied enough to be less disenchanted with the price.  The Miso soup was really good, the spicy tuna roll and NY roll were both just OK.  I also asked if they had Sambal and they brought Sriracha - not as good and lame if they don't have Sambal at all.  Overall, they have a lack of spicy items on the menu.  The spicy tuna was the only spicy roll and it wasn't spicy at all. The one thing I can say is that everything tasted fresh and good quality and the service was fast.
author: Emma H.

description: SOOOO GOOOOOD. The service was crap though but the fish was so fresh, it was delicious!!! Very authentic. Also had onigiri just like in anime and I am seriously craving more! Honestly wasn't sure about this place but IM TELLING YOU THE FISH IS SO FREAH AND AMAZING
author: Anne M.

description: Came here twice. Looks kinda plain on the outside, but there's a reason why this place is always PACKED with people, and that's because the food is astounding. The first time I came, I had some sushi and one of their fried rice bowls - SO GOOD. The second time, I just had the sushi, because that was just how much I loved it. Fish is so fresh, the rice is perfectly flavored, and they offer some really cool rolls. This place is worth the wait (which actually moves pretty quickly considering how many people there are).
author: Katherine Z.

description:
Usually when I order "Chef's Choice" sushi for a premium I expect better, high quality pieces of sushi. This was not the case when I got the run-of-the-mill salmon, tuna, ebi (not even amaebi), and other nigiri pieces that were not even that great. 

Also, the server had to take back my miso soup spoon because it had not been cleaned.
author: Daniel L.

description:
Our last meal during our stay by the Bay.

Quite unexpected stop.  I'm being generous because there was a log line of customers and quick turnover; since we were in a hurry to keep our travel itinerary intact, this fit the bill nicely. 

The bill was quite reasonable too for what ended up being served to us. I got a bento with two items and the Plus One got some kind of egg and chicken donburi and mini udon. Well, I tried the chicken and egg don, didn't tickle my fancy or trip the lights fantastic but it wasn't bad.  I did like the salmon and tempura though. Salad was great, there were two kinds included. Nice blend of flavors. Mini udon was sad, soggy noodles and weak broth.  But it was better when consumed with my tempura, so I dunno. Rounded up for the review, and again, reasonably fast so we could make our plane.
author: Bill C.

description:
If you're hungry for noodles go to the grocery store and get a 10 cent pack of top ramen... I am underwhelmed beyond measure 

Service is rude 

If you have the desire to feel like an inconvenience ...... This is the place for you
author: Joshua H.

description: One of my favorite places in this neighborhood, usually get their katsun don set. It could get busy, sign your name when you 1st come and also call ahead to order to go if you are in a hurry.
author: Bai Z.

description: When I ordered the food, I had to wait more than 35 minutes. so when I check the bill, I said I don't want to give some tips. They said this is mandatory, you have to pay tips. she said "you are not nice and your attitude is not good, and it's America's culture, so you have to pay, where are you from?" I've been living in SF for 4 months. I've never had this experience. Why did she ask my nationality? Fucking racist
author: Byeong Uk A.

description:
There's pretty big portions. I ordered the dinner special with sushi and tonkatsu and couldn't finish all of it. The food quality was pretty good. 

Took 1 star off for the poor service. The servers weren't very friendly/welcoming.
author: Emily P.

description:
This donburi is awesome ~! The best menu is donkasu donburi set. Donkasu and udon at this place when I go shopping in union square. It's gives me memorial food in San Francisco

All the Donburi is great. The rolls have good prices too. Their fish is good too, but i don't really   recommend getting a sushi.
author: Dae Gon K.

description:
Despite being in the area all the time, I rarely find myself at a restaurant downtown. The typical tourist glitziness tends to repel me, but Dojima-Ann is a restaurant that stands out from all the ridiculous light-up signs and weird people standing outside with menus trying to lasso you into their establishment. It has legitimately good food, a great menu, and friendly service. 

Go for any of the specialty rolls, they do not disappoint. I'll recommend the Dragon roll -- indeed it's at every sushi restaurant in existence, but only certain places get the ratios right; a hefty slice of unagi, a good amount of avocado, significant crunch and all rolled up tight = success. 

Before trying this place out I heard that their soup is where it's at, so recently I had some of their chicken & egg udon. The noodles were terrifically lovely, and the broth was savory, piping hot, and supremely satisfying, and the portion was just right. 

Dojima can get crowded, but if there isn't a party of 10 ahead of you I'd say it's worth the wait -- there are few sushi joints in the downtown area that exist on the same level. Good for small groups, better for a couples situation, always delicious.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
I love this place! Friendly, efficient service coupled with cheap but good food! Very authentic donburi and udon. I won't comment on the sushi because I didn't have any. But you shouldn't be spending money on sushi here anyway. The other stuff is just so good!

The daily special donburi/udon sets are a steal. For 12 bucks you get a full sized donburi or udon, with a mini size of the other thing as well. Seems like the specials change all the time.

Last night for the special, there were:
1. Niku udon with mini unagi don
2. Kakiage donburi with mini cold sansai udon
3. Shrimp tempura donburi with zaru soba
4. Katsudon with mini udon

I think I also saw the yamakake on the wall as well, can't be sure.

I tried a bit of the mini unagi don from my friend's special #1. It was some damn good unagi! I wish I had gotten the unagi don with raw egg! The pictures look so amazing.

My kakiage donburi was pretty good. The veggies were well cooked (I fear for undercooked veggies in my kakiage) and the sweet sauce went very well with the rice. I really like the mini sansai udon. I didn't expect it to be cold, but it was delicious! I'm not sure if they make their udon in house, but it was chewy and delicious!

I'm definitely coming back here to try the unagi don with raw egg, katsudon, and some of the full sized udon bowls. Can't wait!
author: Sherry L.

description:
For a place in Union Square, Dojima-Ann serves up decent Japanese food though service is a little lacking. 

I came here with a friend last night before scrambling over to Fisherman's Wharf to catch the fireworks. I had the unagi don, which came with miso soup and an impressively generous portion of eel though I prefer my eel to be a little bit crispier, and I did feel they could have gone a little lighter on the sauce.
author: Kelly R.

description:
After arriving in San Fran and walking for a bit my husband and I were famished. We walked by and saw a line out the door with a sign in sheet so he suggested we try Dojima-Ann - with ppl waiting in the cold rain it had to be good, right?

And....yes, it is! I ordered hot edamame to start while he had the rice balls with salmon which he devoured in less than five minutes. I also got an order of the sake nigiri which was so fresh it literally melted in my mouth. Last but not least was the piece de resistance - Nabe Yaki - chicken, egg, veggies, shrimp tempura udon. The soup was piping hot and perfect for the weather that day. I also couldn't help but drool every time a plate walked by - everything looked scrumptious!
author: Mary L.

description:
We came here on Friday before Mother's Day weekend and it was pretty packed. 

*** FOOD ***
- Beef with onion don: flavor was pretty good but I had a lot of rice and only a few pieces of beef; came with miso soup

- Udon noodle with tempura: soup was delish and we got lots of tempura to go with it

*** Service ***
- Pretty standard service, we got hot tea as soon as we sat down.

I would definitely come back again to try their sushi rolls.
author: Mengerie S.

description:
Now I finally understand why there is always a line outside the store. The food takes about 20-30 minutes to be served and the store can only fit about 20 people. The food isn't bad, but the wait time is just too long. 

Do not come in a big group, not only it's hard to get a table that can fit a party bigger than 4, your food will not be served at the same time. You will end up spending lots of time watching each other eat instead of dining together.

Food wise, the pork cutlet don is good, the fried chicken curry isn't bad either, the only problem is the curry sauce isn't hot at all.
author: Jens L.

description:
Dojima-Ann totally fills a void for me. It's a bowl-shaped void and Dojima-Ann has filled it with steaming hot kitsune (fried sliced tofu) soba. This noodle soup is possibly my favorite food and finding it within a 10 minute walk from work (5 if you run, which I had to do yesterday when I left at 13:25 and realized I had a 13:30 meeting back at the office) was a revelation yesterday.

I will definitely be back for my noodle fix!
author: Miriam W.

description:
The Doj is a great place for Union Square food!

Their sashimi appetizers are usually buttery and mouth watering.  

The staple for me is their lunch bentos to go.  I always get the chicken karaage/beef shioyaki combination.  For $14 bucks, you get miso soup, salad, rice, and two entrees.  

It ain't the best ever, but it's good, tasty, everyday food.  Sit-down may take a little while, but take-out is quicker.  Make sure to ask for soy sauce, mayo, and hot pepper powder if to go.
author: John M.

description: This is probably my favorite   restaurant in downtown. The food is really hight quality and has great ingredients. I usually order the Bento Box with salmon teriyaki and tempura, also tonkatsu don is great. The tempura is made with outstanding ingredients and the salmon is fresh. It's a cozy place and sometimes get crowded. Also I have tried the cold sake and was fantastic!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Mediocre food and the customer service is okay. Wouldn't highly recommend this place to anyone unless you're desperate for food. Only thing I like about this place was their spicy tuna roll. Usually this place is packed at night time.
author: Tina C.

description: Waited awhile and they called ppl before us. We r a group of 4, they called ppl behind us party of 2. And kept doing. That. Then finally the Host noticed they were wrong and called us saying sorry. Too late. I guess thats what i get for giving them a chance.
author: Lisa C.

description:
While I do not often write reviews, the service that my family received was so poor that I feel compelled to share my experience. After arriving around 9 30 pm on a Thursday, we were seated rather quickly but that's where the hospitality ends. 

The server was extremely rude. After waiting for what seemed like forever with no attempt for her to take our order (she even seated someone and took their order without coming back to our table), the server finally returned after we heard the manager instruct her to do so. The food took forever, and when it finally came out, the server approached our table from behind (we were sitting in an elevated booth), and reached all our dishes over our heads. She did not once return to our table. 

It should be noted that despite the poor service, the food was very tasty. It seems from reading other reviews that others have had a poor experience with a female server. Maybe this one server has an attitude problem, and if you don't get her, it may be worth trying.
author: Kaitlin F.

description: Stopped in for a quick lunch. Food reminds me of my time in Iwakuni and the atmosphere took me back as well. Great lunch spot!
author: wayne k.

description:
I came here after major research on my phone on where to eat. I knew it was gonna be a bit pricey because of the location. 

The place is dirty. The walls were full of dust and the floor needed a good mopping. 

The service is borderline annoying. When someone asks you if everything is okay after every second, that is not COOL.

The food: I ordered tonkatsu curry and chicken karaage.

The tonkatsu was so LITTLE. Literally, 5 tiny pieces and a PLETHORA of curry. Talk about a balanced ratio.

The karaage was good but it was served cold.

With Japantown just a MUNI ride away, I've definitely learned my lesson.
author: Leslie M.

description:
Small space. Fast friendly service. I had the chicken katsu meal and it was good. This is the 2nd time I've been here, both accidentally, and was happy w/ it. 
Location is a bit weird bc this time around a homeless guy walked in and caused a small scene but it was resolved ok.
author: C A.

description:
My favorite curry spot in the city! 

The curry is bursting with flavor, spicy, and has just the right amount of salt. The pork katsu meat itself is fatty, juicy and crisped to perfection. I usually order the pork katsu curry with extra curry because I find that I usually run out of curry before I'm done with the meat. The donburi bowls are absolutely yummy as well with well-cooked breaded meat mingled with egg and onions. Mmm. 

Definitely check out Dojima-Ann on a cold night when you're craving some Japanese comfort food!

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Stopped in for a nice salmon sashimi don for lunch a few weeks ago. The fish seemed fresh, was ample for the price, and the rice was filling. It came with a nice little miso soup and salad to start. The waitress was friendly, and the service was fairly quick and attentive given that it was a full restaurant.

I was alone, so I sat at the bar, which is less of a bar, and more of a "sit facing the wall" arrangement, but it was fine with me. I just read the news on my phone and munched away happily on my sashimi and rice. I'll be back.
author: Andrew M.

description:
If I had a DeLorean, I'd rate this place 3 stars but then go back in time and rate it 4 stars and completely blow the laws of physics. To me, this restaurant has been such a dependable 3 that it's for all intents and purposes a 4 and such an everyday 4 that it's fundamentally a 3.

Think about your parents' or grandparents' cooking. You really like it. How do you regard the experience of eating it in your kitchen? It doesn't seem all that special. But to you it is. But to you it's not. But to you it is. But to you it's not.

The menu provides enough variety that I'd eat here any day of the week and enough appeal that I'd still eat here any day of the week even if the variety felt routine. As I type this, I'm picturing some of their dishes. That I want to eat. Today. Right now. And I'm not even hungry.
author: Dan B.

description:
Maybe because it's at downtown, this place is a little over price to my standar. Compare to the price i think the taste is not worth it. I work at downtown and this place might be a  option when I want something new. I usally go there 1 or 2 time a year Because of the customer service is bad.

This place is pretty busy because you'll see a lot of tourist eating in there. So some times it takes a while until you'll get a seat or your food is ready. I been there around 4 or 5 times and usally I'll call to make a order to avoid waiting too long. But I will say 80 percent of the time I'll still have to wait for 10-15min in front of the resturant(I waited 15-20 min before I head to dojima). Don't really recommend when you have a time limited on breakfest, lunch or dinner.

Like I say on top it's full of tourist and it's pretty busy, customer service is not that good. I think it's because they are under stress? I'm not saying it's a everytime thing but most of the time when I pick up my food I have to wait a good 3-4 min (their register is where they take order, make payment, table waits and usally there's only 1-2 people by the register) before I can let anyone know that I'm here to pick up and they seem a little annoyed. Which I understand in this fast paste you'll get really stress but still need to be nice. 
- one time I order a teriyaki bent to go, the chicken was still raw.
- another time I go to the website for menu and order a curry which says it's 7 or 8 buck, it ended up 12 buck. Although it did come with a very small salad it'd not worth it. And I ask the owner?(i think thats him)Why am I charge 12 bucks when it says 7 or 8 buck online he yelled at me saying if I dont have money then don't eat out. I was about to curse, but I decided to not come back unless if I really need to.
author: Mabel M.

description:
We were starving after shopping around in Union Square and wanted to grab a bite to eat. Japanese sounded pretty good and this was one of the closer places that was open fairly late.

It was a cold night so people were packed around the door and near the hostess station- I felt so bad for the waitresses since they had to dodge all the people and a lot of people were giving them a hard time. After a 30 min wait we were eventually seated and ordered the unagi bowl and two rolls. Really NO complaints with the food here. It came out timely, fresh and hot! The rolls were neatly rolled and tasty with the perfect rice texture and the unagi was buttery soft. SLIGHTLY pricey but no big deal considering the area its in and quality of food.

This is definitely one of those restaurants where the Yelp crowd is a bit too unforgiving. Its pretty decent food so no complaints here :)
author: Jackie C.

description: Dojima-Ann offers a wide range of Japanese cuisine. Most of the items available are pretty average and includes udon, soba, donburi, sushi, and more. Nothing really stands out, and aside from the sushi, you could probably make these dishes better at home. Service is spotty and they like to rush you out since for some reason, it's a pretty busy spot.
author: Tunaidi A.

description:
Came here with a friend for lunch and got an order of wakami salad and some cucumber sushi rolls, while my companion ordered a 2 piece Bento box. Overall, it's pretty standard Japanese, nothing really to write home about, although my friend seemed really happy over the serving size of the Bento he ordered. 

The dining area has a really funky smell that I couldn't really place, but was definitely not appealing. 

Overall, there's much better Japanese places but this would do ok in a pinch if you're in the area. Just be warned of the weird smell.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
This is my last time here ever.  My noodle was lukewarm and had practically nothing in it.  The beef curry came with it had a mound of beef that had very unappetizing look.  I ate just a bit of white rice and the curry sauce, but had to push the grotesque looking beef aside.  
I still remember the great taste of the food they produced 20 years ago.  Where did that go?  The people who are waiting on us took 15 minutes to get the order and never brought our check.  We went up to pay.  Perhaps they are ashamed of the food they are serving.  Just because I remember old good time I sporadically came back, it is gone.  I should let go of the memory and hope,  there is nothing left at this restaurant that resembles the great soup I remember.
author: Ono K.

description:
Found this place while we were exploring the city. It's very authentic and amazingly tasty. I love Japanese food so it was such a treat to have authentic tasting Japanese good. My only gripe was that the service was awful. People who sat down after us, got served before us. No one greeted us and served us until I walked over to get someone. The manager (maybe owner) was very rude and pushy. But overall I gave it a 4 star because the food was a delight!

Try the katsu don. So delicious. Also curry u don't was yummy
author: Cj F.

description:
A little restaurant right downtown San Francisco. 
It caters to locals living or working nearby, and tourists. 
The place is crammed to the max, tables are very near each other. Too close for comfort. But that's the goal, order, eat, and get out. 
The menu offered a pretty good variety of Japanese fare. The rolls are very good, not too much rice, a nice balance of fish and rice. The udon has a lot of flavor too. Did not try the curry yet. Tempura is crunchy, not oily. Fairly solid food wise. 
The service is a bit automatic. Not too much of a smile, but I guess if it is so busy, they have no time or energy.
author: lovetoeat a.

description:
This place is jam packed with locals and tourists everyday, rain or shine.  Usually I don't like going to busy spots like this but there are some days where BUT THOU MUST.  The selection won't blow your mind, but the cooking and portions are spot on.  My curry soba wasn't too big and the soba noodles weren't soggy.  My croquette was almost the consistency of mashed potatoes inside despite the perfect fry outside.  The lemon wedge served with it was a perfect touch.

There are other Japanese restaurants within walking distance of Dojima-Ann.  But it's hard to resist when you get dropped off right in front of the restaurant from the 38 Geary line.
author: Christine L.

description: It was good, nothing to complain about, nothing spectacular but it was definitely decent fish.  Fresh, the fishman was right outside loading up the restaurant through its basement opening.
author: Jesse J.

description: Really good and authentic Japanese - sushi, sashimi, udon, donburi, etc. Great for lunch. Small and busy but wait not too long. Goya and Tempura apps very good, and service excellent and homey! Recommended.
author: David H.

description:
I have had this place bookmarked for a while and was in the area last night so stopped by for a to go order. Totally forgot to take pictures but I got a Chirashi, Unagi Nigiri, and Edamame. Was not impressed with food or service. 

Let's start with service. I was lucky and order was taken right away but then I added the edamame later on. Everything was ok until they brought the food out. The lady forgot to add it on the ticket - not a big deal although she was like PAY for it. I'm like I already did. So another few mintues go by, order xcomes out, they forgot the salad and miso soup that comes with the Chirashi... seriously. All this in between, there was a couple of ladies that came in that literallyl stood there for a good 5 minutes before someone acknowledged them. There was SOMEONE at the door and waitresses went by them like 4 times. This was at 5PM, they were not busy at all. With 4 waitresses and like 5 tables, i would think service would be more prompt. People at the tables were waiting to give their orders too. 

On to the food. 
Unagi Nigiri - $5 for 2 pieces - not bad at all. Nothing to complain about here. 
Chirashi ($17) - comes with soup and salad and about 12 -14 cuts of fish and tamago egg. You get tuna, salmon, hamachi, octapus and a couple of other cuts. Was not impressed as they were MAD thin cuts. You can totally get the price bowl elsewhere for the same price with thicker cuts. 

overall - 2.5 starrs not impressed
author: Tao Tao W.

description:
Terrible, terrible customer service!!! They didn't care to explain the dishes. they just brushed me off & once I realized they weren't going to help, my wife & I decided to leave.

We explained this issue to the waitress & said we'll eat some where else, & her reply was"That's fine..."
author: Doug M.

description:
3.5 stars. This is the only Japanese place I'll eat at when I'm in the downtown area. In fact, probably one of the few places I'll go to for a quick bite downtown (as most Union Square places are highly overpriced and not very good).

The gyudon and the salmon + ikura don are awesome! Take-out is convenient too. Sushi quality is mediocre/decent, so stick to the hot food.
author: Joanne Y.

description: Great food and price point is perfect for lunch. Service is terrible. Not sure I would go back. Maybe for take out only
author: Ni C.

description: Really terrible service. I don't know the guy dealt with me was a boss or manager but he was so rude.
author: Daisy L.

description:
Came with my sister on a Saturday evening to fill ourselves with food before drinking the night away. She's been here plenty of times and this was only my first! I never really noticed this place until she pointed it out and told me all the things she's tried here. We were checking out the menu while waiting to be seated, so we decided on getting the Giant Roll (inside: crab meat, eel; top: salmon) and tonkotsu donburi. Both dishes ranged from about $10-$12; expected prices for dinner menu. Overall the food was pretty good and flavorful. Nothing mind-blowing or amazing, but it did its job of keeping us full. Some random tidbits on my experience:

-The rolls on the menu said there was only 6 pcs per order. Ours had 8! Cool. 
-Waitress was nice about letting us share the donburi and gave us the extra bowl.
-Food wasn't too salty, fish wasn't too fishy.
-Restaurant is pretty small. We got a table in the corner and I barely had any space to move my arms or legs because there was an awkward part of the wall sticking out towards me. 

I'd come here again for reasonably priced Japanese food if I'm downtown. Otherwise, I wouldn't go out of my way to get my Japanese food cravings here.
author: Kathleen S.

description: This place is enjoyable and so close to the theater district.   The prices are reasonable for the location.  I had the udon with fresh seaweed, egg, little bites of chicken on the bottom.  I feel like this bowl was such a complete meal with one shrimp tempura and cabbage.  The service is great.  The little table for two is just big enough and intimate enough to have a conversation.  They have combination plate, rice plates, bentos, fresh chirashi,  just about something for everyone.  I didn't see any ramen, so you just go one block to geary street to get your ramen. For dessert, go down a few doors is the cako cupcake place that has a bacon cupcake.  Service was attentive.
author: Helen L.

description:
I have been there often for 6 year now, and their service was NEVER good. 

Ok I know lots of tourists go this place cuz it's really close to union square in downtown. But I would just say don't go to this place, or you will experience bad bad bad service. (I feel katsudon taste good, but else r bad) Ppl work there never smiled, and they always look super bored. 

Yesterday, I went there with my bf, and he ordered unagidon and udon. He felt udon was too sour and taste weird. So he told them in polite way, like did they change ingredients or sth. Two waitress kept coming and going and asked like "So what do you want us to do?". They didnt even give him menu and said "choose other one then". 

Anyways they recommended curry udon and it was served. My bf told me it taste bad as well, that he cant eat it. 

So we juz paid bill and tried to leave, suddenly the owner (or whoever the old guy work there) came to us and kept telling us if we were not gonna eat, why did we order it again. He kept complaining and complaining. It sound like we did sth wrong thing or treat them bad. That guy was very very mean, we felt. 

I dont mind if you ppl didnt like us or whatever, just DO NOT SAY IT OUT LOUD IN FROMT OF US! 

I will never go back there ever again.

p.s. What is that toilet like smell in the restaurant?!
author: Jungeun L.

description:
so many Japanese restaurants are owned and cooked by Chinese, Korean, Mexican, this small cozy restaurant is owned and cooked by Japanese. ya, this is important to me. I always believe usually the locals could cook their traditional foods the best because they have the sense to keep it original which is the meaning to try different cuisines. 

Pick the right thing at the right place. Here has great Udon and don... my favor is Tonkatsu-don. The breaded pork are tasty. No a Japanese restaurant in Japan town could compare with this. 

The service and ambiance is so so but it's convenient for shoppers who are fighting with shopping on Powell st and union square...
author: Patricia H.

description: Good portions for the udon, it comes with a side of rice bowl. Also ordered a dynamite roll, pretty good. small space, not good for groups. will be back again to try other items on the menu.
author: Nikki E.

description: I'm giving a two star review for the service not the food because it was great! Came in to this restaurant in hopes of a good first experience of sushi for a friend in town. We get in and it takes 20 minutes for someone to come up to us. Service was extremely slow and not to mention.... They didn't give me my miso soup with my bento box.
author: Mitch C.

description:
