Yummy with lots of food with a reasonable price for downtown. I ordered the bento box with sashimi it was lots of food, I replaced the chicken with salmon which was really delish except a bit salty. Sashimi was fresh and big. Tempera was really good and big too, I usually don't eat tempera but this was really good. 

Boyfriend ordered karaage and tonkatsu, which were tender and homey too!

Miso soup was really good!!! They gave us extra cause they were closing. And salad was good too :)


Good find :)
author: Katherine L.

description: Was here on new year's eve. Place was crowded and we had a near 30 min wait. Surely a popular place. Started with warm sake, followed by a whole grilled squid. And then tempura with cold noodles. Really enjoyed the food.
author: Shantanu D.

description:
I have lived in Japan before and loved the Gyudon over there. Since I moved to SF, I have been searching for a place offering a variety of don (ebidon with shrimps, gyudon with beef, chicken katsu don etc). Well I believe I can say I finally found it ! I have been to other places they don't have any gyudon that is as good and as close to the real one !

I definitely recommend this restaurant for anyone looking for a very affordable and yet delicious Japanese lunch!
author: Sabrina M.

description: I ordered Ramen. It's just a ramen---nothing special. If you just want to have "normal" ramen, you can try it. Service was very slow. Staffs were not friendly.
author: Ying-Chih C.

description: I was traveling in the city and thought I try his place. The food was ok with big portion. Sadly, The owner was extremely rude, he kicked me out of the place saying other customers are waiting. But I just finished eating and trying to check my phone for direction. I did not enjoy this experience at all!
author: Wanning J.

description:
Yumm! Authentic noodles.
We were looking primarily for sushi, and this wasn't the best choice we could've made. They specialize in entrees here... especially noodles.With that being said, the sushie we did get (sashimi and spicy tuna rolls) was awesome! We both ended up ordering the bento boxes, which was a mishmash of all sorts of things. The teriyaki chicken was okay, as were the rice and salad. The tempura stuff was very delicious and all the food was very fresh. I'll certainly eat here again, but only if I'm looking for noodles.
author: Charles S.

description: Small and intimate restaurant. Food was delicious and service was quick. Be aware because of it's size you will likely be waiting for a table if you show up during peak meal times, but the turn around time is quick.
author: Miriam S.

description: One of the lowest quality food i have ever had at a restaurant. The Sushi was worst than grocery store sushi, and the Udon was even worse. Very disappointing.
author: Aaron N.

description: Came here last night with a colleague and was easily accommodated without reservations during a peak dinner time.  Quick service, Broad menu options and fairly large starving sizes.  I had the sashimi platter and had it not been so good, there would have been some to share. Also the prices seemed reasonable or lower than expected by DC standards.
author: Christopher W.

description:
This place is great! I stumbled across it by accident the first time and the second time I had no idea I was so close so it was a pleasant surprise also because I forgot the name. 
The food is always a perfect temperature, and I don't mind waiting a few minutes outside for this place. The service can be a little spotty but since I've had no problems with anything I've ever ordered, I can't even be mad.
author: Amanda M.

description: I'm a regular customer to this place. I'm soooooooooooooo disappointed with the staffs here that cannot remember and recognized us after we came to this place for 1-2 times a week for ages!!! They always making mistake giving out our turn for the tables to others after LONG WAIT!!! I gotta says... This kind of mistaking really consider part of the bad service. Usually food here is nice and I like the food here but today.... The food is TERRIBLE!!! We ordered bento with Teriyaki Chicken and Teriyaki Salmon... Both chicken and Salmon... NOT COOKED! Inside is RAW. The salad just bunch of lettuce no tomatoes, should come with 2 slices orange... It came 1 slice and they ran out cabbage I supposed they just filled all with lettuce.... this kind of service really pissed the customers. I hope they take this seriously to have better business.
author: Unyo N.

description:
The sashimi is not fresh..when I complain to the waitress of this.She yelled at me and told me I never ate any sushi before.Im so angry.That stupid waitress told me the boss or manager is not here but i know the boss is here.She lie to me right in my face.I never seen any waitress rude like this.
This is not the first I came to the place but I will tell all my frds don't ever ever ever come to this place ever again..
So angry of this!!!!!!!!!!



Not recommend of this place.This place sucks.I don't know why people give this place good review.
author: Arcadia C.

description: Quick, tasty and authentic. Sashimi platter was a standout and bento boxes were great value for lunch.
author: Chantelle S.

description:
Tried this place a few times. Here is my honest review of this place. 

It is just a regular restaurant. If you wanna something fast and you don't care much about the quality of food, go for it. You can go in and out maybe in15/20 minutes?  

The food isn't bad but nothing really stands out... And the services? Don't expect too much coz they are gonna rush you out asap. And don't expect to have dessert here either, coz they are gonna recommend you to go next door and leave asap.
author: Alanda B.

description: I been there few times for lunch with my friends. I regret ever time I go there because of bad attitude of servers and bad food. This place is one of the worst restaurants in bay area. One star is too glorious for them.
author: Henry K.

description: What appears as a hole in the wall is actually a delicious place to grab some Japanese food.  The menu is quite large- there's got to be something on it to please everyone. Service is quick and efficient.  Whenever I am in Union Square, I make it a point to stop in for the beef and onion rice bowl- love it!
author: Rachael S.

description: The food is okay, but the service was THE WORST EVER EVER EVER EVER. It's the second time that my card was overcharged at DOJIMA in SF. I was there a year ago, and I paid our bills with my friend. They charged by my card twice and tips as well. It was okay and understanding if it was busy, out of control. I just wanted my money back so I called them. The first reaction from them I expected was "We're sorry" but the first reaction I got from them was "You guys are friends, right? Just get back your money from your friends. And if you still want to talk about it, you should call us back during our break time which is after 3pm. We don't have time to talk to you right now." So, I called them back at 3 ish, but they never responded. I just stopped going there, but after few months, I went there again. And I went there Feb 21 around 7pm, it was not crowded, and not lots of people were there which means they were not that busy. We were 3 of people so we put our 3 cards, and each of us paid $18.41. Two of us paid 15% tips on card, and I paid $3 by cash, which was about 17-8% of tips. And after that, guess what? My account was charged 15% of tips as well.  THEY CHARGED ME 15% OF TIPS WITHOUT TELLING ME WITHOUT MY SIGNS. What is the problem with this restaurant? This is the worst experience ever ever never from all over the restaurants in San Francisco. I attached my receipt and card states to let  you see and believe it they did it.
author: Nayoung Y.

description:
The food was mediocre. I ordered sashimi and udon, and both of them are 3 stars at most. The reason for overall 2 stars is that I got two dirty sauce plates in a roll. The first one has some leftover pickle ginger in it, and the second one has some leftover sushi rice, which is really disgusting. Also, the water glass smells. It feels like it has been used by someone who just smoked. I really doubt whether they use dishwasher to deep clean the dishes and glasses. 

Overall the place is not the most pleasant place for dinning. The servants are cold and not communicative and the furnitures feel greasy.
author: ying l.

description: The hunt for authentic Japanese food that won't stress the wallet is a perennial problem; mythic perhaps. Fortunately Dojima-Ann is no myth, but thriving and fully-fleshed. A bit of a squeeze inside and oftentimes a wait is necessitated, but the flavors won't disappoint. Japanese food is long known for having a deceptively complex flavor set masked by a startling simplicity. Dojima does not fail to recreate this ideal. Indeed this is no venue for the culinary avant-garde, but a space that seeks to foreground the mundane. But when you are able to cultivate such rich, complex flavors the notion of "mundane" is a deceit.
author: Ton S.

description: Great portion, great food, service was decent. Clean and friendly atmosphere even with high amount of traffic of customers in and out. Highly recommended.
author: Ky O.

description:
This place is awesome! I go to the shopping center a couple blocks away very often and I always stop here for lunch.

If you're not feeling the super expensive nigiri (2 pieces for about $5), I would look on their wall for their specials! 

I usually get the Gyu Don. (Beef over rice) It comes with a small udon!!! So I have my soup and my rice!!!

Quick note though: the combo is definitely a lot of food. Be prepared to take half of your meal home!
author: Mai W.

description: This place is now officially a classic for me. I came into this restaurant only knowing that my family had a long history with the place. This was the first place my dad took my mom on a date after all. The wait took all of roughly 30 minutes due to the seating being somewhat limited. I ordered the chicken don bowl and I was completely blown away. The eggs, onion, and chicken melded for a completely genuine Japanese flavor that I can only describe as "wholly unique". I am a fan of this place and its unique don bowl options, and I can confidently say that it is quite a homage to true Japanese food. The sashimi is also quite juicy! I'll be coming back when I'm in town once more.
author: Allen C.

description:
So delicious.  I only wish it could open more locations all over the city.

Love you so much, Dojima-Ann.  xoxoxo
author: Nicole L.

description: Pretty decent Japanese food. On the smaller side inside but got seated rather quickly. Service was pretty quick too. Had the curry and sashimi. Both servings were on the smaller side for the price but was good. I'd eat here again if I was looking for a quick good bite to eat while shopping.
author: Ry B.

description:
Aweful service.  I had to get up 3 times to get there attention.  Here's the kicker, it was half way empty I here.  

The tempura I ordered wasn't fully cooked and it had - or at least felt like there was dust or tint pebbles in it. Grundy Tempura!



Bleh! I used to like this place but now it's I will def not come back. Boo!
author: Shenni C.

description: This place is my go-to when I'm shopping in Union Square. Food comes out pretty fast. The food is just okay for japanese standards but it's not bad compared to other restaurants around Union Square. It's always packed every night so I'd recommend putting your name down and come back later. I would go for the set menus when you are here and avoid eating their sashimi/nigiri. I ordered 2 pcs of uni and it wasn't fresh at all.
author: Caitlin B.

description: A quick meal when you are really hungry and happen to be nearby. The food was just fine, not impressive at all. The service was pretty bad, cold waitress.
author: Carla L.

description:
After all this time I never knew Dojima-Ann existed up the block from Union Square! Came here for dinner tonight with my girlfriend. There was no wait and we were seated immediately at 7.
Restaurant is a bit crammed but there's just enough space to maneuver around. 
I ordered the chicken onion udon. The noodles were yummy, nice and soft. There was plenty of chicken also and the broth was tasty. Also ordered the agedashi tofu which was good too. 
Prices here are a bit high if you order the dinner combos ($17+) but if you plan on ordering udon or soba noodles, expect to pay around $10-12. From the pictures, it definitely seems like the udon is popular!
Service here was fine and I wouldn't mind returning again if I was in the area and craving some udon soup!
author: Miss H K.

description:
This was one of the places that I had planned to visit.  There was a group of 10 in front of us, but they were nowhere to be seen.  The place was small and it was a bit chilly out, so we huddled inside.  The 10-people group must have given up.  So we were seated fairly quickly.  The menu is extensive with a regular Japanese everyday food items.   
Although they serve sushi, I do not think this is a place to eat sushi or sashimi. I would rather eat food that I grew up with here.  My mom and nephew were visiting from Tokyo, so it was not a big deal with them as they could eat them every day.  But for my son and I, visiting form NY, what to choose was one difficult question!  I was going back and forth between tendon (people next to us were eating it and it looked very good) and nabeyakiudon.  And at the last minute, I got the nabeyaki.
Everyone was very satisfied with the choice.
I see many negative reviews on the service, but we did not experience any poor service.
I took the photos of our order, and my sister in Tokyo correctly figured out who ordered what.  We need to be unpredictable...

Although the space is limited, wish there were some seats to sit for the seniors to wait.
author: Paige Y.

description:
I've been coming here for years. The sushi is fine but this is the place to go for noodles or for any of the meat/vegetables over rice dishes.

The rice on the spicy tuna roll could've used just a tad bit more vinegar.

The beef curry is well prepared and tasty.

The wait can be long at times due to the location.
author: Evan W.

description:
I first discovered Dojima-Ann in January of 2010, when I was preparing to take the MCAT. I was walking around Union Square, looking for a place to eat, when I noticed the unobtrusive sign for Japanese food on O'Farrell. I looked into the restaurant and it didn't seem too full, so I walked in.

It's never been the same since.

I consider Dojima-Ann one of the most authentic Japanese teishoku-yas I've been to in the United States (especially comparing across Boston, SF, and NYC). In Japan, a teishoku is a set-meal served on a tray, generally comprising of a main dish, a bowl of rice, some pickled vegetables, and a bowl of miso soup. They were amazing when I studied abroad in Japan, and memories of consuming steaming rice and awesome tonkatsu or grilled unagi in the middle of January in Tokyo are among my fondest memories. In general, I like to compare teishoku-yas to the equivalent of American diners, since I think they're pretty comparable in terms of the service, occasion for dining, and price point.

(incidentally, "Ann" means a shack, generally made of grass, or the residence of a Buddhist monk. it can also be used as a humble form to refer to one's own residence. this kind of suffix is seen in some teishoku-yas or smaller restaurants in Japanese that emphasize homey, unembellished cooking)

I highly recommend Dojima-Ann's combo with mini-udon. You get a small bowl of their udon namesake (it's just noodles in a plain broth with some spring onions sprinkled on top, but the noodles are the right chewy texture and the broth is never too salty) along with a rice dish. It's a great deal for $2 extra, but warning: it is quite a lot of food so be prepared!

I've been carving away at their combos, and these are the ones that are particularly noteworthy:

-Kaki fry (fried oysters set) - HEAVENLY. You must try if you like fried oysters, and you get a very ample serving too.

-Unagi-tamago don (eel with eggs) - the smoothness of the eggs really compliments the flavor of the grilled eel - this dish is full of the Japanese mirin-savory taste if you enjoy it (if you ever had an oyako-don, it's that taste)

-Oyako-don (chicken with eggs) - same as above

-Kitsune-udon (udon with a piece of fried sweet bean curd) - this is a very traditional Japanese noodle dish, and Dojima-Ann captures the flavor perfectly.

-Nabeyaki (udon with an assorted mixture of meat, vegetables, topped with shrimp tempura and served in a steel bowl) - this is also extremely authentic

-Sushi - they actually have very good sushi, but since it's much harder to get a good donburi (rice bowl) or teishoku (combo) IMO, I usually opt for a rice+noodle combo, but their sushi are pretty awesome as well.

That said, here are the things that I found were medicore:

-Deep fried (tempura) dishes - their tempura has this really interesting greasy aftertaste in my opinion, which I was disappointed to find out, given how strong the rest of their dishes are.

-Chicken karaage combo - don't get me wrong, the chicken karaage is fantastic, but the sheer amount they give you makes you kind of sick at the end because of the grease, unfortunately :(

-Price point - I consider Dojima-Ann to be rather pricey, unfortunately. Luckily, the quality of the food more than makes up for the price.

Going here has always been a highlight of my day and I will continue to be a loyal customer! :)
author: Chris S.

description:
Recently discovered this gem on a Saturday night with a friend, and I was delighted by the quality and the quantity of the food for the price, which drive this four-star rating. 

I got the pork katsu curry, which was huge and in and of itself; I took half home and ended up making another meal out of the leftovers. Not only that, the entree came with a salad and a bowl of udon. The portions are generous, and the food is delicious! 

The only reason I didn't give the place five stars is that it can be a bit crowded such that you have to wait a bit and it's hard to have a private conversation during dinner. That aside, this is fast becoming one of my new favorite places in SF!
author: Ada W.

description:
After shopping around Union Square, we were looking for a quick bite. There was a bit of a line up at the restaurant when we arrived but we got a table after about 15mins. We ordered the gyoza to start and I think it's one of the best gyoza I've had. I ordered the Sukiyaki Udon and my bf ordered an Unagi Don. It was a windy day in SF so it was really nice to have some warm soupy goodness here. I'm a really big fan of sukiyaki and Dojima-Ann did not disappoint. I tried a bit of the unagi don and it was also really delicious.

I also observed that there were a lot of Japanese people that came here, so it must be legit :)
author: Christina C.

description:
My friends and I stopped in for a quick late lunch here. 

I got the Tanin Don which is a bowl of beef, egg, and grilled onions over rice. I also added a Mini Udon for $2. 

This place is supposed to be known for their udon but I personally didn't really like it too much. The taste of the broth was very different from other udons I've tried and my tastebuds weren't too happy about that. The Tanin Don however, was pretty good and they gave me a huge bowl of it that I couldn't finish. 

Service was okay and we didn't have any complaints. 

Not a place I'd choose to come back to but it makes for a quick and clean meal if you're craving Japanese food.
author: Diana I.

description: This restaurant alway busy and i knew that. This is the third time i visit here  last night we when here with 3 person and they ask us minimum order per person must over $10 bucks. That's fine we know they need money. After finish and bill coming  we pay by cash plus 15% tip for them already but server turn back and ask us  this price is not included tip and we must tip minimum 15%.   That so rude. I have work in resturant too but i never ask customers for a tip  i think i never want to go back to this place anymore.  Good luck in your business.
author: Mela L.

description:
Went to Google to find this place and get a lunch menu... Says in the
Menu- Salmon Teriyaki Linch special $7.50.. Called them to order togo n said no salad since i can't have lettuce.. After a quick errand went to the place some old man at the counter told him i ordered Salmon Teriyaki lunch Special... He charged me $13.50 plus tax... WTF!!!  Told him why? On your web says $7.50 .. He says the one i went was not their website WTH!!! It had their establishment and their addy and the price... Also Told them well done but only one side was ... I will not lunch there anymore even if I get lazy going to Tokyo Teriyaki on Mission which has better pricing!!!'
author: I H.

description:
The sushi here was on the cheaper side! SCORE!!
They are also located next to Cako, DOUBLE SCORE!!!

I had the salmon chirashi don or whatever and they were VERY generous with the portion. The sushi rice was also cooked perfectly. 
I also ordered tobiko w/ quail egg (which is like, my favorite thing) and they gave it to me with TOBIKO and NOT masago like some joints. Don't let sushi restaurants stiff you on that people. Masago is cheaper than tobiko. When you order tobiko, make sure they give you your damn tobiko!

Many of the patrons in this little restaurant were also Japanese, good sign!

Great little spot to get your grub on after a long day of shopping (or work).
author: Susy C.

description:
This review is only for Udon noodles. 
As a Japanese, I sometimes crave for Udon noodles and this is the decent place for it.

There are lots of Ramen places in the Bay Area, but unfortunately it seems like Udon is not as popular.  Ramen is a bit heavy to me sometimes, and I crave for Udon when I feel like having the light food and resting my stomach from a lot of alcohol and rich food.

Although the service is generally slow and not great, I like to come here for the comfort food, Udon noodles.
author: Tomomi K.

description:
Traditional Japanese food in the heart of downtown. Easy to get to, hard to get in to. :) At peak hours there is always a wait here, so prepare to stand around while waiting for someone to finish their dinner.

The food is good. I recommend the udon, which is well prepared and has a tasty broth.
author: Roberth K.

description: The sushi here seemed pretty basic; none of the offerings were exceptional. We started with the tempura appetizer, which was served hot, light and crisp. We then ordered four different rolls, two of which were so loosely rolled they fell apart too easily and were not easy to eat. Overall flavor was good, but the presentation wasn't great. The service was efficient and friendly, until the end. We were dining early, and finished around 5 PM. We were told that we had to pay immediately because they were closing out lunch. Since we didn't order off the lunch menu this appeared to be a ploy to get us to leave so they could free up the table. No customers were waiting, so this seemed unnecessary. Not the best dining experience.
author: Jim J.

description: Well I came back on the second night of my stay so it must be good. I am a beginner sushi eater and like mostly the rolls.
author: N P.

description: food is good，especial the rice.unlike the guangdong chinese resaurant.the rice here is like japan or northeast china rice.good to eat
author: Mont L.

description: Small place but well run. Menu was wide ranging and very authentic. Sushi was delicious and the udon noodles and zaru soba were great.
author: Douglas G.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Tekka Don = zomg my new favorite thing. I love having slices of sashimi with rice! The rice was kinda skimpy, but everything was good, and had good presentation ^__^ The tuna was very soft, but it was a lil stringy. I hate that. But might be a one time deal. And omg! It comes with Miso annnnd a Miso Salad! Score!
2.) Sake = I forget which one it was, but it was that tiny bottle. It's strong. But with ice, it's sooo smooth. lol...
3.) Cold Soba = oOooohh I was just expecting the noodles. BUT it came with a cute lil raw egg lay perched in its bed of green onions. And also accompanying the noodles was a bowl of tempura veggies :D "Supplies"! Ruvvvit. Didn't expect it at all.
4.) Katsu don - yum comforting 

Definitely going to make this the go-to place for sashimi / Japanese craving shud it strike when in downtown ;) Passing by all the other tables, everything everyone else had looked deelishhhh!! 


SERVICE:
Service is awesome. Greeted right away, the servers are nice and very considerate :) 6pm on a Saturday night, the wait was only 15 minutes for us. But later on at around 8pm, I noticed there was a small crowd waiting at the doorway for a table 


ATMOSPHERE:
Very tiny, but it's cute. Very casual, low ceilings, .... But no matter, it's about the food^__^
author: Angela L.

description:
worst sashimi, worst service, small plates and none receive their plates at the same time, every 5-10 minutes one plate went to the table.
NO don't go.

15 dollars for 4 little pieces of Bad sashimi and one little miso soup. 

Now my stomach feels weird.
author: Andrea O.

description:
In my rare craving for udon, I came across this place on Yelp. We came on Friday at lunch hour and we were seated within 5 minutes. It is pretty busy, but not ridiculously busy where you won't be seated for a long time.

For an appetizer we got the grilled whole squid - so good! It was probably my favorite thing. It was served with lemon and sriracha sauce - good addition. The appetizer was about $9.

I got the shimp and vegetable tempura udon with extra noodles ($11). It's a lot more than the regular serving, which would have been $2 cheaper, and was very filling. The tempura was served on the side which was nice. The udon was tasty and so was the tempura. It was a nice fulfillment to my craving.

I also got 2 orders (4 pieces) of the ika (squid) nigiri - $9. Not very cheap, and it was a really weird texture. This was the least favorite part of my meal. And I actually could have done without it because the udon was so filling!

Service was a-ok. We were seated pretty quickly and served in a timely manner as well.

I wouldn't mind coming back here for another udon serving since there aren't many other udon places I found in the area. I'd stay away from the ika nigiri, though!
author: Junel S.

description:
I was staying at the Hilton right next door, so the afternoon when we stumbled out of the hotel starving, we literally fell into the traps of Dojima-Ann.

I ordered whatever was infront of me - which was true because I ordered the daily special that was plastered on the wall. It was a beef Udon soup combo with a teriyaki-style Unagi and rice. All this for $11.75. It was a pretty good deal!

The soup was good. Flavourful and big. The unagi was delicious! My boyfriend had the chicken udon soup and liked that too. Service was relatively quick, and we left the restaurant feeling REALLY full and satisfied.
author: Sab N.

description: Nabeyaki udon was ok but not amazing given that they are known for their udon. Do not order the tempura as the shrimp is NOT fresh. Uni sushi wasn't bad but not worth it. Overall I think it's a good place for a not so quick lunch, if you are tired of sandwiches.
author: Jia Xuan M.

description: If you are lining up, go in and put yourself on the self serve wait list just inside the door. Otherwise you won't be seated. Ordered nabe yaki udon. It was OK. Soup base wasn't very flavourful, but got a bit better towards the end as all the ingredients cooked in a bit. Udon itself felt overcooked and soft, but it was actually quite springy instead of soggy which is OK. The gentleman manning the till appears to be the owner and isn't very charming and inviting. Was rather grumpy as he pointed at the sign up sheet when I asked him for a table for one.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
Stopped in for dinner on Friday night around 6 and were seated right away. The place does not have a lot of seating but it was definitely a good environment. It took a few minutes for us to be approached by a waiter, but the service was great from then on. 

Pretty standard Japanese menu with donburi, udon, bentos and sushi. Between three of us we ordered an appetizer (shrimp and vegetable tempura), a few rolls of sushi and I had the tonkatsu donburi. I did not have any of the sushi my self but it looked wonderful. The presentation was simple but nice and the sushi was reasonably priced. The donburi was great. Comes with miso soup and the actual size of the rice bowl and amount of pork and eggs was perfect.
author: Kevin F.

description: If you like watching tourist and locals almost start to throw punches over "this food".. then go. The food is very very average if not below and the prices are all about the tourists. Skip it and go to Blue Fin Sushi instead or O'Toro.. this place is nothing special. Fried oysters were ok.. my 18 dollar salmon teriyaki was SO not worth the price and served on a wilted piece of lettuce that looked a month old. No thanks.. I'd never go back.
author: Brian W.

description:
Meeting up a friend, we didn't know WHAT to eat. She suggested curry, and I wasn't in any mood to walk ALL the way to Japantown for some good ol' Japanese cooking.

We stopped by a Starbucks and decided to Yelp a place nearby. (Thank you Yelp application for saving our lives in finding a nearby Japanese restaurant!) Do note that a lot of places were closed on a Saturday at prime dinner time. My assumption was that we were in the Financial District, and since people who usually eat at these places work Monday-Friday, 9 to 5 job, these places wouldn't make any businesses opening on a weekend.

After a phone call to make sure that this place was opened, we decided to walk the two blocks and eat here. We waited not too long, despite the fact that it was prime dinner time and the place only seats 40 people at a time. (I counted the seats as we were about to head out the door).

I had a really hard time deciding what I want besides something warm. Finally, after we got seated I looked towards the restrooms and saw three pictures slapped on the wall with the words "Today's Special" plastered across the middle one, the tonkatsu donburii and tanaki udon (for the non-Japanese speakers: pork cutlet rice bowl and tempura droppings rice noodles).

I was quite amazed by the presentation of the dish, for such a good deal, it seemed like they went all out on the cleanliness and simplicity. My friend ordered the curry croquette dish, and was surprised that the dish came with some side orders too.

- Tonkatsu donburii: I had my share of this dish (from Daikokuya, from Mitsuwa Marketplace, and possibly a few more), but this place made the pork so moist and tenure that I was shocked that tonkatsu can taste something like this! I believe it had to do with the extra moisture in the rice, which kept the tonkatsu flavorful, rather than the usual dried out odd tasting that I'm used to getting.

- Tanaki udon: I was hoping for something MORE meaty in the dish, but what could I expect from a combination dish? The broth was delish, and the tempura droppings were good too. Kind of wished it wasn't so simple, but again, it was in a combination and the soup was warm.

Wasn't too pricey, like I thought it would be. However, be careful about coming in too late. My friend and I somehow got into this place in the nick of time, before there was a line forming.

And a funny side note, I think the couple sitting next to us, at least the girl, is a Yelper too. (EDIT: looks like I was right, it was Angela L!)
author: Tom T.

description:
Had the nabeyaki udon.  Shrimp tempura was really good.  Nice batter.  Broth is clear, yet flavorful.  Very legit bowl of udon.  would say above average for San Francisco.

Tried the ichigo beer with the udon.  Beer was average by itself, but worked perfectly with the savory soup.  

Place is small, but they manage to use the space efficiently.
author: Sam T.

description: I came here in my birthday for ramen, but unfortunately there isn't one. However their shrimp Donburi was AMAZING! My boyfriend loves the curry and was surpised when it came in with a salad and udon soup.  The waitress kept our glass full and are always friendly with us. Eventhough there wasn't a birthday special, they all said happy birthday when we left the place.
author: Jackie T.

description:
Witnessing the horror of the triple catastrophes in Japan makes me nostalgic for what were happier times when my partner and I lived in Sendai, which happens to be very near the quake's epicenter.  Psychologically I have wanted to re-establish my connection to the the country where we lived for three years and whose culture I hold in unrivaled esteem.  Though it in no way benefits the people suffering in Japan, going out to eat foods familiar from those days is the surest way for me to reconnect.

I was so psyched to discover this Japanese eatery down the street from my hotel here, as it is so typical of the many places we used to go out in Sendai when a meal was had on the run or at the end of a busy day.  Japanese restaurants in the U.S. and certainly Washington, DC are exponents of sushi and all power to them!  But the variety of food in Japan goes so far beyond raw fish and rice!  It's not surprising in the least that San Francisco has a place like Dojima-Ann right in the middle of a major shopping destination, as this city has decidedly strong Asia-Pacific cultural leanings.

Yelping "Haven't had the 'mother and child donburi' (oyako-don, i.e. chicken and egg) in over a decade. High hopes here!" as I checked in yesterday, I was not disappointed in the least. I also heard a lot of Japanese spoken, though mostly by the patrons and not the staff, who seemed to prefer speaking English even to Japanese customers.  The oyako-don tasted just as I remembered and brought back so many sense memories.  I get choked up just thinking about how devastated the region where we lived has become.  And yet I have nothing but mad respect for the strength of the Japanese character and the resilience of a people who have come back to prominence following so many other unspeakable tragedies.  I'm going back to Dojima tomorrow for the tonkatsu-don (fried pork cutlet over rice) and I can't wait!
author: Sean M.

description:
A good location and a lot closer than Katana-Ya (the only other respectable Japanese place in the area).  If not for the location, I'll be honest, I'd probably never come here, but given the location and the choices in the area, this is the best you're gonna do and it ain't half bad.

Good ebi curry and I also like their soba noodle special.  Gets packed.  Their udon and rice deal is a good value.
author: Erika C.

description: I poked my head in the door of and lo and behold it was peopled by smiling Japanese speaking souls seeming to enjoy their food. Well, that was enough for me to stop and I got a simple well prepared lunch of roast whole squid and seafood salad for a reasonable price. The service was fine. I certainly noticed no mildew smell. It smelled of delicious food. Nothing fancy but good food.
author: David L.

description: Ordered the sashimi entree - the yellowtail was literally frozen. I sent it back. They gave me another one - still frozen. The manager then blamed me for not being satisfied and was beyond rude. Awful.
author: Mimi B.

description:
I love this Japanese restaurant. They are great for their savory broth and al dente udon noodles and a slightly sweetened sauce in their donburis. I ordered a kagiage udon, and a katsu donburi yesterday. Both were delicious! The kagiage was crispy, yet not too greasy w/ fresh shrimp and yummy veggies. The soup was good as always, it never lets me down. 
The katsu donburi is the best of I've tasted so far. Their sauce is specially brewed to provide a sweet taste, very different than other teriyaki sauces that are often salty!
Staff  and owner are polite and friendly. I highly recommend this restaurant for someone who wants to try the best udon noodle soups and donburis!
author: LL S.

description: A spot that's great for tourists. The location is great, being a walking distance from Union Square and also most hostels around the area. In terms of the food though, most of the menu items are overpriced, and the food quality is nothing special. There are plenty of places with much better Japanese food around the area, so skip this place if unless you are really hungry!
author: Henry L.

description:
The place is more cramped that I had imagined and the food was unimpressive.  

Came here last Thursday for dinner because I've been craving donburi and this sounded like the perfect place.  Tonkatsu donburi with mini udon on the side it is then!  Slurped up the udon first before proceeding to the donburi.  It was room temperature.  Ew.  I like my food steaming hot, especially when it comes in a soup.  So that was a no no.  The donburi was...a typical donburi.  Nothing orgasmically good about it.  Will not be writing back home to all my peeps about this.  And maybe it was because I ate it after I had finished the udon but that bowl of of rice was not hot either.  I also tried the karaage that my friend ordered.  They did seem a bit generous there with the chicken, but quality-wise, it was nothing special.

Dojima-Ann's location is convenient, very close to all the shopping.  Hence, it made sense that there was a wait for a table.  Half of the crowd there though looked like they were tourists.  I don't take that as a good sign.  Therefore, I will display more caution when choosing where to eat in the union square area next time.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
favorite place to eat around union square,
decent price with decent food.
service is okay.
we usually order the ginger pork / oyako don.

there is usually a line during 'rush hours'
but the wait shouldnt be too bad.

dont expect too much for this price at this location lol
author: Miffy L.

description:
Just finished have a meal here. I'm very disappointed after all, and here's why;
Service was horrible. Menu was on the table so I decided right away. And it took 10 minutes to make an order. Later, food was brought to my table and that was the last time I've seen a waitress/server. Right after I finished my plate, a guy suddenly dropped a check on my table. I put my card on it and ask a cup of water when they took it. Another few minutes were needed to have a water after I signed on the receipt. 
Food was not that bad but has a few problem. Rice was actually gummy, fried Ebi has a really thick paste but cooked nicely. Chicken teriyaki was good (part of it was a bit undercooked tho).
Guess it's kinda vary depends on the time when you visit and who is cooking in the kitchen, but probably not gonna visit again. Sorry, Dojima-Ann, I had a good memory with you before but now it's ruined.
author: Cein K.

description: Have to say the food is good, BUT the service is very bad. Been here 3 times this week, waited for mins and have to go stop them to ask for a table, super slow service, after done eating want to ask for check and keep ignoring me, even I've asked and then she forgot it about it.. Have to say it was about 3pm not rush hour time, so had to ask another one for check.. I don't know what's going on with this restaurant, the reason I went 3 times just because the location and they don't have break time in the afternoon.
author: Sam F.

description:
I went here at noon on a sunday and it was crowded, but luckily no wait in line. I ordered an unagi tamago donburi which was about 11.75. It was delicious! I love this place. Small and cozy, and the mirrors make the place look bigger. Will be coming back.

Pros:
Good food 
Good service
decent price

Cons:
small, not that good for groups
author: Christina G.

description: Best Japanese curry that I have had in the city so far. Great service and some rare sashimi specials from time to time. Always a great spot when I'm craving curry. Sushi is good but there are better sushi places around.
author: Andy J.

description:
Literally stumbled into this place, it's some what hidden away if you were driving by. I had ordered the tempura udon and it was alright. Not saying that I'm never going here again, but it was a nice place just to grab a quick lunch. 
I do give it thumps up for quick service.
author: Katherine L.

description: I was just there with my sister and I had the rainbow roll and Alaska roll and they were absolutely delicious! I highly recommend it. My sister had the Chicken katsu which she also enjoyed very much. The miso soup is also extremely good. The only thing that bothered us was that the space was crowded. But other than that I would highly recommend this place!
author: Elsa N.

description:
The food was acceptable, but the service was bad. We sat down at our table by the restroom and it smelled like piss. We ordered appetizers and asked to be moved when a table became available. 

Our server told us we werent allowed to take a table then ask to be moved, that we could get back in line and wait outside. Yeah, like we knew this table would smell bad when we accepted. Got the food to go instead. My udon was okay.
author: Mitch C.

description:
This place is so lovely. I remember the first time I came here, about 2 years ago, my friend and I shared a bento dinner which only came with one bowl of rice and miso soup... but the owner was so nice, he brought out another bowl of rice and miso soup for us and he didn't charge us. I was so touched and since then i've been coming back here. 
Every thing here is delicious. The tempuras especially is fried to perfection and it's similar to those that you find in Japan, I swear. I also enjoy the various dons here (pork, chicken, eel) Service here is always great. It can get busy during lunch hour and at night, but overall the food here is consistently delicious
author: Connie M.

description:
We have walked past this place from our hotel several times and each time we just didn't feel confident the food was decent here. The one time we decided to try it, we went in to ask for a table, and was greeted by a hostile male server (appears to be either the owner or the manager) who, with a frown, says "write your name on the board behind you and wait outside" and points out the door. How rude!! We didn't bother of course. 
Tonight we finally tried this place, after being ripped off at another sushi restaurant we needed a few more bites to fill up. This time the male waiter wasn't at the greeting desk haha! We only had to wait for a couple minutes and luckily there were small tables available.  We ordered two sashimi plates and a nabeyaki udon - not bad at all! Sashimi was very fresh and decent sized, the tuna was surprisingly flavourful and the hamachi was very good too! Service was alright - polite enough (except the male host ). You just have to get over some wait time and it's a decent experience.
author: Rosaline C.

description: Sushi selection was good and price was very reasonable, especially for this area. I was visiting from out of town and looking for a good sushi meal that would not break the bank. This certainly satisifed my dinner needs. I plan on eating here again next time I visit SF.
author: Gerardo P.

description: This place is always packed which says something!  I usually get their lunch specials...I get the Oyakodon (Chicken with egg and onions over rice) and it comes with miso soup.  Sushi is not bad here either.  You can also order Japanese beer and Sake here too.  Service is good.  This is my go to place for Japanese food in Union Square area.
author: Rissa K.

description: This place used to be pretty good, but now it's just mediocre.   The food does not taste authentic even though they kept all the Japanese signs and wordings.  Note to the owner: maybe you can fool some of the tourists, but not the locals in this town.
author: Dave C.

description: Simple japanese menu. Really love this place. Great service and awesome food. UNA TAMA DON for the win
author: Edna L.

description:
(See pics)

Well, the food and service are solid 4+ stars.

Peter L and I came here after YEE to pack some great food in, to continue a good night of fun events.

The service was great because the adorable server actually remembered PL ordering both a beer and sake last time and joked if he was going to order them together again. You know it's not just being courteous service but was so very friendly and fun environment to be in.

Food is as usual great. The sashimi is always very good and the combo is always a great deal. This time we have udon and Japanese curry, which were all very delicious. Don't forget the different specials on the wall such as the deep fried squids. Tempura was also very good without being greasy.
author: T L.

description:
Best salmon and rice I had in San Francisco. The place is always packed with Japanese customers, a good sign. It's also very affordable. 
This is one of my go-to places downtown.
author: Cécile P.

description:
As I was walking down O'Farell looking for a place to have lunch, I stumbled upon this small Japanese place.
I ordered Unagi Donburi and it was pretty good. The service was fast because I came here aroun 11:30 am. This place gets packed at noon.  I might come back here again to try their Tempura Udon
author: Claudine V.

description:
Gross 
Gross 
Gross

As a San Francisco resident, I would not have stepped foot in here except for an out of town guest who wanted to go to a Union Square sushi tourist trap.

The fish was dry and bland - def poor quality. It was actually horrendous. They even mucked up the soft shell crab (more like deep-fried mushy crab). Udon/ramen was okkkkkaaay. My main gripe was the sushi. I would give negative stars if I was just reviewing that. 

Never did get that water/tea refill...

I seriously don't get the 5 star reviews O_o 
For nearby sushi, opt for Katana-Ya or Ryoko's. Worth the extra penny.
author: Cassie C.

description:
I've come to Dojima-Ann probably 3 or 4 times with friends and every time I enjoy myself. I usually opt for their set specials, but I've also tried a few sushi rolls and their donburis. Their katsu dons are very good. They're simple but made with care and fresh ingredients. I can't remember which rolls I had but I remember that they were a bit overpriced and nothing special.

I would suggest that you go for whatever their specials are. Sometimes those specials include donburi items so you can get the best of both worlds! I think most of them include udon. These specials are the best bargain. This place is tiny and you may face a wait at lunch or dinner rush. The workers all seem to be Japanese which gives this place a refreshing authenticity that a lot of Japanese restaurants don't have.
author: Sannie L.

description: I love this place! Probably one of the great Japanese spot I visit for lunch hours when I crave normal authentic Japanese food. Location is perfect if you are in downtown and are craving for some good Japanese food:) Ahhhhh I wanna eat there again soon!
author: Maitai N.

description:
The place is nice and well sited (just next to Powell Street). The food is not awesome, but it is definitely OK. My friends and I took various dinners, and everybody was satisfied, except the one who took a beef noodle soup, who found the taste of the beef too strong.
Prices are a little expensive, though.
author: Julien B.

description:
Their combos are pretty cheap for a good amount of food (about $10-$15)

Their best items were the tempura dishes.

Ramen was so-so.
author: Steven F.

description:
I have been here at least four times and have been disappointed each time.

I have had their bento, curry, ramen, udon, and rolls before. Each time, the portions are way too small for the price, and it is obvious that the fish is not fresh. I suppose the price point is expected for a restaurant so close to downtown San Francisco, but they could at least make an effort to provide food made with some integrity. 

I also have a serious issue with their service. They are quick to clear your plate and to give you your check, but unless you bother them about refilling your tea, they will never come by to pour some for you. Even if you ask them, they will make sure to refill AFTER you've paid.
author: Yolanta S.

description:
Great place to stop by for lunch or dinner in San Fran. It is a small mom and pop place looking joint.  The staff was courteous and fast.  The food was great quality and authentic fare.

I had the Kitsune udon with a rich broth that was layered with flavor but mild.  That is probably why there was shichimi on the table for everyone to flavor to personal taste.  The noodle were well cooked and tender and not mushy.  The aburage was sweet and juicy with a hint of smokey roasted flavor.  It had enough tooth to it so that it stood up in the broth but not overcooked.

I also got some sushi to see how this was.  The rice was well made with soft grains with a moderate strength su that had a hint of vinegar.  The Saba had a bit too much of a vinegar flavor for my preference that overpowered the fish.  It was also slightly mealy in texture.  The Ikura however was salty, juicy, and firm with the small eggs bursting with the richness of the sea.  It was even richer with the addition of a qual egg that was silky and rich.  Tako was well cooked to a firm but not chewy texture.  Enough of a smokey taste that it blended well with the rice and su for the nigiri.

I would eat here again when back in the area.
author: Jason N.

description:
Although I hate to make critical remarks on a place that other Yelpers seemed to like, my candid feeling was Dojima Ann has amateurish udon.  For a place that promotes Osaka Udon, my expectations were high, yet heir noodles were comparable to frozen/packaged udon sold at Nijiya with very little "koshi" (chewiness).  Whether their soup is really Osaka style is up for a debate.  

As for their other specialty, katsudon (pork cutlet over rice bowl), it was authentic, but nothing special.  Their pork was a bit hard, possibly over cooked.  While I like to have green onion cooked with onions and eggs, they just sprinkled raw green onions on top.  Everyone has their favorite type of katsudon, so some people might like Dojima Ann.  As for myself, I thought that katsudon at Maki's in Japantown was much better.

PROS:  Dojima Ann is a handy place to know if you want an inexpensive Japanese lunch when shopping in Union Square.
author: トモ T.

description: I had a really bad sushi experience with their chef's choice. I wasn't even able to finish it.
author: Susan T.

description:
[M]ona: 3 Stars
[W]ayne: 2.5 Stars
Average: 2.75 Stars

+ Conveniently Located in Downtown
+ Accepts Credit Cards
+ Big Portions

- Crampy
- Slow Service
- Bad Sushi
- Bitter Broth
- Bitter Tea
- Overly Salty Miso Soup 

[W] San Francisco is such a beautiful place especially if you're living here and visit from afar. You have so much to do around here from Fisherman's Wharf, Downtown, and Golden Gate Bridge... what the hell am I talking about. Don't you hate people giving their life story??? Just kidding. This is suppose to be a review right? Anyways...

So me and Mona checked this place out since I transferred back to the city and I work downtown now. I only had an hour for lunch so this was the spot we chose. Dojima-Ann is only of the few Japanese Restaurants that is located in the Downtown area. It's pretty hectic down here everyday so it's hard to find parking unless you go to the parking garages which aren't cheap anymore. This restaurant can also get busy at times as well but I don't know what's the hype since IT DOESN'T EVEN TASTE THAT GOOD!

[M] Wayne ordered the Beef and Salmon Teriyaki Combination Bento Box [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=IV_moeIwmpx1XdWq-ibxFg] and I had their daily special. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=EoOpLJtNUE6dgCalyHomnw] We also ordered a California Hand Roll and the Philidelphia Roll. 

[W] Ok, let's start off with the bento box. My beef teriyaki was over cooked so the meat was all dry. Normally, the beef should be a little moist but even all that teriyaki sauce did it no justice. The salmon teriyaki was ok as well. I guess I just had to keep dipping the meats back into the teriyaki sauce to add more flavor and let it be a little more juicy. It also had a side cantelope and some salad. 

The Miso Soup [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=DFGtF0AzMxtGi9cyOtPf1A] that came with the meal was overly salty. It kind of tasted like it was some packaged Miso Soup that I can just buy at Ranch 99. 

[M] Their daily special was Tonkatsu Donburi and Tsukimi Udon. [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=EoOpLJtNUE6dgCalyHomnw]
The Tonkatsu Donburi was hands down the best I've had. The rice was steamy hot and flavorful and the cutlet was crispy good. It was extra saucy too so that is an extra plus for me. Can't say the same for the udon. The broth was a too bitter and salty for me to enjoy.

One thing that I couldn't overlook was how bitter their tea was. Wayne said it tasted as if they served us the bottom of the pot and just kept refilling hot water to dilute the tea. Tasted more like "Fu Cha" to me. This definitely goes on my list of one of the worst teas that I've ever had.

[W] Moving on to the California Hand Roll, [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=OWab8EzMavz3fACgw3kOYQ] they might as well call it, "We Didn't Even Bother To Try" Hand Roll. Normally it should be some sort of effort in making it, such as having the crab meat peeled and rolled nicely. But it basically was some seaweed wrap, a imitation crab stick that was literally right out of the box and rice. I'm like, seriously??? I can just buy my own ingredients and make it myself with plenty left over! Not worth paying $4-5 dollars for. But then again it IS downtown so they have to milk their tourists somehow right? And if you're a tourist, DO NOT EVEN THINK this is good Japanese food. You don't even know haha.

Service overall was fairly slow as well. Their dining room isn't that big either and they usually have about 2-3 servers. That's a pretty crappy job in my book if 2-3 girls can't even handle 20 people. We were waiting for our check while the girl at the counter was just counting up her tips. I think their little register should be facing the dining room floor instead of the entrance so they can actually see if customers who need to be serviced. 

This is one of those restaurants that doesn't get anything done unless you flag them down. They're very good at taking your order and disappearing for the rest of your meal until they're ready to collect your money. I think I get better service at Burger King. Lines are quick, and I can have everything my way.
author: Mona C.

description:
I've been here on three separate occasions and ordered different things every time and here is the general feedback:

mediocre taste, horrible service, always a wait.

I don't want to come back here again..(didn't even want to come back during my second or third visit)
author: Hannah K.

description: Dojima Ann is a Chinese owned Japanese restaurant located on the fringes of Union Square near the TL. They serve all of the traditional Japanese fare (udon, donburi, sushi). They specialize in the obscure items, but the udon and donburi get the job done in an efficient manner. I ordered an eel donburi (eel over rice with egg and chives). Portion and flavors were just right. Eel was standard. Price is reasonable, though service is rushed. Considering Dojima Ann's close proximity to Union Square (and an overall dearth of quality food), this option is solid.
author: Jay C.

description: Thank you yelpers, this place is top notch. Loved my rolls I had at a late lunch. Friendly service.
author: david G.

description: This place is in busy area downtown so it doesn't have to be good to fill up.  The place is not ventilated very well.  Tempera and the bento boxes are alright and reasonably priced for downtown.
author: Byron L.

description: This is a really good Japanese place.  I had the Japanese curry, inari sushi, and a katsu curry udon with gyoza special.  The flavors are quite accurate to those you find in Japan.  The Japanese curry is delicious and the katsu (pork) served with the curry was great.  The udon noodles are excellent and are clearly freshly and expertly prepared.  I went here three times in the span of a week because I enjoyed it so much.  My average wait time from sitting down to having an entree in front of me was 15 - 20 minutes.  The service overall was good as well.
author: David B.

description: Experienced terrible service. Our waitress was not very personable or knowledgeable about Japanese food. She never asked us how we are doing or if we need something. Had to flag down the manager for our drinks. The 5 star is for the food. The salmon don was delicious. Next time I'll just have to endure the bad attitude for that salmon
author: Nina C.

description: Cheap taste-like-authentic-Jap food. There is always a line during lunch hours but it doesn't take too long. Short of serving staffs, so takes forever to get a check or a water refill.
author: Joelle K.

description: Stopped by this place for takeout sushi.  There was a line outside so maybe takeout is the way to go if you're staying at a hotel nearby.   Good place for decently priced sushi.
author: Gary L.

description: Very quick service with good food: had the kakiage udon and agedashi tofu with a friend. Found the combination to be a bit much on the fried side in terms of batter/flavor, but that was my fault for ordering.
author: Sam R.

description:
I enjoy eating the Tonkatsu Curry Dinner here. It is great to get when you are especially hungry!  The curry comes w/ a side salad and side udon, in addition to the curry and rice.  The udon is super delicious!

I've also had the Udon w/ Tempura which I would recommend if only the Tempura was separate from the Udon!  By the time you get to eating it, the Tempura is all soaked in soup. Also, I like Tempura dipping sauce which it doesn't come with.

I've had the Tuna Sashimi, which I would not recommend. There is better sushi to be had elsewhere.

The restaurant is really busy and very small.  I think the waiters and waitresses are so busy making sure they don't bump into customers that getting their attention can be difficult.  

Overall, this is a great place to go for curry or udon!
author: Erica D.

description: Slow service for pretty bad food. Oolong tea was in a bottle. Enuf said. Still waiting for my check. Everything takes forever even though it's not crowded at all.
author: Renee P.

description:
Green onion, raw egg - pretty trivial stuff it seem like.
But once I found out that it wasn't on my unagi bowl I realized how much these garnish matter in my food experience.

I looked through yelp photos to see what looks good. The una-ju (unagi ricebowl) looked so delicious with the raw egg and green onion so I immediately called and ordered a pick up.
 
Once I picked it up, got home and opened the bowl, I found an unagi, sauce and rice.
No green onion to diversify the taste, no raw egg to experience the creamy yolk mixed with the sweet sauce and rice. 

Unagi it self was good... well except the sauce tasted like mitarashi rice cake sauce.  Hmm... 

... so sad.
author: Yuki A.

description: The grilled whole squid was to die for. It came to the table neatly sliced with a mayo dipping sauce and wedges of lemons. Not knowing how grilled squid dipped in mayo tasted, it actually complemented the squid perfectly and simply. If there is a better item on the menu, I want to taste that too. I enjoy low key joints - this defines that description.
author: Pat F.

description:
I've been dining here a lot lately. Perhaps it's just been my steady craving of quality Japanese food. They don't skimp on the servings and the food is a notch better than most in the Union Square area. The two-item bentos are just under $12 to which you can add a mini-udon for $2. Plenty of donburi bowls to choose from all of which are mostly under $10. The tempura-don is delicious and plentiful.  

I've noticed a lot of Japanese dine here, so you know it must be good!
author: Anna R.

description: My partner and I went to this restaurant a few weeks ago and I had a terrible experience as a vegetarian.  We go to many Japanese restaurants and while I understand that Japanese food is not the most vegetarian friendly cuisine, this restaurant was almost impossible to eat at.  Every item was either cooked in fish broth, contained other meat products, or was fried in non-vegetarian oil.  I couldn't even order vegetarian tempura.  I tried to order plain udon noodles with soy sauce and the server gave me udon noodles with a sauce that I could not eat even though she knew I was a vegetarian.  Do not go to this restaurant if you have any kind of dietary restrictions because they couldn't remotely accommodate.
author: India G.

description: There are a lot of safe-delicious plates and very unusual plates such as Uni Tororo Soba. Rice is pretty good. I recommend the Niku Udon set or Katsu Donburi set. Anything that is sashimi is good.
author: Ibelig V.

description:
Dojima-Ann is definitely one of my favorite spots to grab a bite to eat in Union Square.  Not only is its location absurdly convenient (on O'Farrell, across the street and steps away from the H&M on Powell), the food is exceptional.

The focus of the restaurant is on its non-sushi type entrees.  However, I've also really liked the rolls that I've gotten here.

Although there might be a line, the turn-over rate is fast.  I don't think I've ever had to wait more than 20 minutes for a seat (if you come before 7:00 PM there shouldn't be a wait).   

*Insider Tip: For an absolutely amazing deal, look to the posters on walls opposite the windows facing O'Farrell.  Listed are combo deals on tonkatsu don, unagi don, udon, and cold soba to name a few.  Best deals I've seen in a Japanese restaurant yet!
author: Fei L.

description: I love this place.  Yummy Japanese comfort food!!!  Their chirashi is always fresh and delicious! My other favorites are their katsu curries.
author: Kim L.

description:
Dojima-Ann has become my go-to at lunch when I'm craving Japanese.  Sure, I work at China Basin and there's a Japanese resto right around the corner....But it sucks!  And sure, Dojima-Ann is like a 10 minute drive from work and I have to call on my famous parking karma to score a spot at a meter and not have to lot it.  But it's worth it!  Seriously, I've been here a few times and not once have I been disappointed with the food here.

First things first.  It's small and can get crowded, so walk in and put your name on the list at the cash register.  Some people do not know this and the staff are too busy to monitor who's standing at the door.  (Yes, I learned this the hard way.)  This is one of those places that can only seat about 30 people so I'd suggest going a little early to beat the rush.  My regular is either the Oyako Don or the Katsu Don.  Both HELLA good.  I love the flavor of their sauce and LOVE how the egg is nice and gooey.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=8xH2_Dm8zsm4EDBgoUuMEw)  I also get their caterpillar roll and/or the philly roll.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cseyjQ0XIp6dwC0_TcaMOg?select=J5DtWDC_W_YptlhjakmbnA)  The sushi here is good too.  I'm not gonna say their caterpillar roll is mind-blowing like it is at Ebisu, but it's still pretty damn tasty with good quality ingredients.

This spot is right on O'Farrell, a block away from the O'Farrell parking lot and a few doors up from Cako.  I'd say if you're at Macy's or H&M shopping and hankering for some Japanese food, make your way to Dojima-Ann.  I'll admit, I was pretty surprised how good the food was here.  I'm not sure if the staff or even the cooks here are Japanese, and I know some of you have biases about that.  But I've been back a few times (peep the check-ins) and have never been disappointed.  And if the place is always filled with Japanese customers, then doesn't that mean it's legit?  Just sayin'.
author: Joe M.

description:
I had supper plans looming, but met up with a hungry friend beforehand and we dropped in here for a quick snack.

It was fresh, proper, tastefully prepared basick sushi. I just got one New York roll--maybe out of nostalgia, maybe because shrimp and avocado sounded good--and it didn't disappoint. The menu could have been a smidge more expansive, but I appreciated the restraint at the same time, a bit.

It did take a while to flag down our server for the check, but she even brought us separate checks without us having had to ask first, which was pretty awesome.
author: Bria D.

description:
Had the nabe yaki with soba noodles and a plate of gyoza. The soba was good, but the broth was lifeless (to mirror the sentiments of some folks who posted reviews here as well). I wasn't about to doctor it with anything, as I hate to do that anywhere.  

Gyoza was well formed and the pan-seared bottom crust was perfect, but the meat filling was a bit bland and missing that sourness usually associated with good filling at place like Din Tai Fung and some of those holes in the wall that remind of what mama used to make. I rarely add shoyu to the dipping sauce, but I had to at this joint. Honestly, I'd go back in a pinch, but there is lots to eat still here in the Tenderloin.
author: Michael D.

description:
Pros:
1) Tea is rice flavored and unique.
2) 49er roll - Salmon/lemon on top of Shrimp Tempura Roll = BOMB!
3) Fish is FRESH
4) Nice atmosphere
5) Good pricing

Cons:
(none that I can think of)
author: Calvin L.

description:
This review is simply for the tonkatsu donburi. Its a rice dish with pork cutlets and egg but its really good. They put this sweet sauce in it and it makes the rice moist and the whole dish really satisfying. I always ask for a side of their sauce and some hot sauce too, to dip my pork in. 

I've also ordered their udon. It was bland and unmemorable. 

Beware of lines. They can get busy sometimes. Put your name on their list, grab a cupcake next door, stop by UNIQLO around the corner, and come back :).
author: Chau T.

description: Great sushi! We had take away and even though the place was full we got our order pretty quick.
author: Marianne S.

description:
Working in Union Square, I have frequented this place enough over the years and I'm sad to say that the service along with the food quality has gone down.  It's lunch time on a Tuesday and the staff acted as if the customers asking to place orders from their tables were a complete inconvenience.  Flagging down any one of the three servers for some tea and water was very difficult, since they refused to make eye contact with you once your food was served.

The food quality is on the better side considering the prices you pay.  But do not expect a 20% tip when service was obviously not on the menu.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
crowded, a bunch of Asian tourists, compact space, loud as it can get, love the Japanese atmosphere, services can be lacking but the food is bomb. 

tonkatsu don - nom nom nomdesuu! That's all I can say.
author: Jan P.

description: No frills Japanese restaurant probably most notable to me because they have a lot of non-sushi items. I think the oyaka-don ("mom and son" or basically chicken and egg with rice) is solid here and what I always get when I'm in the area.
author: Victor W.

description:
I've decided to come here for my dinner break after seeing my co-workers ordering take outs a few times.

The place was quite small when I first walked in and the seatings were a little cramped. It took awhile for the waitress to hand me a menu after I was seated and to take my order as well. I ordered a tonkatsu don and it was delicious with a good portion. 

Overall, my experience here was so-so due to the lack of attentiveness in their service but it's still worth to give this restaurant a try because the food is pretty good.
author: Eden W.

description:
Small small small! Came here halloween weekend and I was shocked at how small this place is, however it is SF afterall and a asian restaurant, they always seem to be a bit smaller than most. 

The smell however, it was a bit, hmmm unsettling. My friend said it smelled like soy sauce, I say pee. Ehh whats the difference. However, the food was actually pretty decent, not the best sushi I have had, but better than some I have tried. The salads and soup was good, the sweet shrimp I had was nice as well, you would be surprise how gross that can be at some places. My friends to all seemed to like their meals. The spicy tuna was very spicy, though very good, cleared up those sinuses. 

I would say no real complaints they were able to split our checks, though tell them in the beginning. Also around dinner this place is packed, so prepared to either wait or go somewhere else.
author: Michelle H.

description:
This place is good, depending on what you order.  After reading previous reviews of Dojima-Ann, I've conclude that a lot of negative thoughts of this place are based on their sushi.  So since I'm not big on raw stuff, I come here specifically for their Donburi. 

I dined here on Black Friday over the Thanksgiving weekend with my sister and her BF.  It was a crowded afternoon, even at 2pm, but this was understandable given it was the most busy shopping day of the year.  Luckily, our wait was only about 5 minutes. 

I always order the same thing when I come here--The Daily Special : Tonkatsu Donburi with Mini Udon for $11.95.  Generous slices of pork were nicely battered, and smothered with a semi-runny egg.  I love with the egg on my donburi is runny! That truly shows an authentic donburi.  Flavor was perfect, nice and sweet.  The mini udon accompanying the donburi is average, and the broth is a bit too salty.  But for the most part, this is a great deal for a little combination of rice and noodles together.   If you must order something here, give the Tonkatsu Don a try.  

My sister ordered the Niku (Beef) Udon with Mini Unagi Don, for $11.95 as well.  She also received generous yummy  portions of eel complimenting her bowl of noodles.  The BF also ordered Unagi Don with Miso soup.  

For drinks, I stick to my hot tea...Angie ordered an Iced Coffee, which FYI, is canned.

Service was surprisingly attentive on this busy shopping day, which I was pleased about.  

Overall, as other Yelpers proclaim, skip the sushi, and stick to their combination plates and/or Donburi instead for a heartier version of Japanese food Downtown.
author: Cass J.

description: Service wasn't that great. Food was average or slightly above. I got the Katsudon, I received a small sized cutlet, but it was cooked right, along with the eggs. The udon was good, but had too much of that breading stuff in it. I wouldn't wait the 25 minutes for a table that we did. I would come back again and try some other stuff, if there was no wait.
author: Jon L.

description:
I had my most disappointing udon ever - their nebewaki udon. Despite it being beautifully presented, i should have noticed the bowls of half eaten udon bowls in the neighboring tables before ordering it. Yes, the broth is light. But totally lacks character. One tiny tempura, two pieces of fish cakes, one egg, one mushroom.... And i had to ask where was the chicken. Ah, buried under the noodles were three quarter-sized chicken bites. Hardly worth the price they were asking. 

Another group sat down next to me and asked about my opinion, I immediately told them to avoid the noodles. They heeded my suggestion.
author: J H.

description:
My new favorite comfort food is tonkatsu don (pork cutlet rice bowl), and the one at Dojima-Ann is ridiculously good like Flo Rida's new song. Dare I say the tonkatsu don is the best one I've had in my life although I usually order sushi or ramen at Japanese establishments. 

I don't know how a bowl of rice topped with deep-fried pork cutlet, egg and scallions can be so simple and yet so scrumptious but it is. The pork katsu remains crisp even over hot rice, under a soft egg and smothered in that savory sweet crack sauce. You gotta get it because you won't regret it.

I've also had the unagi don (eel rice bowl) and the udon here. If you love unagi and you're searching for the best, you haven't looked very hard otherwise you would've stumbled on the roasted unagi with avocado sushi rice at The House (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-house-san-francisco). As for the udon, it's ordinary but filling here. I'm still looking for seriously tasty udon in SF.

Come for the location and price. Stay for the tonkatsu don. Winner winner under $10 dinner.
author: Liz T.

description:
Came in here with a friend on a whim and found the restaurant to be a packed house. The space is very small, which may have been a factor. We came in at 7:30 pm and the only seating there was for 2 people was at the bar, which was no problem for us. Right as we were seating a huge wave of people came in to dine and the line remained long as more and more people came in.

It took a while to have our drink and food orders taken as well as to get our final bill. Other than that the service was quick and efficient when receiving our drinks and food. We ordered one large hot sake and one large Sapporo beer for sake bombs. This turned out to be about four per person. I ordered the spicy tuna roll and cucumber roll. Both were visually appealing, but the taste was just so-so. I have had better. My friend ordered some kind of shrimp tempura rice bowl and miso soup. I had her soup and it was about average. She said her rice bowl was "okay."

They had a wide selection of food on the menu in general, but not so much when it came to specialty sushi rolls. The prices were not what I would consider expensive, but were pricier than other sushi places that had better food.

Overall, the food, service and prices were average.
author: Nicole B.

description:
The eel... oh, the eel. Dojima-Ann serves some of the best unagi-tamago don - eel over rice and egg - around. Reliably taste udon, as well.

Service could be better, but for such a busy and conveniently-located joint, I'll give them a pass.
author: Son N.

description: Service is soo slow. It took ten minutes or so to get their attention to take our order. They seemed to be understaff. We ordered two rice bowls, and two bento boxes. When it got to the California roll, rice was over cooked. Thank goodness, we only ordered that from the sushi menu.
author: Eileen O.

description: Had takeout here. Ordered a rainbow roll and salmon roll for total of $20. The serving size was way too small. Rolls were size of my thumb. Way overpriced. Decrease price or drive serving up.
author: Meng G.

description:
Waiting time is ridiculous. 
Went there on a Wednesday, and the waiting time was close to 2 hours.

Food is ok. I've had better sushi.
author: Cryo L.

description:
I've been going here since I used to work at a nearby hotel in 2008-2009. The bento boxes are my favorite since it's a deal and I typically order shrimp & veggie tempura and either chicken katsu or chicken teriyaki since the bento comes with a choice of two entrees. It also comes with salad, miso soup and rice which is a bargain for the price especially in downtown SF. 

However, what Japanese visitors and locals alike flock here for is their noodle soup. I will have either the chicken & onion or beef & onion soup (you get a choice of udon or soba noodles) when I get this dish on occasion and it is absolutely delicious. I like the soba or buckwheat noodles as I don't usually like udon or thick rice noodles for some reason. 

In the rare times that I have ordered the sushi, it has always been fresh and tasty. The service can be a bit hasty at time especially when they are busy, but don't come here for the service, come here for the food.
author: Jared C.

description: Just left 30 minutes ago, as I celebrated my birthday with my family on late notice. We arrived 9:30PM when they close at 10PM, and the place was still packed with a line outside the place. The food was really good. Had the rainbow roll and nabeyaki bowl, both recommended. My wife had the  special katsu don, and that was great as well. Three of the people that helped us were helpful and friendly. The only room for improvement was that our gyoza appetizer came at the end of the meal (they forgot), and I never received my hot tea. This happened with the first lady that helped us once we were seated. She was the least friendly, did not apologize when she came with our gyoza. The rest of the staff was so good, that they came by several times to make sure we are okay, and they even came around to all patrons one by one to let us know it was last call, and imagine this the man packed our food to go (no one does that anymore! i sure miss full service. hate places that hand you boxes and expect you to do it yourself then get upset their tip is not as much). As for the lady that was not as friendly as the rest of the staff, With that said, she provided okay service, everyone else was fine and the food was great. So overall good experience and we would go there again...maybe the one lady will be more friendly as she gets to know my family :-D
author: Manny P.

description:
The boyfriend and I did our regular "walk from home to Union Square because we need some exercise" extravaganza. This time around, we also wanted to stop by the Macy's Christmas Tree. Anyways, as we started getting hungry, I said I wanted something light since Thanksgiving (and the days after) pretty much made my tummy in a very anti-heavy foods mood. I wanted a sandwich or salad, but since it was pretty cold, we decided to get Japanese - something light yet more comforting.

We decided on Dojima-Ann since the bf had been here before and we were nearby. When I saw the menu, I knew it was a good choice since they offer your usual simple Japanese dishes - sushi, rice bowls, noodles/noodle soups, combination entrees, etc.

On a Sunday night around 7PM, the small restaurant was packed. I liked the feel of the restaurant - semi crowded, vibrant, small shop. Service is good here - attentive, quick, and food comes out fast. The food is also decent here - exactly what you would expect from a casual Japanese dining spot. We ordered the Nabeyaki Soba, Combination (with sushi and Saba Shioyaki), and also an order of Tuna and Hamachi Nigiri. All of our dishes were good - standard tasting Japanese food. I especially enjoyed their Saba Shioyaki.

Prices are good here, however my only gripe is the pricing on their combination orders - the rice and noodle bowls are around $8-$10, which is a great price, but my combination box was $17.50 - a little too high I think.

Overall, good spot if you're looking for a casual Japanese meal.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
I finally came here after seeing so many people waiting in line outside each time I go to downtown. 

Lets sum this up by, I should have just gone to Japantown for Dinner. 

Upon arrival, remember to write down your name on the inside clip board.
