Since this is a busy restaurant, after being seated for 5 minutes, I was asked to order. 

I ordered a tempura udon. The tempura was soaked in broth upon arrival. I couldn't drink the soup since its battered soup. 

My friends ordered Chirashi, Tonkatsu Curry, and Tekka Maki. This place does not carry fresh fish and neither was the sashimi cut correctly. The pieces were uneven and oddly shaped. Tonkatsu Curry was just OK.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
This was one of the dining highlights of my family's recent trip to San Francisco :)

Being from Hawaii, we were craving Japanese food (particularly sticky white rice) after a few days.  A quick disclaimer: even though we were on vacation, my family was trying to save money wherever possible and we weren't willing to splurge on meals.  Luckily for us, we found this restaurant by chance while walking around Union Square. 

We grabbed an early dinner around 4pm and it was packed!  Because the restaurant is pretty small, I wouldn't recommend this place for large groups (our party had five people and the restaurant staff had to move two tables together to accommodate us). 

As for the food, it was not only delicious but very affordable (especially for the location)!!!!  I ordered a combination meal with teriyaki salmon and tempura.  It came in a cute bento-style box and included several other small sides and a bowl of miso soup.  For under $12, it was definitely a good deal!!  My brother and dad added on a bowl of udon to their meals and both enjoyed it.  I'd say that most dishes were in the $8-12 range.  

The staff was very nice and provided excellent service.  I highly recommend this restaurant and would definitely go back if given the opportunity to travel to SF again!
author: Kristen N.

description: Was looking for a place open at 11 for lunch and my original spot wasn't open till 1130. Upon entering the restaurant there was a strong odor... Possibly cleaning supplies or just old walls and floor. This totally killed the ambience and the dining experience. Additionally, a homeless man entered the restaurant to annoy the employees and left an unpleasant scent. My tea was watered down and flavorless. The food was average, the sushi roll rice was over cooked and hard.  Overall, if you're desperate for something quick to eat and a place open early then  why not?
author: Colleen C.

description: This place is so not consistent! I guess its depends on which chef you have that day. I usually get togo, but I realized if you dine in, you will get more and better quality. I've talked to the owner once, but he literally didn't care and walked away. Probably he doesn't care small togo business, since he has people waiting in line trying to get in.
author: Allie K.

description:
Party of seven just blocking the freaking doorway. WTH?
I get in there to fill out the waiting list only to find out there is a table for 2 available. AWESOME!
The table is a bit small. =/
The waitresses came by pretty quick to give us tea and to take our order.
Besides them bringing our food we never saw them again. 
We ordered 2 rolls to share. They did not give us little dishes besides a dish to hold our soy sauce. Not cool. 
We asked for more tea which took 10 minutes and it also took forever for them to give us our check. 
I thought the sushi could have been better.
author: Sarah C.

description: No frills restaurant. Food is decent. Customer service could be better. If looking for a quick bite and they can seat you reasonably quickly, I'd recommend it.
author: Jisun C.

description: Why you only mehhh?  Upon entering, the restaurant had a weird smell.  One that I was not too particularly fond of. it was also not spacious and the service sucked.  The waitress only came to take our order and to bring us food. Not once did she bother to check on us.  The combo was mehhh... Prices are decent but food is okay.
author: Ann L.

description: We ordered to go on a Friday night. Over the phone the serves was friendly. The order was ready fast. However the food was sub par. The edamame was cold, the tofu in the soup wasn't tofu and the sushi roll hardly had any fish in it. I would not return again
author: Cyrena E.

description: Always a treat to come here when in the city! The chicken udon is always fantastic. The salmon dishes are a delight! The restaurant is in a small space but the place is a warm and cheery culture.
author: John M.

description:
The food was alright for what was on the table. My biggest issue was that the waitress was rude. She took our order. I wanted the shrimp tempura and what I ended up getting was the mackerel.

We tried to tell her that maybe she got the wrong order. We said "Excuse me, I don't think this is the right dish..."

And while standing at another table, she raised her voice and was like "No. That is what you order. I took your order. I know. You ordered the shrimp tempura and then changed it the second time. I heard you. That's what you said." Even then I never said the word mackerel the whole time I was ordering.

I was like "Okay, it's fine. I'll just eat this" because I'm not one to make a scene for one, let alone a scene while the table she was helping was just staring at her and us.

And she went ON AND ON about how she heard me say that I ordered the mackerel and that she was right. 

Like gosh, ALRIGHT LADY. I'M FINE WITH THE FISH. SHUT UP AND LEAVE ME ALONE. I'LL EAT THE FISH!

Oh yea, and then we had split the bill and told her to put 14 dollars on a credit card and the rest in cash. She didn't bother to return our change. Instead of letting us fill out the tip, she kept our change and charged the card 12 dollars and added 2 dollars in the tip to make it 14.

The money part wasn't a big deal as it was only a few bucks... but you know, we should get our change back just as principle.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I have come here multiple times with friends primarily because of it's convenient location. It's right in Union Square shopping and easily accessible by BART. 

The service is decent, and can take a tad long even when ordering something as simple as seaweed salad and one roll. The quality of the food is pretty good, but the taste is not that great. Although it is decent, I didn't find it to be memorable. While most of the time, the food is consistent, I felt like the fish wasn't always fresh.

The Unagi over rice and Soba Noodle Soup is what I stick to when coming here.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I personally think that this is the best little Japanese eatery that I like around Union Square.  If you are feeling like Japanese while shopping, come here.

Things of decent quality, they are attentive to the cleaniness of the food, and there are still hints of the Japanese spirit in their food.

I generally get the curry and katsus here, as that is what I think they do best.  Beef curry is my favorite here.
author: Mark M.

description:
I was in SF with a hankering for sashimi and -- of course -- turned to Yelp for advice.  Dojima-Ann was a block from my Parc 55 Hotel and had pretty good reviews so I strolled over.  The place is small, about 40 seats, but clean and comfortable.  The service was perfect.  There when you need them;  gone when you don't.  

I started out with a sashimi (Maguro) appetizer and was very pleased to be served five quite large (and thick) planks of maguro.  After the appetizer I wondered how much room I'd have for a meal and decided to go ala carte with a bowl of soup.  I'd read the raves about their Udon noodle soup and chose the curry beef.   Outstanding!  And a HUGE portion chock full of noodles, beef and some veggies.  The bowl was seriously the size of Bruce Bochy's baseball cap.  

Needless to say there was no third course.  The appetizer and the soup had me stuffed and satisfied.  The whole meal, with two glasses of chardonnay, tax and a generous tip came to under forty bucks, which I consider quite reasonable in downtown SF.

I'll be back ...
author: Tim O.

description:
I'm sitting at Dojima-Ann right now at the counter.  Service is strange.  The person who sat at the counter next to me has gotten a chance to order and he's actually gotten his food already and I haven't been asked if I've been helped.

It's only courtesy to go in some kind of logical order where the person who came first gets served before someone who comes later?  I know everyone is busy all the time and it's hard to keep track, but really?

Give me a break.

I had to stop the waitress from helping someone else who actually sat next to me to get my order in.  Ok, I'm leaving.
author: Peter K.

description: The nabeyaki udon is excellent! The maguro sashimi is fresh and tasty. Service is a little spotty.
author: Noriel A.

description:
I came here for dinner with a friend before we went to watch the 'Maple and Vine' play last Saturday. She choose this place because of the reviews. The place is small and cramped. It was busy so good thing that we were able to get a seat.

We weren't ready to order so we asked the waitress to give us a few minutes. After a few minutes later, she asked 'can I take your order yet'? I understand that they were busy but it came off the wrong way to me so she sounded a bit rude. My friend ordered one of the specials for the day with salad and I got the tempura udon bowl.

When our food arrived, my friend had to ask about her salad since they forgot. Their salad was fresh unlike the normal salad you get a Japanese restaurants. I don't think I would order the tempura udon bowl again. Normally, the tempura is off to the side but they put the tempura in the hot udon soup. So during my meal, the tempura became soggy and was sliding off. Later on, it just didn't become appetizing. My friend was okay with her dish as well.

I don't think I'll be coming back here anytime soon.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Ordered Katsu Donburi Set, which means it came with udon. 

Service was okay. When they served the food, they pinned me into the wall so the food can be properly placed on the table. Sorta funny actually. 
Otherwise food was served promptly. 

As for the food, we had udon was good. Nothing too special about it, but nothing negative to say about it either. As for the katsu donburi the ton katsu was really good and had great flavor. Was not crispy, but juicy. Gotta say I didn't care for the raw egg on top. But didn't really take away from the dish either. The rice underneath was whatever. It's rice. 

Note my cousin hyped this restaurant up as the most amazing thing I'll ever eat. After looking at the menu he told me I can only order one thing.

I wanna give it a 4 star review, but just can't go above 3.
author: Howah L.

description: Dojima-Ann is where I head when I'm craving Japanese comfort food. My faves are tonkatsu curry, katsu don, gyu don, and the 2 item bento box consisting of salmon teriyaki and chicken karaage. The service is friendly and the ladies who work there are always sweet. There is usually a wait during peak lunch and dinner hours, but it's always Japanese people, an excellent sign for a Japanese restaurant.
author: Kevin C.

description:
This place is conveniently located near Union Square, so I stopped by for lunch with my brother and sister. There was also a line forming already, so I thought it must be good. The place is actually a lot smaller than it looks and all the tables are placed REALLY CLOSE together. Overall, I think the food is decent, but the service needs some work.

What I ordered:
- Niku Udon Set: The set comes with the teriyaki fish rice. The niku udon is decent. It's nothing fancy and similar to other ones I've tried. The teriyaki sauce is a bit too sweet for my taste. The set price is a good value for the amount of food you get.
- Beef Curry: It's pretty good except there isn't enough rice. This came with a salad.

* I did notice that the side of my udon bowl was a little crusty....they need to do a better job of washing their bowls.

Service:
Like other reviewers said, the service isn't great. The waitresses aren't friendly, and barely noticed me when I tried to get their attention.
author: Judy L.

description:
If you are craving for Japanese food other than raw fish, this is the place for you! Here are some must-try items:
Kaarage Don (Deep fried chicken over rice)
Croquette Curry Rice
Chicken Curry Rice

How convenient its location is near Union Square!
author: Spicy G.

description: I've been here many times and it is a solid place for udon and donburi. I've never had any of the sushi or sashimi as I don't think that is their thing. Reading the other reviews, that seems to be the case. It is a great place to stop for lunch or dinner when you are in the Union Square area and are looking for something casual but good. However, there is often a long wait for dinner.
author: Jessie L.

description: Good for the udon and tonkatsu, but don't get the sushi here. Sushi portions are small and mostly just rice.
author: Jin N.

description: Used to be a good and authentic Japanese restaurant in downtown area and one of my favorite. But recently the food quality is getting worse. Tempura shrimp is small and not fresh. Aji fry is totally out of shape. Even chicken cutlet today is small and meatless. It's the 3rd time I'm disappointed by the poor quality and quantity this year, which makes me don't wanna come back again.
author: Kai-wing B.

description:
Welcome lunch for Amy! Service sucks....45 min wait and only 2 out of 6 people got their food...

Came here thinking this was a ramen place lol. The lunch deals are what you come here for but be warned sometimes it could take awhile as we had a big group and I think maybe only half of us got our order while the other half continued to wait like over 20 min more. The lunch deal is a good portion - I think i had the soba? It was hearty and decent. 

Kind of a trek to get here from our office so most likely not going to venture out here often
author: Christine W.

description:
I'm here definitely more than once during my trips to San Fran. 

The sushi rolls are always on point! The rice is never dry, and every ingredient is always fresh. Kudos. 

The quality of the Katsu Don was the best I've ever had.  Of course there are your typical small Jap joints that serve Katsu Don for cheap...still good but not as good of quality which you can obviously tell. 

The bento boxes are my favorite I must say.  The plating is beautiful and everything is again, super fresh.  Goodness of the california rolls, with the perfectly grilled meat, well balanced salad, all plated perfectly. LOVE IT.

The only downside is the space. I understand that in general Asian people tend to portion everything, make everything a lot smaller but C'MON! more space = more customers! I'm not a big girl but hey I like my space. I don't like it when people are all up in my bubble...especially when I'm eating.

Other than that 4 stars and a happy dance from me! =)
author: Deborah K.

description: One of the best nigiri sushi I've had in a long time! The maguro and Unagi nigiri was amazing! Also, their don-buris are one of the best I've ever had!
author: Bobby C.

description:
I had my doubts about this place since I find most restaurants around the Union Square area to be lacklustre.  My husband was craving Japanese and on a rainy night, a bowl of hot udon noodles sounded good to me.  There was a bit of a line up so we waited for about 15 minutes which wasn't too bad.  It's a small restaurant but turnover is fast.

The chicken udon soup bowl I had was delicious and my husband enjoyed his unagi don.  Service was quick and efficient.  Overall a great Japanese restaurant in the area.
author: Tanya N.

description: Had a late lunch so we weren't hungry until late, at about 8:30pm.  Since we just wanted a quick bite to eat within walking distance of the hotel, we stumbled upon this Japanese restaurant.  It looked crowded so figured it must be good.  It was ok.  I had shrimp tempera udon noodles - hit the spot on a cold chilly night in late June.  I think hubby enjoyed his bluefin tuna collar more.  He also had sashimi which he enjoyed.  Decor looks alittle run-down; slight language problem with the staff.
author: Aly Y.

description: Decent food but very rude staff.  Unfriendly,  sad looking crew that is always miserable when I come here to eat.
author: Jack T.

description: Came here on a friday for a late lunch. Ordered the seaweed udon and raw tuna with avocado sushi roll. Food tasted good, waitresses were polite, and freshness was decent. However, price and uniqueness were not impressive, meaning that I didn't feel the special oomph factor that set this restaurant apart. And, they nearly forgot my sushi roll order. In fact, I finished my udon and a waitress was about to give me my bill when she realized I had not gotten my second order yet. Overall, an average 3 stars.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
Awful!

I have never had worse Sushi in my entire life.

To begin with the Miso was a little strange tasting with something like breadcrumbs in it. Strange I can deal with because all Miso is different, but they gave me a spoon for it. A SPOON! C'mon people it's Miso.

Then I actually got the Spider Roll. Ugh, ick, ack, gag. First off it had lettuce and carrots in it. Which I have never found in Spider Roll's before. Then add that to no sprouts, no sauce and really small amounts of horrible tasting crab and you can see why I almost got up and walked out. It was bland and tasteless and way worse than the Mall sushi I had a few weeks ago.

You know it's bad when you'd rather have mall sushi.

I will never be back.
author: Meg T.

description:
Nice place, nothing spectacular. Service was good and overall the selection is pretty average.
There was a slight problem with the oyaka-don that we ordered but they fixed it quickly and the meal was enjoyable overall!
author: Jessica S.

description: Bad was waiting for 25 minutes on a Monday. Good was the $6 Asahi black specials and the above average huge sashimi Moriawase. Soup was great and salad also above average. Great meal, would eat here again, and out for $40 with the sashimi and two beers, can you go wrong????
author: Lauren C.

description: Grabbed take-out here on a Sunday in June. There was a wait  for a table when we arrived but this place was good 10 years ago and the Yelp reviews were high, so we just ordered to-go from the online menu. The (owner?) at the register seemed stressed and was curt with me. Not sure he had an easier buck, I knew what I wanted, had ordered ahead, was in and out. Didn't appreciate the attitude. Seemed cheap to feed four people dinner, under $50. The food was good for fast-fare. It's all donburi, any and every kind of protein over sushi rice. Not sure I would bother eating in, I don't appreciate attitude for any reason.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Yelp says that 3 stars means "Yay I'm a fan".  Looking at other reviews, I think that some people are not aware of the definition of the star ratings.  I'm sorry but I can not say that I am a fan.  First of all, I went to this place as a second choice.  The first choice was very busy and could not get in.  It was about 4PM on Sunday afternoon.  Anyhow, we were quickly seated down by someone pointing us the direction to our table to seat our selves..  It was a late lunch for us so we ordered just one entree each.  My friend ordered a bento box which looked not bad and I ordered Tekka Don which is Tuna over Rice. 

I agree with another Yelp reviewer that the Tuna was thin and stringy. The price for Tekka Don was $13.95 which is OK only if the Tuna is better.

I needed to use the restroom and I was disgusted.  This is not a restroom that I believe a local Japanese restaurant owner would have.  After my restroom experience and looking around, I noticed that this must not be run by Japanese (I may be wrong).  I have noticed this before in other restaurants.  I don't want to go into detail but...  you might know what I am talking about.  Don't be surprised if full dirty bus trays are left on tables next to you while you dine.

I will not be coming back to this place because they are passing it on on to what it is not.  This is only my opinion and make it yours once you experience.

Please go to an authentic Japanese restaurant and receive not only what you pay for but what you receive.

Thank you and best regards.
author: Don J.

description: Not satisfied!!! I've ordered bento box.. It's supposed to come with rice and miso soup!! I didn't get the miso, they just forgot to bring it!! I was waiting for my credit card for 10 min...!! I didn't rated 1 star because food was normal..!!
author: Kateryna D.

description: The food is good, but it's pricey for the portions, I guess because it's downtown.  Sea food is fresh.  It's a very busy place with a wait list.
author: Maria T.

description:
Finally got to check this place out over the weekend.  The wait wasn't too busy on a Saturday night, so we got a table in like 10 minutes, though normally you would have to wait longer.

I ordered a salmon donburi.  Though I did question how quickly the donburi was made with a full house, it actually wasn't too bad in terms of quality.  Service was a-okay, prices are reasonable for dinner.

In general, the place isn't spectacular and exciting, but they do what they do, and it's perfectly fine.
author: Ren L.

description: You may have to wait a while, but the wait is worth the fairly priced, authentic Japanese dishes they serve here. Its almost like walking into a Yoshinoya minus the tickets. Last time I went, I was seated under the ac vent and got pretty cold so remember to bring a sweater. I will definitely go back for my next udon fix.
author: Dexter K.

description:
Came here on a Friday night in the city. I had heard stories of sushi places in SF getting crowded even on off-nights, but luckily arrived just before the crowd.
A bit crowded, as the place is quite small, but not a big deal by any means. The service was pretty good: they didn't leave us for 20 minutes before taking our order, I got my water refilled, the usual. We each ended up getting the sets - consisting of a noodle dish and a rice dish. My girlfriend got the cold noodles - tempura set, and I had the udon - donburi set. They were really good, and the best part was that dinner for 2 came out to about $25! Crazy deal, especially in the city.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Party of 3 came here on 12/30/09 at 7:30 to be greeted by a line out the door. Really, that many people want udon and curry tonight? We decided to be patient and wait because there really wasn't anything else around. 

The space is tiny and you won't have too much elbow room but we were lucky and were seated at a booth near the back.  We had the standard fare, udon and curry. The curry croquette was o.k. it just needed some flavor so I ate it with a lot of the ginger to give it extra flavor. It actually tasted better the next day. The udon was good but wasn't anything to write home about. 

We tried to chat but our waitress polited told us we had to scoot as there was still a line outside at 9:45pm when we left and she needed to seat those hungry folks. This is an eat and go establishment, don't expect this to be a place you can linger and chat with your friends after your meal.
author: Betty C.

description:
What a great find!  My boss has eaten here several times and introduced me to Dojima-Ann when we dined there together.  He even had a plan for what we should order, so I graciously  let him take the lead.  I played my part by selecting the sake. 

We started off with the shrimp and vegetable tempura and a plate of cold soba noodles.  I loved how the noodles came with a small speckled quail's egg to crack over the noodles!  The tempura was light and crispy, and the shrimp were massive.  The noodles were simple and nicely cooked.  Everything worked really well with the dipping sauce.

Following these as an appetizer, we ordered one of the specials - grilled tuna collar, or hamachi kama. Essentially, this is the part of the fish that is harvested after the head is chopped off.  It's the region right behind the gills.  My boss referred to it as "seagull's food" because you have to pick at it with your chopsticks to get all the tasty bits out  And, BOY was it tasty!  To me, some of the meat tasted sweeter in some areas of the collar than others.

Be forewarned, this place is not very big but is very busy (and with good reason).  Venture a bit off the beaten path (i.e. eat stuff besides sushi and udon), and you'll be pleasantly surprised!
author: Christine G.

description:
This place was PACKED on a late, Wednesday night. I'm glad we stumbled across is in our touristy wandering around SF.

I decided what I wanted to eat when walking past all the rest of the patrons and spying on their food. So many people had the large, steaming cauldron of Nabe Yaki Udon that I knew it's what I had to have. The table next to us also had the tempura appetizer and it's been so long since I had tempura that I was lured in. The boyfriend ordered the special, which was a bowl of tanuki udon (crispy tempura bits), and a bowl of pork katsu over rice.

The nabe yaki literally arrives in a cast iron cauldron which you're cautioned not to touch. There is a raw egg dropped in the top which is perfectly cooked by the time it arrives at your table. I popped the yolky goodness and stirred it into the udon. The broth is not as rich as other places I've been, but what it lacked in bone-broth flavor, it made up in accompaniments: tempura shrimp, tempura crispies, sliced fish cake, shredded seaweed, and slices of chicken.

The tempura appetizer was excellently crispy and satisfied my need for deep fried happiness. It came with two shrimp, a couple of green beans, a slice of eggplant, mountain potato or boniato, yam and broccoli. The dipping sauce had freshly grated ginger in it.

The tables around us also had sushi, which looked pretty, but it was chilly enough outside for us to stick to the boiling liquids. The flavors were not complexly layered in any of the dishes, but it was solid and well-portioned for the price.
author: Julie C.

description:
I really want to love this place, I really do, but the 3 times that I was here the food didn't convince me to give it a 4 star.

It's a good lunch place, the price is ok, $12 something for a set of donburi and udon (they have 3 sets like this) is really a bargain in downtown SF. The chicken and egg donburi is only $8 something. The 6 piece classic sushi rolls are around $6 and up. 

However, it only gets 3 stars from me because the two times I had their rice bowls (first time the unagi don and beef udon set, second time the chicken and egg donburi) they left a weird taste in my mouth, I believe it's the taste of MSG? They tasted great but that weird aftertaste made me feel like I ate something bad.  The third time I had their sushi roll (rock and roll and hamachi roll). The size of the rolls were ok, but the rice was very mushy, and a bit on the sour side. Not sure if it's just a mistake on that day or what.

Having been here for 3 times I feel that I can give it a fair assessment, which is you don't need to go all the way out here to try this place. Not worth your time. But if you happen to be around the area for lunch, you can give it a try if the line isn't long.
author: Peggy M.

description:
Thankfully I pre-Yelped and knew to avoid the sushi.  In such a ramen-focused era, it was nice to see a large Udon and Soba menu.  I wasn't overly impressed with any one dish, but the soups were good and worth exploring more of the menu for a winner later on.

Gyoza: Typical.  Mild minced meat inside.  Steamed on one side, pan fried on the other.  The dipping sauce was colder than room temperature which put a damper on the normally steamy experience.

Tori Karaage: It feels like they're cheating!  They took larger pieces of chicken, deep fried them and then sliced them.  I was definitely missing out on some the normal crispy surface area.  Also, their mayo was so miserly dabbed on that it was gone after the first piece.

Niku Udon: Low on ingredients (beef & onion), but high on taste.  Maybe its the pho lover in me, but beef makes such a savory soup base.

Nabe Yaki Udon: Bland soup base, but almost everything in the house thrown in.  Very thinly sliced fish cake yielded subtle bites that weren't too fishy.  The raw egg was a nice touch, but I felt rushed to eat it before it solidified.  Way too much cabbage, I know it is cheap and all, but not the best thing en masse in a soup.  The chicken bits were hard and dense, probably boiled too long.  The one shrimp tempura dropped tasty fried batter bits into the soup as I let it seep which helped evolve the soup over time.
author: Adam B.

description: I had Shrimp fried curry. It was so-so-good.  I love to go back and try Udon next time.
author: Yaeko M.

description:
I had friends of mine from out of town spend the day in SF doing all the touristy things (Fisherman's Wharf, Pier 39, Ghiradelli Square, riding cable cars, etc). Since I didn't have a preference, my friends chose this place for dinner in Union Square based on the positive Yelp reviews. I took the Caltrain and walked the ~15 minute trek to Union Square. Note to self: always bring a warm jacket. It unexpectedly started to drizzle and my track jacket wasn't quite enough.

I arrived at Dojima around 7:10 p.m. and the place was full. It's not a huge place to begin with so it can fill up pretty quickly. Since some patrons come in to grab a quick meal and head out, we were able to get seats within 5 minutes. Given that it was chilly outside, I opted for the Udon (with Beef and Onion). The hot soup broth really hit the spot and I was pleasantly surprised to find the generous portions of beef in my dish. I also ordered the hamachi roll, which was only around  $5 for 6 pieces.

Overall, the value was good as I was expecting to spend more $ for dinner. Most udons are only $8 to $10. So for less than $15, I admit I was pretty full. The service was quick and attentive and while some hungry guests were waiting for a table, the wait staff did not rush us in any way. 
  
The restaurant is one block away from the O'Farrell/Ellis Parking Garage in the heart of Union Square, which makes it a convenient and easy place to find.
author: Chris L.

description:
I've eaten at the place twice before and was always satisfied especially with the food.  We decided to eat here again because of the food and we were in the area.  

We walked in and it was semi busy but there were three servers and we were not greeted immediately.  I looked around to see that there were no tables available to fit 3 people because they sat couples at 4 seating tables...I questioned that because why would you seat 2 at a 4 person table when there were clearly tables for 2 open.  So we decided to just take the bar, which we voluntarily took on our own.

It took the servers a while to take our order...at this point I was quite irritated but tried to ignore it.  When the food finally came I forgot all about the service and paid the bill.

I am going to admit, I did not tip the 10% because I did not think they deserved it.  I tip based on service and not because the food is good.  Here is the good part...the waitress came back to me with the bill and TOLD me you have to give $2 more tip.  I looked at her and said "oh so you tell your customers what they should tip you".  She said no but you have to pay 10%.  I said "well your telling me now to give you $2 more, so you do tell the customers what they should tip".  She said no we don't but if you want to leave it the way it is than it is ok.  

I was shocked and gave her an evil laugh and shook my head and said I can't believe you just did that and left.

NO STARS - for service
2 stars - ONLY FOR THE FOOD.
author: Zsheron I.

description:
Not a local of San Fran, I was back in town for business after a few years and staying at the Hotel Nikko. Walking back from the convention center, i was stopped first by the plastic food in the window, a welcome site for an american who loved his time as an expat in Japan 10 years ago.  

I went in and it felt just like home. I ended up eating there 3 times over the course of 4 days. Day 1 was the novelty that is o-nigiri. Very tasty, good rice, nice amount of salmon (although I was kind of hoping for a little mayo mixed in) and followed it up with their sushi platter and a large Asahi super dry. The Sushi was good and fresh and being from Michigan, the pricing did not seem outrageous to me.  

Day 2 I walked in, they remembered me and asked right away if i wanted another beer! Yes! I ordered some pieces and it was great. It was also very comfortable to be surrounded by a lot of asians. 

Day 4 of my trip, they sat me with a beer (clutch). I had the tori karaage and it was as good as I remember eating it in small bars in Japan.  Overall very comforting. Not high on appearance or presentation, but all the food was simple, fresh and very tasty
author: Todd M.

description: I don't  remember the the name of the sushi roll I ordered here, all I remember that it was very flavorless and I didn't like it. Wasn't worth what I spent on it. The service was ok though. Probably won't be back.
author: Joselyn G.

description:
I'm so mad at myself for staying but it was raining outside and it looks like I was desperate.

We waited for about 25 minutes with no acknowledgement from the manager or a server but were walked past numerous times. It's a small room so I guess there's an understanding that the next table is yours but a simple, "30 minute wait" would suffice people!!!

There was a woman behind us who waited for about 2 minutes and left in a huff because she wasn't acknowledged. 

There were 2 4-tops opening up at the same time, but instead of seating us right away since we were the next people up, the servers and manager instead waited for another smaller table to open up, then sat us and keeping the group of 3 behind us waiting. During all that though, not a word. I'm not familiar with the ways of a Japanese restaurant patron in San Francisco, but where I come from, you open your mouth and SAY SOMETHING!

We sat down with our menus in our hands ready to go and luckily our server accommodated us quickly. I had the bento box with salmon teriyaki and veggie tempura and he had the unagi don. I've got to say though, for the craptastic service, the unagi don looked fantastic. The salmon was dry and overcooked and the wasabi I asked for on the side was watered down if there could be such a thing. My favorite part of the meal-the miso soup had freeze dried tofu in it which spoiled it for me. 

The only part of the experience that was quick was the honorable paying of the bill. Anything to get us out of the door so they can make another quick buck I guess 'cause I certainly won't come back.
author: Jessica K.

description: Seems to be very popular. You need to wait for a table but it's worth it. Great food.
author: Pawel L.

description: Really good food in Union Square. After some serious shopping my sister-in-law and I found this little gem. It was packed and we had great service. We ordered sushi, beef teriyaki, miso and some edamame. We enjoyed everything, I would definitely go back!
author: Chelsea H.

description: The onigiri was extremely disappointing. There was two big pieces per serving, but each one had such a tiny little amount of salmon in it and no bonito or anything either. The rice was still warm, but they didn't have to be so stingy on the salmon. I had the potato croquettes in curry sauce over rice was great. The potato croquettes had curry spice in it too, which I was hoping for. The curry texture was smooth and it tasted not too mild. There was also some pickled radish on the side. It came with a side salad with a housemade ginger miso dressing. The curry udon was like the same thing, except the curry was slightly thinner and the udon looked incredibly chewy and bouncy. If I had a bigger appetite next time, I'd get the donburi/udon combo.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Found this gem on our way to catch our flight. Very good. We only got some salmon and tuna nigiri, but the fish was so fresh and was like butter.
author: Kerri S.

description: My family and I have been going to this place for years. Great prices! We really enjoy the variety of sushi they have and they have the best miso we've ever had so far.
author: Mia K.

description: Order the spicy tuna sushi, it was great! Seating is limited, but we had a party of 7, so we had to wait 30 minutes or so but finally got a table. Well worth the wait.
author: Dan B.

description: I forgot exactly what I ordered, but the waitress was extremely impatient with us. I wasn't overly impressed with the food nor with the service. Combine the two and that makes for a bad experience. I wouldn't come back to eat here again.
author: David C.

description:
This review was for the bad first impression. Thanks Yelp for recommending this tiny-small space without the heads up! 

So we were in the Westfield Shopping Center, when we were craving for Sushi for dinner. We've never really had any in the area other than the one in the food court. So I decided to look one up walking distance in the area on Yelp. Dojima-Ann came up with good reviews, and for pricing. My boyfriend is a SF local, but I'm from the East-bay, and we met up with his brothers who are from SF, and our kids. So we did need to accommodate for a larger group....When we arrived to Dojima-Ann we were a little disappointed to find it quite small. 

A lady welcomed us, but tried to split our group in 1/2, which we did have 4 little kids with us, and 4 adults. My boyfriend is stationed in Hawaii, so he hasn't seen his family in over a year...So breaking our group into 2 tables across the room from each other wasn't going to workout for us. We asked the male hostess, who seems like he would've been the owner if he can maybe try to accommodate us somehow, and even if we came back in 15 mins. He said NO we don't hold tables, and wasn't really trying to work with our situation, came across somewhat rude. So we decided to leave, and instead we went around the corner to Hana Zen...Yes, it was a little more pricier, but we got what we paid for. They had no problem accommodating our group, and Sushi was fresh. A great experience! 

Will we ever try to dine at Dojima-Ann again...I think not!
author: Leah B.

description:
On this trip home, the guy really made it a point to catch up with old friends.  So after work 1 day, I met up with him & we went to have dinner with his friend & his wife.

He got a Wakame udon that was small (he does eat like a family of 4) & did not have a lot of wakame.  I got a Kitsuni udon which was a good size for me.  I've never had it before so I wasn't expecting the tofu skin to be so sweet.

Our meal of 2 udons + 4 rolls + 2 drinks came out to $71 which is slightly pricey but understandable given the prime location.
author: Karen S.

description:
All around authentic Japanese food.  They have decent sushi, donburi, bento box sets, and of course bottles of Shochu.

Good for lunch and dinner.
author: HY L.

description: Can't comment on the food since I never got an opportunity to order today. After entering this place I got waved toward a dirty table then got ignored from that point on. No menu was given, the table next to me got cleaned but not mine. When they brought drinks to a group of people who got there after me, I decided to leave. I used to go there very often a while ago and the tonkatsu curry was very decent back then. Today, the only thing I can comment about  is the level of disrespect the staff displayed toward me and it was shamefully high. Won't go there anymore.
author: fabrice a.

description: Small place that fills up quickly during lunch.  The food was good but it was too cramped for my liking.  I need some elbow room for my sashimi.
author: Brent T.

description: My go to place for KatsuDon with running eggs + udon !!! It never fails.
author: DANIEL T.

description: Stopped by for lunch after an exhausting business meeting in the city. After wandering around downtown I stumbled across this place and decided to give it a try. Two of my colleagues joined me and we were seated quickly. The food was delicious although the service left much to be desired. A simple smile goes a long way...The price was just right for a simple bento box. The sushi was fresh and the teriyaki was delicious. I'd go again, but not for any special occasion.
author: Roderick S.

description: Ate here twice: first time I got the Tamagotoji and it was excellent. The second time I got the rainbow roll which made me sick (literally, weird stomach ache several hours later).  The fish smelled old but I still ate it like an idiot.  I think they gave me left over food! Not coming back here.
author: josh d.

description: Was starving so there's not much this place could have done to not have met my expectations. The Soba was delicious and the service was fast and cordial. I would recommend this place to anyone. The rice ball was da bomb suckas!
author: Alexander L.

description:
I totally agree with Toro E.  Their Udon tastes like frozen/ fresh packaged Udon sold at Japanese markets.  I do think they are Kansai (western Japan where Osaka is) style though...  Kansai style has less soy sauce flavor and more Dashi (fish broth) flavor than Kanto (east Japan where Tokyo is).  I can make better Udon at home with my own broth, but Dojima-Ann is handy when I'm near Union Square.  Also I am very happy that they have extended lunch hour which ends at 5pm (I usually eat lunch after 2pm...) . 

For Katsudon, they are too sweet for me.  Kansai/Osaka style usually uses more sugar and/or Mirin (sweet cooking rice wine) in their cooking.  I like Edomae (Tokyo downtown style) better for Katsudon.

For me, good Katsudon have to have 
1. Rice have be on the hard side.  Not too wet to accommodate the moisture from the broth.
2. Katsu have to be freshly fried.
3. Pork have to be thick enough but not hard nor dry.
4. Sliced onions have to be cooked just enough in the broth before adding Katsu.
5. Eggs have to be still soft and not cooked all the way through.
6. Mistuba or Negi (Japanese green onions) on top
7. Have to be served with Misoshiru (miso soup) or Suimono (simple fish broth soup) and Tsukemono (Japanese pickles) .  PLEASE do not call Misoshiru (Miso soup)- Miso.  Miso is soy bean past used to make Miso soup.  It's like calling clam chowder -clam or calling tomato soup -tomato.  Miso is a name of paste not a soup!

Dojima-Ann's Katsudon is not bad and they do come with Misoshiru and Tsukemono but I like Katsudon at Sakana (lunch menu) and Katanaya better.  (they are less sweet and they use better pork but not served with Stukemono...)
author: Chie J.

description:
Came here yesterday with a friend for lunch. It was a tiny place, but we got seated quickly.

Staff is friendly and accommodating. We both got the rice bowl special (with mini udon for $2 more) and I was NOT disappointed. I got the donkatsu bowl and was surprised at first when the egg wasn't fully cooked. But as I continued eating I was pleasantly surprised at how all the flavors and textures mixed together to a tasty treat.

I will definitely be going back and trying new things!

The only con I could think of is that you're RIGHTNEXTTO the people around you. Not ideal for private, deep conversations, but good for a quick meal with a pal.
author: Becky K.

description:
Of all the fabulous places one can dine in the culinary rich city, I ate at this little hole-in-the-wall Japanese restaurant near my hotel twice when I visited San Francisco from Los Angeles! As usual, I was totally craving the taste of home after being away from home for a week!

Dojima Ann, located a few blocks from the hustle and bustle of Union Square, is not just a little friendly Japanese noodle shop but an oasis for any Japanese or Japanese-food loving travelers tired of dining at fancy restaurants and just want simple, down-home cooking (the place was packed with those appeared to be Japanese tourists). What is so pleasantly surprising about this place is that despite its location, it offers many authentic, Osaka-style dishes that you would only expect in Asian enclave.

I ordered a bowl of Daikon Oroshi Udon, a cold udon noodle with grated Japanese radish, quail egg, fish cake, scallion and root vegetables (pictured above), served with dipping sauce, and a side of hamachi (yellowtail) cut roll to calm my Japanese food craving.  They were both so darn tasty!

I will definitely be back here the next time I'm in SF!
author: Hirono S.

description:
This place isn't really that bad.  I figure if a restaurant is in downtown San Francisco, it would be pricey, lower quality, and portions would be small.  It was the total opposite.  Portions of the sashimi was good, fresh, and decent quality.  It's not Ino, kiss, kabuto, or miyaki quality but more like a taraval okazuya, sushi sam's, and ebisu.

The restaurant itself is nothing to really talk about.  Pretty boring.  But........if you happen to be in downtown and yearning for some decent sushi at an affordable price then this your place.  I also saw a lot of people sluping up some good udon soup noodles.  I just wasn't in the mood.  If Manabu M. says there udon is good.................it's good.

Try the halibut, salmon, maguro sashimi.   The rolls are pretty decent but the California roll threw me for a loop.  I know.........why the hell am I ordering California roll at a Japanese restaurant.  Answer...........I can't help it.  I just need to.  Damn it!!!  They didn't chop up the imitation crab.
author: jason g.

description: Food is great. However, a little too expensive and service is slow. Our server and the staff we interacted with were very nice, but even with a small number of tables in the restaurant the service is not up to par. I loved their sushi, but I'm afraid I will not be returning to Dojima-Ann.  Also, it was very hot inside the restaurant which is never good.
author: Chucky H.

description:
About nine years ago when I moved to the States from Japan, my brother and I came upon this place by happenstance.   It was seriously our first Japanese restaurant experience that made us nostalgic for Japan.  Sadly, we forgot where this place was located and gave up on trying to find it.  If there ever was a holy grail for restaurants, this was it for us.    

Flash forward to last year, I drive by this place by chance, take out my iPhone and bookmark it on the Yelp app.  When I come back with much anticipation, I discover that it has maintained that yummy Japanese deliciousness of home.  

The location is fairly small which is fairly reminiscent of restaurants in Japan.  You could very well be sitting at a table awkwardly close to some couple trying to go on a date.  Just accept the awkwardness - it's a pretty awesome set up.  The service here is spot on, and some of the staff seem to understand Japanese.   

This place excels in great Japanese comfort food.  I would actually just skip the sushi here (which I'm assuming they just have on the menu because everybody here is so obsessed with it here).     

My favorite thing at this place is the curry udon, which I think is kind of a rare find in Japanese restaurants in the States.  The other udon bowls here have a great balance in the broth and even the texture of the noodles. 

I also love the curry here.  You just can't lose with Tonkatsu curry, especially on a cold yay area day.   

The pricing is pretty decent considering the location.   It's my official place that I have to eat at whenever I'm visiting the bay now.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Sometimes I wonder how some businesses have gotten so big-headed that they don't even care about their customers. This is Dojima-Ann. 

I was so excited to try this place and when I walked in for lunch with my mom, she told me we actually ate here once about 10 years ago with my cousin. My mom was getting giddy because the food we had last time was really good. She still remembered it and it was 10 years ago!

My mom had the tanin donburi which was beef, egg, and onions over rice. I wanted the unagi tororo don. But instead, I accidentally ordered the unagi donburi. When I asked the waitress (let's call her Waitress A) if the unagi donburi came with egg, she said yes when obviously it didn't. She could have told me that if I wanted egg, I needed to order the unagi tororo don. But she didn't. When our food came I asked the waitress (not my original waitress so we'll call her Waitress B) why my order didn't have an egg, she said I ordered the unagi donburi which doesn't come with egg. I told her that Waitress A told me it did. She went over to Waitress A who then told her I ordered the unagi donburi. I asked Waitress B if they could just add an egg to my dish and she said no but I could just order the unagi tororo don. Really?! Order another rice bowl for 2 people? Waitress B leaves and a few minutes later Waitress C comes over and asked me if there were any problems. I explained to her what happened and she had to go to Waitress A to talk to her about it. She returned with the same answer: you can order the unagi tororo don or just eat the unagi donburi. 

Waitress A never came to talk to me when it was her who took my order. WTH?! Why didn't she just come over instead of playing telephone with the other waitresses?? I was so mad and my mom was going crazy. (You know Chinese people resort to yelling in these situations). I did order the wrong dish but the waitress told me it came with an egg. So I was under the impression that my dish came with an egg. I didn't want to be "one of those customers" so I just gave up after trying to explain to two different waitresses that my waitress misinformed me about the dish I was ordering. 

They didn't even try to make the situation better or alleviate my frustration. Our tea was never refilled and they never checked up on us. If you don't care about your customers, that's fine. We won't care to return.
author: Judy H.

description:
For years I've been wanting to come in because every time I walked by it was always packed with Japanese people and other Asians. 

So based on the speed of service, portion size and price point, it's no wonder this place is always packed.  The food won't blow you away but it's solid Japanese comfort food.
author: Roger H.

description: Don't let that line fool you. They're packed because of their location. Location, location, location! That's it! Granted, the sushi is not the worst I've ever had, but it doesn't compete well with the others in the area...or in the city, period! The sushi is okay. Not the freshest cuts, but not bad. The bento boxes are decent, if you're into that sort of thing.
author: Helen L.

description:
A worker bee like myself (not your typical bee mind you) needs to refuel, recharge, and well re-member what to nourish my stomach and soul with.  

After a busy morning of dropping mom off at the salon, some much needed clothing shopping and other errands, I was in the mood for sushi and poof!  This place came to mind.  3 rolls (tekka, rock & rock, and ca) + a to go order of chicken terriyaki don for my mom, it was a delicious and easy way to feed us.

The genmachi was particular good.  My mom and my tummies were well loved and now taking after lunch naps.   Arigato!
author: Jen L.

description: My favorite Japanese restaurant in SF seems to always be busy with locals and tourists.  Their version of Oyako Donburi, a seemingly easy dish, is the best I have ever had, with the egg not overcooked like many restaurants.
author: Dennis C.

description: What a great place to grab a quick lunch.  I would suggest trying the tori toji udon noodles (chicken + egg).  The uni here is also delicious.
author: Alex B.

description: Lousy Japanese food I ate the whole 4 weeks in SF... Overcooked soba, soup tasteless and chicken cubes from freezer or something. I won't go there again.
author: Stephen C.

description: I ordered Unagi Don and Sweet Shrimp Sushi. The unagi was tender, savory sweet and melted in my mouth. Yummm! The sushi was excellent as well. A nice, informal place to escape to during lunch and dinner. Reminded me of my visits to Tokyo when I would duck into similar eateries for lunch. I will definitely keep coming back to this one!
author: Nat V.

description:
I don't know why everyone gets udon here, but it's definitely not their forte, IMO. I prefer the hand written specials listed at the door, generally they're served in a bento style plate with some appetizers. My favorite special (which I hope they will have again soon!) was the fried tails of hamachi. Similar to a hamachi collar, the meat is plentiful and perfectly salted by the sea. Paired with a little salad and some miso soup, perfect.

Cozy restaurant, good food, not too busy usually, despite it's prime location in union square.
author: Alex R.

description:
When I'm shopping downtown and I want a decently priced and convenient place to eat I always come here.

I usually never have to wait in a line and the udon is decent enough. Plus it's smack dab located in between Macy's and Westfield!

So I admit it's not the best Japanese restaurant but when in downtown and not wanting to spend 20 some dollars and to not stray too far away from the market street muni transportation? But where your choices are a selection of Thai, Italian, Pizza, Hot Dog or Fast Food???
...I definitely recommend this place.
author: Michelle L.

description:
When in doubt, I'm always at Dojima-Ann. It's just that when almost half of the sushi joints in the downtown area are all shi-shi and far from where I work, I make myself walk over here because the rolls are affordable, food is decent, and it's just a nice place to be in. 

It's pretty much a tourist magnet since it's on the outskirts of Union Square and H&M (ha!), but I really just like coming here when I eat lunch alone because most of the people who go there eat lunch by themselves, too. It's like our own personal hang out.

But as for the food, I really do enjoy their version of the 49er roll, which has shrimp tempura in it. Love it! Also if and when I do order entrees from the lunch or dinner menu, I love that there's always some great bento deal or whatnot served with miso. Almost everything comes with miso. The one thing I would most definitely stay away from: the Rainbow Roll. Not. Good. Their tempura is always delish, and I always found it interesting that they served their tempura over rice with the sauce on it already. Saves dipping time, I suppose. 

The staff is always nice and friendly, which is also something noticeable. I actually sat at the bar one time (Which I have to say, was not pleasant because I was right near the drink case and radio nudged in a corner. Suuuucked.), and they were pretty slammed with customers, and the waitresses were working their butts off and still managed to provide me some excellent service. 

All in all: good place to go for lunch, and also if you usually dine by yourself. But don't come here expecting like, THE BEST sushi you've ever tasted. I'd call it enough to satisfy your craving.
author: Caroline L.

description: Muy buena relación calidad-precio. Un sushi y sashimi de sabor excelente.
author: David Q.

description:
I've been coming here since i was in middle school.  This place can get expensive if you order sushi,  but usually i would'nt order it here because there dinners/lunch sets are better value and flavor.  It has been almost two years since the last time i came here,  because my last experience was not too good.  Today,  i decided to give this place another try and it was pretty good.  I ordered katsu curry,  it was $13.50, a little more expensive than usual japanese restaurants,  but the good thing was it comes with a small udon which makes it worth it. My boy friend ordered a niku udon with unagi rice for $12.50. The portions were just right.  
 By the way,  for years my favorite here is the oyako don and still is ,  but tonight i just wanted to try something else.
I would definitly come back for the oyako don.  
Also,  this place seems to open till pretty late,  when i left at 10:15, there was still a lot oa customers there.  One thing i wouldn't get here is the sashimi,  because i think its kinda over price for the portion and quality.  But over all,  this place is pretty good.
author: Toshiko B.

description:
Seriously, this place is a major no no. I like to read reviews on yelp, but never did I write one.. What brought me here?
Here's what happened.
My sister and I were craving Japanese food after going shopping in the city, we randomly stopped by this restaurant. 
However, as soon as the waitress came to us, there was an inevitable feeling of uncomfortableness due to lack of a positive attitude.The Korean waitress was neither friendly, nor helpful even for a slight second. She couldn't even get the basics of being a waitress: not explaining the meal options properly, or doing a simple task of tilting a jar to fill our empty glasses. Although it wasn't great, I didn't give a shit because I had a great shopping spree the whole day. After finishing  our meal, which seemed overprice compared to the lack in quality, I asked for the check. 
When it came to the table, I simply placed my credit card and the waitress took it back to the register. While I was waiting for the return of my card, I wondered how much tip I should leave regardless of the rude behavior of the waitress. When I thought the night was all over and we could go home, the best part approached me along with my credit card: the receipt. The line where I was to write the tip, was already filled in with dark, finely pressed, black ink.
They decided to tip themselves! ...like WTF? 
When I called the same waitress and questioned her about the written in tips, rather than apologizing she said if the other server did not say that the tip could be included, that would be her fault. Unless I have some mental memory problems, I absolutely doubt that I said anything even close to that. Actually, neither did I say anything nor did the other waitress tell me when she took my check, she surely wasn't the "talk to your customer type". Claiming that I said that, she kept defending herself that it would be her fault not herself only if she didn't.
This is when my temper started to rise. Is writing tips in for your customer some kind of new thing that I've missed? Let me just make a point: I am not a stingy tipper, but a waitress that tips herself... Are they evaluating their service quality? Like, "Oh~ I worked hard today, I should get this much tip from her, and this much tip from him and blah blah blah."  
If you neglected to read any of the things I've written above, just read these two sentences.
For your own healthy mind set, don't go to this restaurant. The waitresses are a two second meal ruiner. 

And just in case that girl that calls her waitress reads this, this is my message to you:
Customers evaluate your service, not you. I honestly would have given you much more tip than what you've put down yourself. But doing what you do, and being what you are, you don't deserve a single penny from ME or from anyone else. I guess that you thought of us as tourists because I spoke Korean to you. And you assumed that your services won't matter since I'm only traveling. Well, I'm not a tourist. Here's just a Korean to Korean advice: If customers don't give you tips, you don't write it for them, but fix your fucked up attitude:)   

Definitely be cautious of where you go, and who you are served by.
author: Narae Y.

description:
Dojima Ann has been one of our favorites for over twenty years - going to shop at Union Square and ending up at Dojima Ann with my kids, my parents - everyone had a good time and the curry udon was my wife's go to favorite.

A few years ago we felt, after having been away for a while, that things were slipping and getting run down.  After a several decade run of good food, décor and energy - maybe this was it for Dojima Ann.  But yesterday we stopped in after a day at SFMOMA and Macys and Dojima Ann had the magic back.

The crowd is usually good - the place was packed on Friday after work with the usual mix of European and Asian tourists from all the nearby hotels, especially Japanese tourists from the Nikko practically next door - interspersed with shoppers like us, nice.  The place looks spiffed up, new floors, all the nicks and scratches buffed or painted out, and the kitchen was rocking.  The wait staff was good, attentive; include new lighting and it looks like the improvements all really paid off.

The layout has always been cool, very narrow and unusual in that it has 2 levels about a foot or two in height, apart - this gives a neat perspective to the place which is sort of cosmopolitan Tokyo hip in design - modern, not traditional, no shoji screens, etc.  

The menu is big; I think it's been expanded to include the whole spectrum of Japanese cuisine from sushi to teriyaki.  We had the tsunomono which is unusual for Japanese restaurants here - a sweet vinegary sauce over cucumbers and raw octopus and cooked shrimp with wakame (seaweed), pretty good.  

My wife's curry udon - she loved as did I my curry rice which comes with a salad and small bowl of udon - it was scrumptious.  The curry rice was loaded with thin cut beef, onions and the usual mystery chopped sweet pickle of neon red takuan - it reminded me of dishes I had in Japanese train stations and airports - you can get it most anywhere in Japan.

I hope Dojima Ann can keep it together like this.  The location is unparalleled and the fast urban crowd/environment is paced by the quick city food Dojima Ann makes.  One of our old favorites has been successfully resurrected!

(Groups:  As a review mentioned Dojima Ann is not large group friendly - because of the dividing wall the ability to seat a large group is diminished)
author: Alan O.

description:
Everytime we visit San Francisco--which is actually quite often, we have to eat at Dojima Ann.  We usually end up eating there at least 3 times during our stay.

The food is very good quality and very tasty.  We are from Hawaii where there are tons of Japanese restaurants and Dojima Ann may actually be better than any I've been to back home.

This is not a fancy place.  Small, plain atmosphere, but always busy.  Sometimes we order take out and eat in our hotel room.

Try the Tonkatsu (Pork Cutlet) Donburi-- you will not be disappointed.  I always have a difficult time deciding between this or the Tonkatsu Curry.  9 times out of 10 I go for the Donburi and hope that someone else orders the curry!
author: Joanne N.

description:
This rating is for the TORI (CHICKEN) KARAAGE.

I have been here twice, a year apart, and the quality of this karaage is consistently...perfect.  If you are a tori karaage addict like me, then this is the place for you.  In my estimation, there is a shortage of karaage in the world, but that is still no reason to settle for less than perfect karaage.  This is traditional karaage exactly the way you remembered it in your fondest memories of childhood.  It looks as good as it tastes.  And it is sad when you consume that last morsel.  The batter is light and never oily.  It is the perfect balance of salt, pepper, soy sauce, garlic, ginger, and potato starch that is rarely achieved anywhere else in the Continental United States.  Many establishments simply do not serve it.  The chicken is tender juicy, cooked to perfection without excess fat.  The skin is removed, battered, fried, and served separately for those that are health conscious.  For those that love the skin, it is a nice surprise waiting for you beneath the stack of perfect morsels of tori karaage.  

When I think of San Francisco, I think of Tori Karaage at Dojima-Ann.

Note: The only other place that I can give 5/5 stars for a non-traditional tori karaage is Raku in Las Vegas (review pending).
author: Paul Y.

description: Don't go to this restaurant !! Service was horrible !!!!!!! We got there 25 min before closing, but the restaurant was packed so we didn't think anything about it. Waited 15 min just to give drink order.  We ordered yellow tail sashimi and 2 miso soups. After another 20 min ,Only yellow tail came out had to wait another 5 min just to get servers attention that they didn't bring out the miso soups. 10 min later she brings out 1 soup and tells me she could only bring out one.   ??? Didn't explain.  15 min later there table next to us gets a miso soup.  Very bothered !! asked them why the table next to us got a miso but we didn't response was that they just made another pot.... At closing time. ???
author: C M.

description: Veges not fresh for the udon. Bluefin Kama is good! Spoke to one of the waitresses abt the not so fresh veges, her attitude is questionable.
author: Zhi Z.

description: This is the best place to get Donburi.  Service could be a little slow only because it's a tiny place and it's right there near union square by the ever so busy Powell Street.  The service is good, never had any bad experiences. I find the host and servers being very polite even during busy hours.
author: Sarah V.

description: A tiny little place, with excellent service and super-fresh food. While we ordered a variety of dishes, from the udon soup to the fresh tofu garnished with scallions and bonito flakes, the rainbow roll was the star of the table. We ate our way through every color of fish, and declared it all good. (Well, I declared it good, and mostly to myself rather than out loud, as my mouth was pretty busy slurping down every kind of fish on the roll, as well as my neighbor's chewy udon and fresh avocado rolls.)
author: Ryan W.

description: Decent udon for lunch.  Lots of other authentic looking things to try.  The wait for lunch (take out or otherwise) can be a little on the long side.
author: Mike L.

description: Nice little Japanese place that was quite busy while I was there and several hours later when I walked back to my hotel just up the street.  Food was great, service relatively attentive even during a rush.  Certainly not fine dining, just a nice small restaurant, decently priced food.
author: Darin C.

description: Hard to find Ramen as good as this. When I go to Japan I'm all about the ramen and have it 5x/week and I find myself going into withdrawals when I get back. My mouth is watering as I write this review and can't wait to go down to the South Bay just so I can eat here.
author: Hiro R.

description:
The food was good but i'ved ate in other japanese restaurant that tasted better. Went there for about 3 or four times, one thing i hate about this place is their waitess. i have no idea if she is preoccupied but she never seem to pay attention in small details, i was asking for a glass of ice for the "yogu" but it took me 3 times to ask her to get it for me.

Another time i ask for a to go box and it took her 4 times (i asked 3 of the waitress but they seem to forget about it.)
author: Wendy Z.

description:
Dojima is another one of those places I should have Yelped a loooong time ago.
It was the very first restaurant I ate at when I moved to SF 9 years ago, so it has a special place in my heart!
That said, I have never been disappointed, although there is nothing wildly exceptional about it. The place is clean but nondescript, the service is good and courteous but not warm or friendly.
Prices are very reasonable, especially for non-fast food downtown place.
I've had almost everything, from sushi and sashimi to udon and donburi. Everything is fresh and yummy; now that I think about it, it's still my favorite place for oyako donburi.
Little plus: I often see Japanese people eat there. Always a good sign.

I think it's a good alternative to all the fancy/expensive and cheap/quick/junk food in the area.
Slightly above average for everything gets 3 stars and a half, and I add a half star for the sentimental value.
author: Vithiet L.

description: As a bonafide LA sushi snob, I am always skeptical to try a new place while I am traveling for work, but Dojima-Ann proved me wrong. They had delicious sushi and noodle dishes and it was all very reasonably priced. I will definitely be back the next time I find myself in the Bay.
author: Danielle G.

description: Mediocre Japanese food in a good location. I've tried the rolls and the Udon (too salty for my taste), and they were both okay. Would go back again if I was in the area and needed some Japanese food to hit the spot. It does get VERY busy.
author: Cate A.

description:
Chicken Katsu, cooked just right. Crispy on the outside, moist on the inside, not oily like some other places. Dipping sauce is authentic, not sweet & sour like the food court places!

I love my Chicken Katsu!!!
author: Jilly C.

description: Everything at Dojima Ann is really good, whether you get a bento box, a combination or sushi.  It's well worth the wait.  If you are coming for lunch it can get a little crowded so I recommend going during off hours, or heading over a little early. My favorite thinks to order are the bento box with chicken katsu and a california roll, or the chicken katsu curry.  Definitely a great place to check out if you are looking for some hearty japanese food.
author: Elsa H.

description:
First time I came here, I really did not like the smell in the restaurant! Maybe it was because I sat near the bathroom door? I don't know.. but the other times I came here, I didn't have that problem.

I like the sushi rolls here, the teriyaki dishes are OK too. I usually come here with my friends when we're downtown and don't want to eat in the Westfield food court. With that said, it is in downtown and it's a small space but it doesn't feel too cramped either.

The prices are decent and the servers are nice. It's definitely not the most amazing sushi place ever, but the location is convienent, and food and service is good enough to fill some cravings. A 3 1/2 stars, A-OK for me.
author: Vanessa L.

description: I currently have an obsession with udon noodles, especially when they are put in soup.  Truthfully, I just have an obsession with Asian food in general at the moment and I was happy that Dojima-Ann was only a short stumble away from our hotel.  I ordered the daily special and found it very satisfying and decently priced.  Paired with a Sappora, it was perfect way to end my first day in San Francisco.
author: Jessica F.

description:
This please should have higher rating then 3.5 starts as what it is now. Just got back from dinner at this restaurant. Food was yummy and pretty authentic! I love their Tonkatsu Donburi. YUM YUM YUM!!! Servers were attentive and nice.  

Restaurant is not big. They don't take reservation neither. I was glad that we got their earlier so that we didn't need to wait like the people who came after us. Another down side was that the owner don't smile. Maybe he just doesn't like to smile in general. 

Overall it is a great spot for authentic Japanese food with reasonable price in Union Square area. I shall return to this restaurant.
author: Lianna D.

description:
This place knows how to use its noodle.  I knew this place was special on the second visit when I noticed it was packed with Japanese tourists and businessmen.  

The sushi here is fresh and good, but places with good sushi are a yen a dozen in San Francisco--it is the soba and udon that keep bringing me back.  I really like the nabeyaki, which is chicken, egg, and veggies with shrimp tempura.  The rice bowls (donburi) are also delicious.  They have good specials, and have also made stuff for me off menu before (like chicken katsudon, instead of pork).

The space is small, but the staff is quick and friendly.  This place is just by Union Square, so it is a great place to get a bite if you need a break from shopping, or a quick bite before a show or movie.
author: Aaron S.

description: Ordered the oyakodon, which was good, but felt cheated because my portion was definitely smaller (about half) than other customers at another table who ordered the same. Price to portion does not balance.
author: D C.

description: Kind of a random food spot to eat at while I was in downtown.  I got the chicken katsu curry and it was pretty good.  I good spot for lunch, not so much for dinner.
author: Jor S.

description: I make sure that I get sushi here every time I'm in San Fran!  Love this place! I've been here at least 4 or 5 times and each time it is fresh and delicious!
author: Karen L.

description:
So Dojima-Ann sounded good for a cool night in SF.  So we stopped in and I was surprised how busy this little restaurant was.  We waited a good 15 minutes before being seated.  But once seated i was ready for a good meal.  I was pleasantly surprised they had Ama Ebi on the menu so I knew that was what I wanted.  Then I choose the veggie, chicken udon.  
The soup was beautiful and had a wonderful aroma to it.  The flavor was also yummy and warm in my belly.  But there was so much soup you could have shared it with another person.  The Ama Ebi on the other hand was another story.  I had a funny little taste with my first bite but I continued to devour the other bite and about 2 minutes later my belly didn't really agree with the ebi,  
so the rest of the night my belly was tossing and turning...so i may pass on the sushi there but I do recommend the soup.
author: Christina P.

description: Best chicken katsu curry hands down. However, service is pretty slow and space is limited. I work in the area so it's better for me to order take out. Other than that the food is delicious!
author: Brigitte M.

description:
We were looking for a place for brunch and somehow ended up here, don't ask me why but I'll take the blame.

We tried this place few years ago and were not impressed, why returned for yet another mediocre meal?  Again, I'll take the blame.

I don't need to try the sushi or sashimi personally to tell you to skip them - they simply did not look good.  California roll made w/ imitation crab roll is just the pits.  The tuna sashimi someone did not look fresh.

Back to what we ordered - oyako don (chicken and egg over rice) and tsukimi udon (raw egg w/ udon).  Both were around $7.50 - reasonable price considering it's Union Square but the portion is smaller than most Japanese places.  The oyako don was very saucy and came w/ a bowl of miso soup.  Hubby found it a bit bland and had to sprinkle some pepper to each bite, which is very unlike him.  The udon was ok, the broth was a little on the salty side - besides the raw egg, there are 2 thin slices of the pink fish cake.  I think I must have used about 1/4 of the pepper.

They maximize the space so it's a little cramped in there.  Unisex bathroom that requires a code.
author: Gloria H.

description:
The food here was a bit off.  For instance, the chicken karaage didn't come with any dipping sauce, only a teaspoon of mayo on the side.  The udon broth is pretty bad...I got the nabeyaki udon, which you usually can't go wrong with, but the broth was very flavorless.  The strangest thing of all was my nigiri.  The tuna came to me lukewarm.  I have never had lukewarm sashimi but I'm guessing the rice may have warmed the fish up if it were sitting on the counter for a while.
Service was slow and I actually had to pay at the counter because the server never came back to us even once.  No water refills and no service.
author: Amber R.

description:
Katsu-Curry: 5-star (Love it)
Udon: 3-star (lower than average compares to actual Japanese don)
Ten-toji-don: 5-star (good)
Price: 5-star
Service: 3-star
Atmosphere: 3-star
Temperature: 4-star
Brightness: 4-star
Table: 2-star (some tables are too small)
Cleanness: 4-star
Bathroom: 3-star (decent)
author: Yosuke K.

description: Great food and great service for such a cozy lil place.
author: Eve R.

description: Went here after the San Francisco Marathon for dinner. I was craving udon and this place fulfilled it! I tried the curry udon (with chicken) because of someone else's reccomendation on Yelp. It was soooo good! My husband even loved it and he doesn't even like hot soup. The ladies serving us were super nice too. Definitely going back here when I visit SF again.
author: L W.

description:
In the past, I've had good experiences at this restaurant despite the possible need to wait for a table (due to its relative small size and its near Union Square location).

I came again this evening after some shopping at Macy's. I was seated after a short wait and ordered. For a time though I was bothered by the fact that nobody brought me any tea. I got more worried when a lady who came in later than I did got her food first. I was not even provided the miso soup and salad which usually comes first. All was well, I guess, when I made a quick inquiry with the owner because by that time I forgot which waitress took my order.

My sashimi combo dinner again come out pretty good. There were more pieces and more variety (six types) than I recall from the past, and all were pretty fresh.  The soup and salad came right before the main plate (maybe as if the waitress was making up for not bringing them earlier). The soup was soup but the salad was disappointing in that there was no dressing. There was a time when they served it with a good vinegar dressing. (Minus one star for this.)

On a side note, I saw a big time Yelper there, and in fact sat next to her. She (Tammy C.) good thing probably had no recognition if me but I recognize her from her photos here. She's better looking on person. Great for the chance to check her out. :)
author: H K.

description:
It's so easy to dismiss this place as another touristy Japanese place in union square.  I know because I did for 10+ years before finally walking in and kicking myself for not having tried it sooner.  Best udon/donburi type dishes I've come across anywhere in the states.  Brought someone who ordered chicken teriyaki here once, and even that looked really good ;).  If I lived closer, I would eat here at least once a week.

highlights:  udon, katsudon, natto maguro
author: Wendy C.

description:
I have been going to Dojima-Ann for years now.
Randomly found it with a friend of mine, when we were both lost and hungry.

For the past 10 years, I always get the same thing.  Katsu Donburi.
My friends usually get something else, and some times we shared.

The food is pretty authentic.  I wouldn't get Donburi from any where else.  

The curries are pretty good. The sauce is think and hearty.

The sushi is pretty decent. But I wouldn't really recommend this place for sushi.

I can name tons from their menu but ultimately, I can't think of one thing I don't like.

The price is decent.  about 15$ per person, unless you go wild and order tons of things.

The service is OK.  They are always so busy!

The line is ridiculously long around noon and 7pm... but worth the wait.

When you see Japanese people eating at a Japanese restaurant, you know its made properly.
author: ji K.

description:
Dojima Noodles are great, and priced to eat (whatever that means... I like it when things are priced to do something. Priced to go, priced to sell, priced to make babies, whaevs). 

Ok, so anyway, go Dojima! I've eaten here enough times to know what I'm talking about.
author: Chris Y.

description:
