This review is only for unagi donburi, grated yam and ramen. I can't see why some people rated their donburi as 'authentic'. Dojima-Ann is a tourist trap so AVOID IT AT ANY COST !! It's much much much better for your belly and wallet to just buy a burrito bowl at Chipotle across the street. 

But if right now you are reading my review inside the restaurant and it's kinda too late to withdraw because the server is waiting for your order, chicken katsu is a safe bet.
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
Went there today for dinner. The sushi was above average. Not the best I have ever had, though definitely not bad. Service was a little slow. 

All in all a solid restaurant, would definitely go back.
author: J M.

description:
I've made a slight turn from my regular sushi joint visits and decided to rate some udon this time

Pipin' hot & smelling delicious were my first impressions of the Nebayaki Udon. I adored the colorful vegetable & seafood chunks mixed in the Japanese noodle soup base. Though what I hate about udon is that you have to wait until the temperature of the soup cools to savor the bowl unless you want to burn your toungue. Though, it was worth the wait.

My favorite is the Unagi Donburi w/ raw egg...served in a big bowl with teriyaki grilled eel over a bed of sticky Japanese rice with egg. One of the things I look for is whether the eel is under or overcooked and fortunately, it was cooked just right & uber-yum...man if only my taste buds can speak.

Fortunately, the delicious food made me forget how cramped this restaurant was... the tables & chairs were almost so close to each other that you can probably make a bed out of the furniture if inched together

I would come back...and this time I will stay on course & try some sushi
author: Charmian D.

description: Taste of udon soup was la Osaka, not Tokyo.So  I like it and I felt sense of nostalgia.
author: Goo F.

description:
While vacationing in San Francisco, we were sushi hopping and stumbled upon Dojima-Ann Japanese Restaurant. This place ROCKS it is casual, clean, full of flavor and one of our favorites in the city, you can tell it is full of locals and tourist as well. 

We went twice in one week for lunch; we loved the Eel Udon with yam and quail egg, Sushi (VERY FRESH FISH!),and everything in between that was served. The service was a little slow but we were in no hurry. It is well worth the wait!
author: Jules S.

description: I was transported back to Japan at this little spot. Portions are plentiful, service is cute and friendly, the place turns tables fast so the wait is shorter.
author: Ameer N.

description: Great place to eat in the Union Square area.  It's seems to be crowded at all hours, so be prepared to wait awhile for a table, but it's worth it.
author: G O.

description: Una tama don was excellent.  Very tasty affordable lunch specials under 12.50.  Found this place last minute for a quick eat.
author: Vincent M.

description:
I was craving sushi while strolling on my own in SF and was so hungry (lazy?) that I stopped in here since it was the first sushi place I came across by the Hilton. 

I checked the menu on the window and it seemed like they had enough sushi choices so I went for it. I was seated right away. The place is small and it had a bit of a funny smell (pee?) and I thought about leaving but stayed and prayed. I was brought delicious free tea and when I was handed the menu I was a bit bummed that there really weren't that many rolls (that at least I would eat). So I went for my standard spicy tuna roll and a Philadelphia roll. 

The hand roll was smaller than what I'm used to but it was still very fresh and delish. The Philly roll was good as well - all six pieces. I was going to order more but unless I went for a Cali roll (there wasn't anything else I'd try) - so I stopped there. And no doubt was starving again an hour later! 

All an all I'd at least recommend getting more food - but the service was on point and the sushi tasted fresh and I enjoyed it nonetheless.
author: Erin H.

description: i had their gyudon and it was delicious! the place is a little small so we had to wait for a bit...but their service could be better though.
author: Ru C.

description:
On a rainy day in San Francisco, Dojima-Ann's Chicken Katsu Curry was amazing. I don't usually like curry, but Japanese curry is an exception. I love it. The space is tight, and crowded, but the waiters are pretty nice and the food comes relatively quick. My Chicken Katsu Curry also came with a "mini udon." But to be honest, it wasn't so mini at all. I probably could've had that mini udon for a light dinner. It also came with a small salad as well. The meal was $13 and very well worth it. 

All in all, good food, good portions, good service, all in a very tight space. If you're not interested in hearing other peoples conversations, this might not be the best place for you. But if you need a good place to go to in the middle of Union Square to get warm and fill up, it's perfect!
author: Tammy C.

description: This place is cute. Yeah, it's pretty small & tight, but s'all good! The service was great, at least the time I was there. Their sushi wasn't all the best, I enjoyed their Don's best.
author: Rachael R.

description: Expensive but great late night eats! im A HUGE FAN OF THEIR SOBA!
author: Caesar H.

description:
I stopped in here for some udon because on the sign outside it has 'OSAKA UDON' (Osaka being a city in Japan well known for its udon) written in Japanese. Having read the sign, I was hoping that udon was the specialty , so I ordered accordingly, opting for a cold udon with tempura, the cold udon due to the current unseasonably hot weather in SF, and the tempura due to the fact that I was not-a-little-hungry.

Service was quick, and I found myself with a nice, standard-looking set of ten-zaru-udon sitting in front of me. Generally when I go to a restaurant there are a couple things I look for to see if they are doing a good job on their soba/udon. The first thing, naturally, is the noodles themselves. In this case, the speed of the service was about as fast as could be, leading me to suspect that the noodles had been pre-cooked and possibly the tempura also- according to my father, a fairly common tactic for noodle restaurants everywhere. Live and let live, I say---at least as long as it doesn't affect the flavor or my digestion. In this case, the udon tasted fine, and I was hungry. So there we go, no problems. 

The second thing, however, and this is where I begin to justify the middlish rating, was the tempura. 2 shrimp, 1 pumpkin, 1 eggplant, 1 potato, 1 red pepper, 1 pimento and 1 broccoli (well, actually, 'broccoli' is plural, so I guess it should be one 'broccolo').  The tempura was filling, but that is about all I can say for it. I came in for the 'Osaka udon' and make no mistake, I never got served no BROCCOLI  in Osaka. But fair enough, this is the USA, and we are a melting pot, and I don't begrudge people their broccoli tempura, if it is nice and fresh, which this wasn't particularly. Not bad, not good.

Finally the last thing that I tend to look for when eating any kind of cold soba or udon has to do with the sauce for the noodles, which contributes greatly to the flavor of what are otherwise basically flavorless noodles. In this case, the sauce was fine, but the raw quail egg served with it was less than totally fresh- it took quite a bit of mashing with my chopsticks to get the yolk to break up. I hope that leaves a nice image in your mind.

So what have we learned from this bit of dining experience of mine? I would submit the following things in defense of this restaurant: it is conveniently located. The portions are good. On the flipside, the food is marginally authentic, and it is not cheap. If you are looking for a place to eat Japanese food and happen to be in the area, it's not horrible, but neither is it a place that I would rush to eat at again. In all, a great dining conundrum in restaurant form- so it goes.
author: Daniel P.

description: The server was a bit slow and not extremely attentive. We walked in and the server kind of gave us this look. They weren't too busy either. The food definitely makes up for it. Definitely order the Tonkatsu Donburi. The tonkatsu is crunchy and the egg is cooked perfectly. It was very yum yum. I also had a side of tempura which was okay.
author: Elaine L.

description: The place is small but the wait wasn't long for a Friday night. The food was great but the service not so much. I asked for a refill on my soda and never got it. Had to ask for the check twice. Don't think I'll be going back.
author: Rachel G.

description: Super authentic place! Was in San Fran on vacation & was referred to this spot by someone who lives in the area. It's a small divey spot but the service was good. It's got a mix of Japanese, Thai & maybe Korean.., or Vietnamese.. Lol.. I'm not even really sure.. But I orded a curried beef w/ rice & miso soup. Soup & salad were yum but my curry was actually quite bland & meat a little chewy. My boyfriend enjoyed his dish tho... A pork, fried egg & rice type bowl.. Overall a good experience but something's on menu are better than others!
author: Sasha P.

description: 3 at most liked how it was fast but sushi was ok and we got our appetizer after the sushi? no 2nd round of drinks - no asking us if everything was ok - waitresses seemed as if their socializing was more important - this place is extremely small everyone can totally see you doing NOTHING! fail
author: Eni V.

description: Pretty good Japanese food located very close to Union Square.  My husband and I come here every once in a while when we get hungry power shopping.  The food isn't spectacular, but it's consistent.  I recommend the bento box for a little bit of everything but leave the sushi alone.  Too much rice and not enough stuffing.
author: Julie P.

description:
I went here on a recommendation from a co-worker who lived in Japan. I had sushi and agedashi tofu.  The uni tasted sweet and fresh.  The agedashi tofu, although not a barometer for good Japanese food, was meh!  
The sushi was too big.  I like smaller sized sushi.  If my maki falls apart in the soy sauce, it makes me mad.  I also don't like to stuff myself with huge maki rolls or nigiri. Trying to chew all that food just interferes with the ability to taste them. The salmon skin roll was good (too big).  The spicy tuna was so-so.
I'll come back because it's close to work, but I might go to Katana-ya instead.
author: Genevieve W.

description:
Although it's by Union Square, this is a hidden treasure. Good! I don't like waiting for a table anyway. 

I come here to have their combination: I have their udon, or order a typical donburi with a mini-udon noodle soup. Eyes larger than stomach? You bet. But the rice bowl is good, and their noodle soup is really good. I haven't tried their sushi. 

This is a casual place, good for pre-shopping energy, post-shopping fill-up, or a leisurely lunch with a good friend. On weekdays, I always seem to wait for a table since worker-bees decide to lunch here as well.
author: Loocha L.

description:
My first meal in San Francisco did not impress. This brightly lit restaurant was busy, but I managed to snaffle a table towards the back next to a family.

Not wanting to rock the boat I went for a fail safe Chicken Teriyaki Don, side of edamame and a glass of Chardonnay. As I waited for my food to arrive the little boy on the next table spilt a full glass of iced water all over his lap. Seemingly unperturbed he stood and removed his shorts. Just what you need when you are about to eat. 

My edamame arrived shortly. You cannot go much wrong with edamame, and the soya inside the unfortunately yellowy looking pods  tasted good. Then my main arrived. I threw the broth in with the chicken and rice, making a thick soup. Again unfortunately the crispy part of the chicken was burnt and tasted burnt. It tainted the entire dish.

I have eaten some sensational Chicken Teriyaki Don's in my time and this offering sits way down on my list.
author: Leon C.

description:
Ok, I and my wife went there for lunch around 1:20pm on Saturday.
We ordered Chirashi don and Unatamadon.  Chirashi don came with miso soup and salad.  Both of them were good, but the problem was the Chirashi don.  All the fishes were so bad.  They were soggy and not fresh at all, and they charge it for $16.50.  It was the worst Chirashi don we have ever had.  The saba was so bad that after we got out from the restaurant, we had this bad fish smell in our mouth, we had to buy a gum to make our mouth fresh.  I know saba has unique fish smell and i like it WHEN ITS FRESH.   Don't ever order Chirashidon here, you might get sick.  
Service wasn't good either.  The waiter was friendly, but other two waitresses were like zombies.   We will never go back to this restaurant.
author: Jin K.

description: Kachu donburi was my menu but not exactly Japanese food because the side food was not Benishoga, and taste was soso. Big problem was 'a wrong change'. I gave them $10.82 but they hid my quarter, then said that is not enough. We argued but I could not proof that situation:( anyway... I don't want to go there anymore.
author: Yeryn J.

description:
This is a great spot for Japanese comfort food like Mom used to make.
It is what I consider "Japanese diner food".
It's all about the Donburi and Udon. I had the oyakodon and croquettes they were spot on .
Reminded me of my Mom's and places I have eaten at in Osaka .
Very satisfying on a rainy day.
If you grew up eating this kind of food you will like this place.
author: Trixxi T.

description:
Went to have a quick lunch on Sunday. The place doesn't look good and we were seated at the counter. It was dirty and there was a bad smell around. 

We ordered the Tekkamaki, Salmon and some Sashimi. It was average at best. 

Service was bad. Don't recommend.
author: Reinaldo N.

description:
Setting: Right in middle of downtown and close to the shopping center. This restaurant is so busy. Specially around 9, there is a line outside the door.

Their soups are very good. 

Customer service can improve a little.

-Sue
author: Sue C.

description: This was my first visit here and what I like about this place the most was the service. They were fast to take my order and let me sit were I wanted. I had the sushi combo which I found to be really fresh and the price here is reasonable. I eat out alot and give this place a three stars and will be back again. I have found better in SF. If you want to impress your date this is not the place.
author: Tommy S.

description: Avoid the Udon broth as it was just flavorless, worse I have ever had.  Maybe other things are better as it was crowded at lunch time.
author: Matt K.

description: I went there on a busy night. Fortunately, I was by myself so I was seated by the bar right away. The katsudon that I was recommended was excellent. The cutlet was juicy and breading stayed crispy. The rice had just the right amount of sauce and the taste of the sauce was rich and not overly salty. For the price, the meal was superb. However, may be I went on the wrong day with the wrong waitress. My waitress did not smile even once during my entire stay. I felt like I was in a funeral... May be this place is one of those where you don't go there for service. Ah well.
author: Alfred L.

description:
ate here today before going to see Wicked.  Typical japanese fare, but i really liked the flavors.  i got a beef teriyaki lunch plate along with a shrimp tempura roll.  beef was tender and medium rare.  good stuff.  

i knew it was gonna be a good japanese restaurant because there were alot of japanese people there.  

i love you long time.
author: Ray R.

description: We've seated for 15 mins and no one take our orders. Food does not mean everything, their service is sooooo bad!
author: Aluna C.

description:
I got the combination plate with sushi and beef teriyaki. The sushi was pretty good, and the prices were reasonable, as sushi goes. 

The beef teriyaki was not impressive. The beef was chewy and the teriyaki sauce was too subtle for me. The pot stickers were middle of the road, nothing to write home about.

If I go back, I'd probably just order sushi.
author: Jeremiah R.

description: When stuck in Union Square for some odd reason, I have been to Dojima-Ann a few times now.  It is a serviceable, no nonsense sort of place that serves Japanese comfort food.  Things like donburi, udon, etc.  As such, it's pretty decent, and it won't break the bank.  I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here, however.  Not with places like Muracci's a ten minute walk from here...
author: Dave N.

description:
We were starving one night and didn't want to stray too far from our hotel (especially since there was much drinking to be had!). We ended up here, at Dojima-Ann, at a fairly decent hour. The line wasn't too long for this tiny restaurant but the smells wafting from the kitchen convinced me it was worth it. 

When we were finally seated, there was a great selection of rolls, soba, udon, and other meals. I opted for the Tori Udon while my friends go the Tonkatsudon and the curry soba.

Mmmmm. The soup warmed me up on a chilly July evening (hey, I'm from the south bay! I don't do well with the SF temps!). The portions were generous and came out quickly. We all tried a bit of each other's food before scarfing down our own. 

We left Dojima-Ann happy and satisfied with our meal. Then it was game on for the drinking. But that's another review.
author: Julia W.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon with a party of 3.  It's not crazy special or anything, but no complaints.  It was good.  I got the chicken karaage don.  The white sauce it comes with is really good and the chicken isn't over fried.  They also have pretty good specials if you have a large appetite.  Typically, it's a small sized udon and a donburi for $11.95.  I would not mind coming back.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Gross food, I mean it! Tastes awful! I had something with chicken and rice, i can't remember what exactly it was, but it looked good on their specials picture so i ordered it. It was pure boiled tasteless chicken with runny eggs, gag! I had never had anything worse in my life! And they call this Japanese. This is a mockery of Japanese food! 
When we came in and sat down, the waitresses kept coming to us every 5 seconds asking if we were ready to order, while we were clearly still studying the menu. However, once we ordered and they brought our crappy food, they did not once come to us and refill water or ask if we needed anything else. 
Terrible food, unprofessional staff - in two words: tourist trap! If you are a hungry tourist, do not go there, you will only thank me in the end!
author: Suzanna G.

description: Very small cozy japanese mom & pop shop for some REAL DEAL Japanese food! The katsudon was delicious and mini soba hit the spot.  Inexpensive Japanese comfort food for this little Japanese American girl!!  soooo gooood.  Portions are generous and tastes like mom's cooking!  Definitely will come back when I'm staying next door at the Nikko hotel for work!
author: Emi G.

description:
This place is right around the corner from where I work so it's really convenient to get  decent Japanese food at a reasonable during my lunch breaks. So far, I've only had their tonkatsu curry, beef curry, and curry udon and all three were pretty damn good. If you get their curry rice to-go, I suggest asking to keep the curry and rice separate to keep the rice from getting soggy. And if you get udon, be sure ask for and pay a little more for extra noodles. The side salad the comes with the curry rice items are pretty good too.

Service here is okay. I ordered to-go for the 3 occasions that I have been here and only once did the waitress tell me to have a seat and brought me a cup of hot tea, free of charge. The guy at the register isn't too friendly but he's not exactly the rudest person I've ever met. The service prevents me from giving a full 5-star rating.
author: J L.

description:
After trying out Dojima-Ann, I am under the impression that most of the eateries around Union Square/Powell Station are rip-offs to locals. Note that I say "most", not "all" since I have not tried all the places yet. Still, I was irritated by how popular Dojima-Ann seemed (it filled up quickly even before the usual dinnertime of 6pm), yet the quality of the food was mediocre and the price was just too much for the food.

For $17.95, customers can order two entrees with rice, salad, and miso soup. Sounds like a good deal, right? Not to me; luckily I wasn't the one paying for the meal last night (early birthday treat from a friend), but I still felt bad that the value of the meal was so poor. I ordered tonkatsu (fried pork cutlets) and potato croquette for the combination; probably not the best combo to have when I'm trying to limit my intake of fried foods. 

The presentation of the food was decent, Japanese-style; the tonkatsu seemed a bit tougher to chew than normal. I was disappointed with the small amount of sauce they provided for both the croquette and tonkatsu. The salad and miso soup were typical to most other Japanese restaurants.

Service-wise, the servers were attentive: they made sure to refill our tea in a prompt manner and bring us water when we requested it. The clientele of Dojima-Ann last night consisted of Koreans and caucasians. My friend stated there were no Japanese in the restaurant, which may indicate some lack of authenticity at Dojima-Ann (or, it could just indicate that Japanese want to eat elsewhere in the Square or go to Japantown instead).

The daily specials seemed like a better deal, but still, I had an issue with the price. The dinner at Norikonoko cost about the same, but there was a larger variety of food available in the meal than at Dojima-Ann. Also, I've had combo meals at other Japanese places for less money and more food.

Not the best place to go to in general if you're craving Japanese food and a good bargain. You might be better off going to Katana-ya on Geary or go for non-Japanese cuisine in the Square.
author: Helene K.

description:
1 star for their decent food
2nd star for being close by the mall area
3rd star for being consistent

I recommend the special with the katsu donburi and the tempa udon. That's about all that i really recommend, because the other shit here isn't that great. The only thing here that beats every restaurant i went to is the tempa udon. They are a bit pricey though.
author: T t.

description:
Likes: Unagi donburi and beef udon set, tempura rice and cold noodles set, spicy tuna roll, spider rolls, etc.  overall good food and good location 

Dislikes: the wait is long if you come during peak periods, place is a little small so can be a bit cramped if you happened to have a lot of bags or jackets on hand, unagi had a lot of bones but I guess that's normal
author: Karen M.

description: My wife and I have been eating here for over 20 years and other than being slightly more expensive, it is as good as it was the first time. We admit we havent tried the more unusual items. We stick with the udon/soba and donburi. We've eaten Japanese food all over the USA, and still feel the quality and price will keep us coming back for another 20 years.
author: Sam L.

description: mediocre.  kakiage don, tempura had very thick batter, not much shrimp, rice too sweet, side of cold udon with wasabi based sauce.  sushi farm raised soft salmon.  nabeyaki udon was ok better.  crowded, but only for convenience for tourists.
author: Rob C.

description:
Okay, perhaps unfairly, I am going to base some of this review on the overwhelming...bathroom...urinal cake-y smell that just hit me when we walked in.  Ordinarily, I would leave a restaurant that smelled like that.  Especially one that served raw fish (just a bad combo).  But, my family and I had been wandering around aimlessly for too long and I just wanted to sit down somewhere.  It was just very unpleasant.  I don't know if it's there all of the time, but it was when I was there.  The whole meal.

This was lunch on a Thursday.  My brother's sushi was bad.  He ordered a dragon roll and couldn't eat more than one slice.  I thought, "It can't possibly be that bad."  I tried a slice and there was just something off about it.

I ordered the bento box with beef teriyaki and tempura.  My beef teriyaki was very tough.  I could only eat a few slices before I got bored with it.  The tempura was fine, but as with most fried foods, tempura is a little harder to mess up.  I don't like the miso they use.  My mom seemed to like the tonkatsu but probably wouldn't say it was the best ever.

We also shared an appetizer of agedashi tofu which was good.  The service was just kind of weird, and again - the smell...I won't be returning.
author: Mary O.

description: A bento box place that tastes really fresh and good? Yes! This place is it! The tonkatsu was good but to my surprise, it was the combo sashimi dinner plate that was the bomb. For $20, you get a 4 choices of sashimi, 3 thick slices each. You can't beat that! AND IT WAS SUPER FRESH! This will be my go-to sashimi dinner joint when I'm in town for work. Try it!
author: Red G.

description:
Acceptable Warm Things
- muffins
- puppies
- the pillow of that girl you're stalking

Unacceptable Warm Things
- raw fish
- soda
- the adjacent pillow of that girl you're stalking (heartless bitch...)

Good service. Warm sushi. Why won't she return my calls?!
author: Keane L.

description: My new favorite Japanese restaurant!!! Been there 5 times in the past 3 weeks. Such a good deal, 12.50 for a tonkatsu donburi and mini udon combo for dinner!! The sushi is delicious as well, and don't even get me started on the curry! The beef curry isn't just beef curry, that's an understatement, it's STEAK curry! The udon has a unique light broth, which is delicious and satisfying. The servers are always sweet and is relatively fast. I read reviews about this place and all the good things I've heard are true!
author: Robin O.

description:
I really like this place for lunch when I find myself in Union Square, shopping, working, waxing or whatever. Situated on Cyril Magnin, a relatively relaxed side street away from the hordes of Union Square proper, Dojima-An is a good choice for an authentic Japanese lunch.

This restaurant replaced an old school noodle house that was here back in the day. I don't recall the name of it unfortunately, but I do remember ordering the sansai udon there and loving it. Happily, Dojima-Ann serves it too, and its tasty, although the broth is just a wee bit watery. The sansai (mountain vegetables) are perfectly cooked, slightly crunchy and fun to eat. I like it. I also like the rice cakes filled with salmon - two generous triangles with a seaweed wrapper for a mere $3.50. The tempura looks worthwhile, although I have yet to sample it myself. Tables all around me were scarfing it down.

It's a clean, airy space with a nice view from a window seat for leisurely gazing while you enjoy your lunch. They offer a range of lunch specials at reasonable prices, but I generally stick with the above cause I like what I like. And I do like Dojima-An.
author: wendella a.

description:
I left great sushi in San Francisco.  After 30 years, found Dojima-Ann while I was visiting Union Square a few months ago.

Great, fresh sushi and efficient (kinda abrupt, but not onerously so).

Go for lunch
author: Duck H.

description: Great food!!!  We did take out but even when we got back to the hotel the food was still hot.  I had tempura...it was sooo good.  My sister got tonkatsu and it was good.  The only downside is that they forgot to put my agedashi tofu in the bag.  I called and went back and not only did they put my missed tofu dish but added a tofu salad.
author: Marisa A.

description: Really good dishes. Simple place with great prices for dinner. Good for foodies who enjoy Japanese. Quick service. Appears to get busy during dinner rush hour even on a Monday night.
author: Joe W.

description:
large fillin' bento boxes, donduri 'n' udon....japanese style comfort food with "americanized" portions.....tonkatsu donburi sweet 'n' meaty...thickly sauced.....overly starched sauce....and simple no frills udon....combinations available..undecided between donduri 'n' udon...both an option...mix 'n' match items to create ones desire....complete meals averagin' $10 to $13 per person....bargain stop 'n' eat when near the union square*....

*avoid during the sunshine filled warm days....sauna experience....no a/c a discomfort...
author: Hen A.

description: I was in the area with my bff and walked by this place. We were originally looking for a Thai spot. It looked busy so we went inside. This man greeted us in the front without smiling and waved his hand to "sit over there." Ok that's fine. It took 10 minutes to get menus. One waitress was looking at each table, looking to clear dishes, saw us a few times and never noticed we never got helped, even after I waved my hand. I'm not in a rush though...I'm pretty patient and we were having girl time to talk. I ordered the mixed tempura and a 49er's roll. My friend got the chicken terriyaki and tempura bento box. I ate my tempura and it was delicious. My friend's bento box was good too.  Maybe 30 minutes later, my friend reminded them I was still waiting for my roll and the waitress said "okay." Waited again for a bit. Why does a different girl come over and try to give us a check and ask if we needed anything else. I said yes, I'm still waiting for my roll. So, they told me I didn't order it but they can put the order in now. I had to wait another 20 minutes. I was mad but still didn't give them a hard time. My 49'ers roll had lemon wedges on top with the rind on it which was very bitter. I would have ordered something else because I was still hungry but we have been there way too long already and I was not happy with their lack of service and disorganization. Not a good experience.
author: Bay M.

description: This is the real thing!  Authentic, high-quality, inexpensive Japanese food, in a convenient location to the Moscone Convention Center and downtown hotels.  I had the Soba (buckwheat) noodles with ikura (salmon eggs).  Delicious!!
author: Glenn C.

description:
Review by a Japanese.

I was walking around Union Square one day, was straving, and their wax food display caught my attention (hey, this reminds me of restaurants in Japan!).
I had a udon/katsudon combo, which was definitely under $10 (don't remember exactly how much).
I was pleasantly surprised by their katsudon.
It was just like how they make it in Japan.  Slightly sweet.
By far the best katsdon out of all katsudons I've had in the US.

5 stars for their katsudon!

They can sell their katsudon in Japan, no problem.

Update:
I went back there to have tororo unadon.
This was extremely good.  Give it a try.
author: Yusaku S.

description:
I used to come here all the time ten years ago and have just recently visited again after all these years. Surprised to see the EXACT same menu and receving the EXACT type of service. 
  
The qualify to noodle/broth....all reminds of me of a real authentic Japanese noodle house.

However, the overprice bland sushi, the not so clean floor (they do have high foot traffic), the small portion is what turns me to another Japanese place close by....especially there are so many within 5 blocks. 

My suggestion is to leave union square wiht the high rent, lower the price and become the best neighborhood noodle house.

Or just reamins the same and continue with the tourist business. Locals....we can do better.
author: Maggie C.

description: I like this place. The price is right and the portions are significant. Service is friendly, however, the only downside is that it's a bit too crowded. The plus side is that it makes for a great intimate atmosphere.
author: John C.

description:
You can have cheap sushi, you can have good sushi, and you can have a lottal sushi.

This place is inexpensive and has big portions.  Enough said?

Miso solup came out room temperature.  No problem, they have a microwave.  Wakame was too sweet.  Mirin?  Chirashi was abundant and beautifully presented but not very fresh, a feast for the eyes but not the mouth.
author: Gil S.

description:
You can find a sushi restaurant blindfolded.  A restaurant that prepares Japanese comfort food (donburi stuff) is not so easy to find.  Dojima-Ann is one of them, and the one few not in Japantown.  
The food is not really good but its not really bad either...atleast they are consistently average.
author: Wakako U.

description: Excellent Sushi and worth the wait if there are no seats available.  This is clearly a family business that is beyond any expectations.  My only issue preventing 5 stars is that with all the hotels around it they do not accept American Express.
author: Joel N.

description:
My friend introduced me to this restaurant the other day. It was a bit busy, but service was fast.

Food: The food is probably a three stars. Minus 1 star for not even having a dessert menu. I was pretty shocked that they didn't even have mochi or green tea ice cream or any other type of "Japanese" dessert. I ordered the dinner combo with sushi (half a California roll and a couple other pieces of sushi/raw) with miso soup, salad, and chicken teriyaki. I have to say that the rice was pretty good. The chicken was a bit dry, but overall the portions are moderate especially considering the $17.99 they charged for the dinner combo (I got 5 pieces of chicken literally). Even though I was already stuffed since I can't eat a lot, the portions are small relative to some of the other Japanese restaurants with the same offerings. The soup was pretty good and they added bits of bean curd/tofu bits which is a bit different than the standard miso (more unique in my book).

Customer Service: Service was pretty good. The waitress was pretty fast. She came by a couple times to see if we were ready to order. 

Ambiance: It's a bit cramped though many restaurants in Japan are a bit crowded due to space limitations (perhaps imitation?). It's located in a busy part of town so you'll always see a crowd. It's quaint for a small place, but not a place for a quiet convo with a friend since there are many people and a small room.

Payment: They do take credit card (several types including VISA, AMEX, and the JCB-Japanese card).

Parking: Parking is a bit hard though not impossible at night especially if one is good at looking for street parking. There's also several paid parking lots - though expensive within several blocks.

Overall, it's a good place to dine especially because it's so central to all the shopping, Union Square, bus and other transit lines. However, I've been to other Japanese restaurants that are around the same cost/type and their food and portions are a bit better. I would probably give the food here a 3.5, but the lack of a dessert menu and the crowdedness made me give it a 3 versus a 4 for star ratings.
author: Tina C.

description: Tasteless sushi, awful service, but tasty noodle bowls...thassabouttit.  Good luck getting a refill on anything or your check. It's like you're trapped in there forever waiting! Ugh...
author: Rachael C.

description:
Sushi restaurants are notoriously expensive, but if you're looking for something more affordable, where you can buy tasty and well made sushi, as well as other Japanese dishes, then Dojima Ann is an excellent restaurant to visit. It's a very popular place on Friday evenings, often with long queues outside the front door and on other week-day nights the restaurant makes brisk business. The food is served promptly and the the staff are efficient and friendly. I find their Don's and Soup's are excellent and come in generous portion sizes. There is a wide selection of freshly made sushi on the menu and there's a good selection of refreshing Japanese beers. 

If you're eating by yourself then you can have a sumptuous meal for around $15. Dojima Ann is highly recommended, but if you're a sushi snob then it might not be the best place in your books.
author: Kaustav B.

description:
Not authentic japanese food nor does it taste super authentic.

The rice was soggy.

Food is decent and almost no worth what you pay for. 

Beef curry over rice is my favorite.

Pricing was cheap too.

Wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Keit K.

description: Pretty good...Maybe a buck or 2 high priced for lunch. But everything we had was pretty solid. Bento boxes are very nice. Chirashi presented nicely and fresh as well. Miso was nice and the salad was good. Definitely prepare for around 20$ in here for lunch with tax and tip...
author: Matt W.

description:
I always walked by this restaurant and saw full house so I thought I'd give it a try.  It was full as usual so we were placed near a counter area close to the kitchen.

The waiters mostly focus at other diners sitting at the tables and totally ignored the people who are sitting at the counter area.  Someone finally came and took our orders after we've been sitting there for 10 minutes.

After our order has been placed, we sat for another 10 minutes before someone realized that we were not provided water/tea.  But they didn't bring us any water/tea.

Our orders finally came out.  The waiter who brought the food to us apologized that no water/tea was provided and finally brought water/tea.  However, he forgot about the miso soup that came with the meal.

They always bypass us to enter/out of the counter/kitchen area.  But we felt that we were being totally ignored.  There's a man who would recognize that certain items are missing for us, but he never bring anything.  He just order the other 2 ladies to bring stuff and the other 2 ladies forgot.

Finally a lady brought us the miso soup at the end of our meal.

To make it worse, the bill came incorrect -- overcharged.

I will not visit this place again because 1. the food is not great -- it's packed because of the location  2. bad customer service.
author: Yuko Y.

description: The place need to more clean I walked in here and and the floors and table are not cleaned at all. The waitress just swipe one time the table and say me down it was not clean enough for me. The food is good but it's not clean environment. They need to put more effort into cleaning the place it was mint even busy at the time.
author: m l.

description:
I love this place.

Why? It's fairly inexpensive for the city. If not down right affordable for the awesome food here. The best thing is the sushi rice. You can just tell they actually know how to make the stuff (it's hard. I've tried). Not only do they have a good selection of sushi, but they have curries, noodles, and rice dishes. If you're in the Union Square area, head over here. In fact, I'm going tonight.
author: Eric N.

description:
One of my favorite places to have lunch.. and dinner. We had dinner yesterday and I totally forgot about this place, but when the thought of having authentic japanese food without emptying my wallet even more after a good night of shopping crossed my mind, it hit me. DOJIMA-ANN! 

Its located on Geary and going to eat at 7pm, there was plenty of space to feed an army. We had the curry beef, which came with japanese style curry (saucy and a touch of sweetness) and beff on a plate with rice, and a side order of "mini" udon (which is nothing more than a couple of udon noodles. 

On the other had, my SO had tokatsu donburi, but her egg wasn't fully cook, so we sent it back and heard the microwave go off twice (coinicidence?) ;) 

We both enjoyed our meals and was rather full (and sleepy) after having ate both plates. 

it's an awesome place, and the service is quick and friendly. One star notched off because sometimes their food is hit and miss. 

Luckily it was a hit to end the night of shopping.
author: Wilson L.

description:
konnichiwa! 

my husband & i ate here about 6 times in august, '06, while attending a convention. it's a tiny restaurant on o'farrell st. just down from the nikko hotel. i thought the food was quite good, and the prices were reasonable. it was frequented by japanese patrons. for lunch & dinner - lines were out the door & down the block. we found this to be a little oasis in the midst of a very busy convention week!

you may not want to go during high meal-time hours unless you don't mind standing in line. parking may be an issue, unless you're staying at one of the hotels nearby - or park in one of their garages.

btw - "i left my cc in san francisco." not realizing until i returned to st. louis (where i frequent japanese restarurants). i called and spoke with the manager, not knowing where else i could have left it - they had my cc. he told me to call my cc co. & ask them for a new card, then let him know & he would destroy the one i left behind. 

i did that - no problem!
author: Nancy P.

description: The best miso soup I've ever had. Very good sushi as well. Packed with Japanese people, always a good sign! Very small though.
author: Giorgio B.

description:
the only REAL home style japanese food I've found! (besides kirala in berkeley) It is very inexspensive which is incredibly reare for union square japanese food. Funny enough, there is another japanese food resturant 5 times more exspensive and not even close to the quality of this udon house!

If you're smart you'll order what I recommend: (not sushi... its a udon house..)
- age dashi tofu
- katsu anything
- Nabeyaki udon
author: Kendra C.

description: My husband and I had been happy customers for several years. However, I doubt we will return after our experience on Monday night. We arrived before 5pm, so the place wasn't crowded at all. We were greeted in a friendly manner and were ready to chow down. We were surprised at the lack of service and the poor quality of the food. They were well staffed that evening but the waitresses were so inattentive. We had to wait over 10 mins. for our water, even though another table came in after we arrived and received their  water and tea immediately. I noticed a sign on the wall for Shrimp Tempura with rice and cold soba noodles-but I was in the mood for Shrimp and Veggie Tempura. I pointed to the sign and asked  if I could have veggies with that as well. The waitress misunderstood me and thought I wanted veggies only. When I told her that I'd like Shrimp and veggies, she gave me a nasty look. I told her that I assumed if would cost more and that that was no problem. She actually harrumphed and then angrily scratched my order off her order pad, barked that it came WITH vegetables and immediately turned to my husband to take his order. Whoa! Luckily his order was pretty straight forward. The waitress never came back to check on us. My tempura was cold and soggy, and the batter was off of the shrimp. My husband's chicken teriyaki was bland and there wasn't much chicken at all. The miso soup was really good and the soba noodles? Well you can't screw that up too badly.
author: Dee T.

description:
The sushi was delicious. 

Miso soup, can you really go wrong?

Seaweed salad, again, can you really go wrong?  On point with most other seaweed salads...

Salmon & avocado maki - the salmon was SO fresh.  Yummy.

Spicy tuna handroll  - very spicy!    : o

Service was polite and quick.  Prices were great!  

It is very close to Union Square, so it is very accessible.
author: Katherine W.

description: it was okay, had the eel with egg + mini udon. a bit on the bland side.
author: Tiff W.

description: They have the tastiest beef curry. A little pricey but worth it. Est. $12 - $17 per person.
author: Fabled O.

description:
So this place seems to be getting reviews all across the board and I figured I'd throw my 2-cents in as well. For all sakes and purposes, this place gets the job done in providing reasonably tasty japanese food in the mess that only Union Square can provide. Is the sushi great? Of course not but it does get the job done. Case in point, their hamachi sashimi wasn't the freshest of items served to me on my visit but once doused in a little wasabi/soy mixture, I could really give a s**t. Bonus points that this place was still even open and willing to take our group in at 9:50 pm on a Friday night. Apparently every damn restaurant in the Union Sq. area shuts down by 10 pm (I will never get this City). 

Bitching aside, their katsu donburi was actually pretty good and probably  one of the better one's I've had in the City. The pork cutlets were cooked just right and their sauce-to-egg ratio was spot on. I also tried their daily special grilled squid plate and, although not amazing, it was decent. If anything, it served it's purpose in making the rest of my party sit with eyes wide open.

In the end, are you going to bring a date here? Recommend it as a great dining out experience to friends? Hell no. If you're caught starving in the black hole that is Union Square and find yourself too far away from the SF Center food court, this is a very valid option.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
I always go to this restaurant since its location is close to Union Square. I went there last night and the service was really bad. The guy who I guess was the owner, the one who wear black square glasses and always at the cash register, was really mean to us. (me and my another 4 friends) 
So, after eating I went to him and asked if he is the owner with a normal voice. He suddenly raised his voice and said "What do you want?" I told him that the service today is not good. His reply was "Do I need to service you? If you do not like our restaurant, you do not need to come. Nobody asks you to eat here" Didn't even say sorry for the bad service. I thought the conversation was going nowhere since he has a mindset not to listen to anything that customer want to say. So, I walked out and few minutes later, he followed me out, kept on yelling at me without sincerely apologize. The worst part of this would be he threaten me by saying "I know where you work" and end the conversation with " This is San Francisco. What do you expect?"
I mean in my whole life I never experience such a bad service mind and attitude like this.
author: Alex J.

description: Had the Spider rolls and then the California rolls. Pretty tasty, I must say.  The only qualm I really had was the service. At first I thought maybe it was because I wasn't a local, so okay I understand people getting annoyed with tourists, but no, this seemed to be the case with everyone. Slow to give menus out, and then to take orders. But the food was good, and well priced for 1. Union Square and 2. San Francisco.
author: Lizz M.

description:
Cheap price, decent quality.

I was living in SF Hilton for conference, and Dojima-Ahn is the ideal lunch place. The flavor was decent, nothing bad.  Compare to where I am from (Boston), the food is a lot cheaper with more variety. 

recommended for budget lunch!
author: Hsuanchi L.

description: I've only ever eaten the cooked food -- donburi and udon -- and it's really outstanding.  It can get crowded at lunch, but if you make it in before noon you should be okay.
author: Andrew W.

description: Good food. Reasonable price. Quick service. Cozy atmosphere.
author: Marina M.

description:
Dojima, gets the job done. 

Small restaurant, with good waiter service. You really get a bang for your buck in this place. I ordered the katsu-don and received a salad, the entree and miso soup. I could not eat all of the delicious food by myself even if I wanted to.

This is a great place for take out and is close to Union Square if you want to purchase your meal and sit under the not so warm San Francisco sun.

I frequent this place whenever I'm in the area and don't feel like spending tons of $$$ for a good meal. Its not the best Japanese by far, but for what its worth, it deserves 3 stars.
author: Carlos V.

description:
I live in downtown San Francisco, so this place wasn't too far away.  It was getting kinda late and I was in the mood to eat something.  I like to eat sushi almost every week, so I made up my mind that I'd go to a sushi bar.  At first, I thought this place was primarily a sushi bar, from the first impression of the restaurant but really, it is a Japanese restaurant that carries dishes such as curry udon to tempuras.  I must admit I was tempted to order other dishes but I was really in the mood for some sushi so I stayed with that. I had my usual assortment, which was shrimp nigris, maguros, shrimp tempura roll, and spicy tuna roll.  You may find my choices as common or bland but it's what I liked the most, although I forgot to order some sea urchins.  :)  I also had the miso soup, which was very good and flavorful except for a bit too much of seaweed in it.  The maguro tuna was very good too and was cut large enough to easily span over its rice, as it well should be.  Waitresses was attentive and friendly, easily struck me as Japanese.

The place is small and cozy in space, so it wouldn't be such a good idea to bring a large crowd of starving people, as seating will be limited and you'd feel a bit crowded in too. Good to dine alone or bring a date.  The rest of other menus looks good too, that I am eager to try.
author: Nathan K.

description: I had the unagi-don, katsu, and various other appetizers. This place is solid, authentic, and reasonably priced.
author: Andrew H.

description: Delicious and fresh sushi. Decently priced. Great lunch specials!
author: Bridget B.

description:
Nothing impressive.

I was amazed to see the amount Japanese people in there though. Most of them looked like tourists. 

The menu was typical. They have a lot repeat items all for different prices. But I fail to see the that with miso soup or without makes a difference of $3. 

My tuna maguro was mediocre. I was saddened to see that only 5 pieces were served on it. 

When it's busy don't depend on good service.
author: Aromy X.

description:
This is authentic Japanese food.  That does not mean is it good. Japan is a nation like any other and its restaurants have a range of quality.  This is a downmarket, inexpensive (for Union square) restaurant, and your expectations should match that.  Think of it as the equivalent of the McDonald's in a tourist area of Shanghai.  That said, it's the cheapest Japanese food that I've found in the Union square area. I had Donburi and it was great.

When I visited there were several groups of young Japanese tourists.  This further confirms my impression of this restaurant as a relatively inexpensive, tourist-oriented place.  

As a final note, while a correct Romaji spelling of the name may be Dojima-An, my receipt quite clearly spells it Dojima-Ann.  So for better or worse, that is how the proprietor has chosen to spell the name using English letters.
author: K. B.

description: I have been here either twice or 3 times, I can't remember but it is probably one of the more decent places to eat in San Francisco for Japanese food at least near union square.  Not bad, decent prices for lunch.  I usually having a craving for Japanese food and I need it.  I am surprised San Francisco doesn't have better places to eat Japanese food.
author: Chris L.

description:
I've eaten at Dojima-Ann over a few dozen different times, but have just recently felt the urge to Yelp about it after eating there last week. Something has changed, and not for the better.

Dojima-Ann used to be a place i used to eat at for lunch when i worked on Maiden Lane, right off of Union Square. It's one of the few relatively authentic Japanese restaurants in the area. Note: i said "Japanese restaurants" and NOT sushi. If you want sushi, go somewhere else as it's not their specialty even though they have a huge sushi menu. Besides, if you're REALLY an authentic sushi eater, you'd agree with me that any Japanese restaurant that doesn't have a sushi bar does not specialize in sushi. Great authentic sushi is supposed to come direclty from the sushi chef's hand and onto your plate and into your mouth within seconds.

But i digress.

Now that i've clarified that I'm not going to talk about their sushi, I will say that I used to really like their various donburis, their udon, and their small dishes. It's not the best stuff out there, but it tastes more authentic than most places you'd find. The chicken karaage used to be crispy and tasty with just a little squeeze of a lemon, and their udon was light, yet tasty. You can get a natto maki there, and even maguro yamakake. Pretty O.G. 

But when i went there last week, things were definitely different. The waitresses were new and didn't speak Japanese, when they've always spoken Japanese for the 10+ years i had been going there. The udon was different, the karaage was in bigger chunks and came with japanese mustard and no lemon. And service was terrible. I had to ask 2x to get a beer, and the food came all at once when we specifically asked for the appetizers first. This in itself wouldn't be surprising, but it has NEVER been this way. There is something wrong. I wonder if the owners changed hands? There was a sign up in the window that was a copy of a health inspection report. I wonder if they had to post it due to a change in ownership? I might be completely wrong, but something has changed.

I will give Dojima-Ann one more chance before i give up on them completely, but the change was just too dramatic. It just isn't the same anymore. Does anyone know what happened? I was going to ask, but i couldn't get the help of a waitress, even when i was leaving.

Oh, and those fellow Yelpers who say it's a tourist trap? Yes it is, FOR JAPANESE tourists who are looking for an authentic Japanese restaurant. If those are the kind of tourists that eat there, there's nothing to fret. Most times i'm there, the place is packed with 80% asian people, and half of them are speaking Japanese and carrying maps. Call me crazy, but wouldn't you want to eat at the burger joint in Japan where the Americans are at since Americans would know a good burger?

Net net, Dojima-Ann used to be a great place, but it has gone downhill. Oh well.
author: Don T.

description:
Been here a few times on a weekday for lunch - if you arrive before 12:15pm and have a party of 2 or 3, chances are you'll be seated pretty quickly (i.e., within 10 mins or so).

Love their Ebi Curry; have also had their soba noodles with tempuras on the side but that was only ok.  Love the convenient location tho!  Service is decent and prices are very reasonable.
author: Maggie T.

description:
Went yesterday for lunch and got seated with a menu almost immediately a little after 12 pm, which I took as a good sign considering the near full capacity already reached. A minute later, another person got seated at the empty table next to me, and the both of us proceeded to wait, first to get our orders taken, and then for water/tea to be served. My order was taken about 15 minutes after getting seated. My initial good feeling went away as the wait time drew out.

Two waitresses were available, with a third (the manager/owner perhaps) coming on to help when he finally realized the two could not keep up. However, just watching them running around made me realize that they were not very organized nor good at multitasking. (I've worked in the restaurant business before so have experience with this.) Either they need a better set game plan (server A seats the table with menus while server B get the water/tea and vice versa depending), more wait staff during the lunch rush, or those who are available need to step up and take off their blinders (I mean, it's not hard to pick up payments ready at tables in their path of travel as long as one saw them). There was another table who got seated with no menus, and it took the waitresses about 7 to 10 minutes to realize it. The person who sat them should have realized it immediately! Luckily, the patrons had their to-go menus to look through while they waited and were able to put their order in when the server showed up with the actual menu (I could tell that they were -not- going to let the waitress get away or they'd be waiting even longer just to order.)

The food itself was not bad, though I did not venture beyond the bento as they had a selection available that I had a craving for. I might go back there to try the sushi, but only during off-hours to see if the service improves. As for now, I'm avoiding during the lunch rush.
author: A. C.

description: If you are in the area and don't want to spend much on decent food, this place is definitely worth the visit.  Service could be a bit spotty depending on who your waitress is, but it is not that bad to deter me.   The daily specials are definitely worth the price you pay.  Nothing fancy, so I would think you are getting something close to Japanese home cooking.  There is usually a fair number of Japanese dining in the place.  That should say it all.
author: Henry G.

description:
I was attracted by the huge (Japanese) crowd in front of this restaurant ... a good indication, I thought. Indeed. After a fast investigation of the sushi places in the Union square neighbourhood, I came back and joined the queue. Let me say, I have got some excellent deluxe sushi: melt-in-mouth albacore, red tuna, scallop were my absolute favourite together with some amazingly juicy sea urchin.  I asked the waitress to have spicy tuna instead of the ordinary tuna roll. After a little mumbling, she agreed (thanks God, flexibility  is always highly appreciated in those cases) and this gave me the chance to taste one of the best spicy tuna I have tried in a while.  Even the miso soup was better than the average, in particular thanks to the tofu pieces that had been fried instead of boiled. Too bad they didn't have a dessert (I had to "fetch" one from the neighbouring Little Delhi, once of my favourite Indian, by the way).

Definitely a good Japanese.
author: Andrea L.

description: I came down this restaurant to eat "delicious authentic" Japanese food. Yelp reviews are right!! This place serves very nice food. I ate Katsu-Don (pork cutlet bowl). Yes! This is the Katsu-Don. If you want to taste real Katsu-Don, you should come here. I'm very much satisfied. It's worth waiting for a long line.
author: Ted W.

description: Decent Japanese restaurant~ Curry Ramen looks pretty good and I regret I didnt try that. Curry beef is good not great. This place is also kinda crowded.
author: John W.

description:
I was there to eat yesterday and found that this place can still keep the quality of udon and donburi of any kind after 6 months of not visitng there. Katsudon & Oyakodon are the basically the best in the city. Chicken pork chop are always cooked very juicily. Plus, the udon they have is also the best I ever have. (Hotei Japanese Restaurant on 9th Ave @Irving St. has the same quality of udon as well.)
Same opinion as the previous reviewer, there are many Japanese customers every time I eat there and I believe this should be one of the best Japanese restaurant in Union Square.

I have never ordered sushi and I don't really see many people eating sushi as well, that's why I think this should be a very good place for sushi. 

Servers are always very attentive/polite and I got tea refilled for several times.

Generally, if I have to think of a place for donburi or udon in downtown SF, this must be the first choice.
author: Man U.

description: THe Spider Rolls here are some of the best Ive ever had, and this place really makes up for the bad experience In had at Sushi Rock.  I've eaten at this place twice so far and have not been disappointed.  Great flavor, fresh ingredients and good service make this one of my favorites when it comes to Japanese food on the go.
author: Jack F.

description:
Totally legit Japanese food. The sushi rolls were pretty as well as tasty. The curry chicken katsu was delicious, and the curry was just right. Not as starchy as Curry House. It came with a small salad (with yummy dressing!) and a small bowl of udon. All for $12.75! The only downside was the broth. The flavor was there, but it was a tad on the weak side. My friend ordered curry udon, and it was super. Other friends ordered karaage and tempura don which looked good as well. We polished everything off! 

I'd go back again next time I'm in the city...as long as I'm willing to wait 30 minutes to sit down! The restaurant is teeny tiny.
author: Lisa H.

description: Good seaweed salad. Excellent spicy tuna roll. Fresh ebi nigiri. My friend got the potato croquettes in curry sauce which were a bit drowned in curry sauce. They were still tasty. Nice to have a good go-to sushi place down town.
author: Shannon L.

description: The sushi here is definitely not the best ever but the prices are reasonable and the service is quick. Came here on black friday about 2 years ago, it was a nice escape from being in crowds since 7a.m. its near powell st. basically just a walk up the hill on one of the cross streets... The miso I had a couple of months ago was really yummy. don't try the iced coffee in the can, its not so great.
author: Christine G.

description: Food is godly.  Service is not so godly - food takes a while, but it's understandable considering how busy they usually are.  Uh, waitresses are cute too...shabam!
author: Eugene W.

description: i only got the chicken teriyaki lunch but it definitely wasnt anything to rave about. It came with salad (interesting sauce, but pretty good) white rice, soup (unlike any miso soup ive had) and a little fruit. It came to just over $10 for lunch which i felt was kind of expensive. The chicken was a little burnt and really didnt have much flavor. Definitely better options around
author: Tyler L.

description:
Authentic & delicious Japanese food in the Union Square area. Went there during the busy weekday lunch hour. Didn't wait too long. Less than 10 minutes. The wait staff was really busy and nice enough. 

I ordered the Tentoji Don. It was really good. Most Japanese restaurants don't have this on the menu. It's a favorite of mine, so if I'm at a place that serves it, I'm getting it! Will definitely come again.
author: Deb O.

description:
They try to be as japanese as possible, although not authentic, the flavours and taste is definitely asian. The special dishes ( the ones that gives you 2 items) are common in Japan, this place represents well.

I am not sure about the sushi, but the udon and unagi combos were good. For a downtown touristy place, I would expect places like "asian express", or some high priced sushi place( have you noticed that there are not many japanese folks in these places compared to the mom and pop places?) follow the right crowd and they will take you to delicious places.
author: B H.

description: Awesome Japanese food, not only sushi. Very affordable too. You know it's a good Japanese place when the patrons are all Japanese.
author: Mihai M.

description: While drinking in the area the day before, we walked by this place multiple times and each time there was a line out the door.  We were like, there must be something special about this place because people were waiting 3-4 groups+ for a table.  We decided to try it out the next day.  It is a small place which gets a lot of foot traffic from being in the Union Square district.  There seemed to be a lot of Japanese patrons so it seemed like a very legit place.  All four of us had different meals which we all thought were good, but nothing spectacular.
author: David C.

description:
If there's a "real Japan", Dojima-Ann is a "real Japanese diner".  Breakfast and lunchtimes bring in a steady stream of Japanese salarimen ordering fairly-priced meal combos.

It's Japanese comfort food, and it's above average.  Nothing particularly stands out for me, though.  I've enjoyed the saba shioyaki, though it tends to be too much shio (not enough yaki).

If they have hamachi kama, it must not have been notable in any way, because I don't recall eating it here.
author: Naomi M.

description: I used to come here a lot because my friend knew someone who worked here... LOVED their tonkatsu donburi. I feel like they mostly specialize in rice and noodle bowls rather than your typical Japanese restaurant with sushi rolls and sashimi.
author: Constance C.

description: This place is good for Japanese who don't like cooking and miss Japanese foods. They serve real Japanese home style foods, for example, oyako-don, udon, katsu-don and soba. Taste is good but I say it's not beyond the expectation, just normal. I think we Japanese can easily cook this quality food.
author: Machiruda Y.

description:
Mediocre. 

Nothing about this place is spectacular, not the interior (which is way small), not the udon, not the rice, and definitely not the sushi.  

But it's really good comfort food, especially after a long day of shopping out in the cold.  It's a decent place to swing by if you're in the area.  

Do get their specials where it's a big bowl of udon and a small bowl of rice, or a big bowl of rice and a small bowl of udon.  Usually runs for about $10-$13, which isn't too bad.

Good service, not sure if it's exactly run by Japanese.  I think I heard the owner/manager/guy that stands at the register speak in Chinese before?
author: Emily L.

description: It sucks! I've been there  twice. They messed up my order. Portions are way smaller than the average for the price. Fish is not fresh. Those who give more than 3 stars have zero clue if what a good sushi tastes like. I completely agree with Yolanta and cassino.
author: Ben Y.

description: I don't know how my earlier review ended up with one star. Dojima is a good place for some decent Japanese food, especially noodles, at low prices that are hard to find around Union Square. Service is quick, too. Not a fancy joint but definitely worth return visits.
author: Eddie S.

description:
What comes to mind when you think of Japanese comfort food?  For me, a bunch of dishes that my Mom use to make like zousui (rice cooked in miso soup with Japanese radish, green onion, Japanese parsley, and, sometimes, mochi), ochazuke (green tea over rice with salmon flakes or bonito shavings and pickled radish), whisked raw egg and soy sauce over hot rice, maguro yamakake (grated Japanese mountain potato - which becomes like a white, slippery paste - with raw tuna pieces mixed with wasabi, soy sauce, and roasted seaweed), yudoufu (tofu cooked in a hot pot with dashi, green onion, grated ginger, lemon peel, and served with a yuzu ponzu dipping sauce), zenzai for New Year's Day (sweet red azuki bean soup with mochi), sekihan (red rice with azuki beans and roasted sesame lightly flavored with salt), and roasted mochi in either sugar and soy sauce or powdered kinako - which is sweet roasted soybean flour.
 
Boy, my Mom could cook up a storm, and not just Japanese - for example, Southern fried chicken, chicken and dumplings, Hungarian goulash, and spaghetti and meatballs (all made from scratch).

Ahhh, Mom, thanks for the great food and all the love and memories...

I've never found a restaurant in the US that approximates the Japanese home style cooking that my Mom loved to prepare from her humble ancestral roots of Fukushima Prefecture.  They're just not out there.  

Dojima-Ann in San Francisco, however, does do up some Japanese comfort food in good style.  I like their donburi's, especially the katsu-don (fried, breaded pork cutlet, eggs, and onion over rice) and tendon (fried shrimp tempura and sauce over rice).  They also have unagi-don, or unajyuu, which is eel over rice.

Their udon is also authentic. It's hard to find a really good nabeyaki udon here on the Monterey Peninsula. Dojima-Ann presents a good version of it (which is Japanese noodles - udon - cooked in a hotpot with egg, seafood, and veggies).  It's only $8.50.  They've got lots of other Japanese noodle dishes, including kitsune, wakame, natto (fermented bean curd for those adventurous enough to try it.  I use to eat natto toast with ketchup...!), and so on.  

I eat sushi here, but only on the side.  For me, this is not a go-to sushi place.  They can make sushi that's not on the menu. For example, we ordered saba-gari (a simple roll with mackerel and ginger) and they prepared it true to form. The sushi chef here is not a one trick pony.

The prices are reasonable.  Environment is casual and friendly.  Service is good.  

It's not what my Mom use to make, but no place will ever be....
author: Clyde R.

description: Small unassuming place, great sushi! They also had a number of lunch specials which were great. Prompt and friendly service, and a bottomless cup of green tea with your meal.
author: Kristen H.

description:
The soups here are comparable to Mifune in Japantown. Decent udon and soba bowls. A bowl of beef udon (tea included) comes out to $7.32 with tax.

Service is quick, friendly and efficient.
author: Pat T.

description:
Close to Union Square, Hotel Nikko, Hilton SF, etc. Close around 10pm. So you usually see lots of tourists too.

Still it is good Osaka style food. Definitely a nice stop for an iron pot of yummy zaru soba noodles in a rainy night.
author: Zehr S.

description:
First off Jeff (reviewer) is totally incorrect Its spelled Dojima-Ann, with two 'N' not one. If the sign on the awing is spelled that way then I think the owners might know it.

The staff is lovely and efficient. You don't have to wait forever to eat and they are quite attentive.

I go there often after I leave the Razz Lounge (see my review) for a quick bite. It's true, the sushi is not the world's best (it's not the place for it) It's a noodle shop plain & simple. The wheat noodles I find are the best.

You will always see Japanese there and I don't think any self-respecting Japanese would eat bad noodles.

If you want good sushi, there's a place on Castro Street but for the life of me I can't think of the name. You won't miss it though because it's always packed with patrons

I recently had an experience here where I passed-out and collapsed on another patron's table. My doctor had changed the way I take my high blood pressure medicine and when I stood up after eating...down I went. The staff and owner were very kind to assist my friend in getting an ambulance for me and for that kindness alone I give them an extra star.
author: Lee S.

description: I ate here when I was little with my mom, but this first time in many years I'm eating here Dojima-Ann.. Today I had tonkatsu donburi and it was delicious and sweet.. I really wanted to eat shrimp tempura only like a couple pieces but unfortunatelly they don't have the menu by piece, you have to order the appetizer special or lunch special which is $8.99.. They should put into consideration on that ordering like 4 pieces for $5.00 like at one japanese restaurant I go to.. The service is great, but the restaurant is small which is ok, but it's pretty tight to walk in.. But overall its good..
author: RICHARD W.

description:
I had a quick lunch here on a weekday.  A small bowl of miso soup and a big bowl of rice, unagi (grilled eel), onion, and egg.  The miso was just fine, and the unagi bowl was really tasty.  I kind of wish that the miso soup had come first, before the rice bowl, but that's not a big deal.  My wife had a small bento box with salmon teriyaki, and she thought everything was good.  The meal came with free hot tea in ceramic, handle-less mugs that were ridiculously hot.  The mugs were much, much hotter than the tea was, and made it very hard to drink until basically the meal was over.  The restaurant was basically full at noon.

Although this restaurant takes credit cards, they're too cheap to take Discover or American Express.
author: Ken H.

description: Been to this place twice. Food was quiet good the first time, so came back for the 2nd. Ordered a grill squid for $ 7.95, but it was really disappointing. We started eating from the end so it was not that bad, but I found pieces the backbone of the squid, and then found that the inside of the squid was not cleaned.
author: lin h.

description:
This is a review of their Katsu-Don only.

I like their Katsu-Don, it's just like you get in Japan, runny eggs and everything. If you don't like runny eggs on Katsu-Don, like my husband, just ask to cook a little longer. They'll do it.
author: Wakaknee J.

description: I can dig it, I was craving some sushi wandering around trying to buy a V-Day gift for the girlfriend, and stumbled in here. It's a small place, and the waitresses always made sure I had what I needed. Nice if you're stopping in for a quick bite to eat. The food was good, and they had a large selection. I'm generally picky with my Sushi and only order certain things each time. In this case, my nigiri pieces were fresh and good as hell. I had to order more before leaving. When it finally got crowded, they didn't even ask me to move to a smaller table (they sat me at a four top) I picked up and moved myself, and they thanked me for it. I'd come back.
author: Ward A.

description: warm little shop, a little pricy compare to  southern california's japanese restaurant, food is not bad
author: katy c.

description: Love this place!  My husband and I have been working on a project in SF every week for last few months and commuting each week from Seattle.   This place has become a weekly staple for us.  The food is very fresh, visually pleasing, light but satisfying and inexpensive.   Although in tourist area, it is not a tourist restaurant.  Our usual is to start with some sashimi and nigiri sushi (very fresh and cut properly) and a roll---  the tuna with avocado roll is extremely good.   I then order the same exact thing every week, the Sansai (its hot Udon noodle soup with Japanese Mountain veggies) and of coure Sake.   We have tried almost all of the Sakes offered and there are none that are bad.   I originally tried the SANSAI as I had fallen in love with this dish last year when traveled to TAKAYAMA, Japan for the Cherry Blossom festival.    I have to say, the SANSAI at Dojima- Ann is as good as I had in Japan.   AMAZING PLACE.
author: JoAnn S.

description:
the place is ok but not great. 

when we went for dinner, it was pretty crowded but we did get seated right away. the service was good, and quick. 

we ordered one bento box for 22 dollars. it was pretty sizable. came with chicken, vege tempura, and 5 generous pieces of sashimi, salad and rice. for downtown, it was not a bad price i guess.

i ordered cold tofu, and some grilled fish. the fish was overly salty but overall it was acceptable..

it is not a place i'd highly recommend, but if you are around and need a quick fix, it can do.
author: Danielle A.

description:
My dining companion and I stopped in here on a lark and we totally enjoyed our donburi.  Mine was the tonkatsu donburi (no use trying to resist breaded and fried pork!) and it was warm and hearty and flavorful.  Totes hit the spot.

Our server forgot to bring our second beer, and when we reminded her, she got all flustered and scurried to the refrigerator to retrieve one for us.  Cute!
author: Marcus C.

description: really liked this place given it is really small and i can see the wait times being long but the sushi was excellent. Their soba noodle menu looked good but i stuck to a couple sushi platter orders and was not dissapointed. The sushi was fresh and was some of the best stuff i have eaten outside of japan. Highly reccomanded.
author: Avinash S.

description:
chicken katsu curry  $9.95. 
unagi donburi and niku udon combo $11.95.

decisions. decisions. probably the hardest one i've made in a while. i LOVE curry!  but for $2 extra, i could get a bowl of udon and a small bowl of unagi over rice. hmmmm...which one should i get? eh. i just got the frickin combo.

their udon was ok. reminded me of the udon you get at the supermarket. i wasnt too thrilled about their broth. as for the unagi, it was pretty good.

i also ordered onigiri. it was pretty tasty and was filled with salmon. it was kinda on the the dry side tho. but you get 2 pieces for $4. 

damn, i knew i should have ordered curry. now i have to go back to this place and try it. 

more like 2.5 stars. but i'll give them a 3 cause i'm feeling nice. service was blah.
author: B B.

description: One of the worst customer service out there. We waited for about 15 minutes to be seated, but one of the waitresses allowed a couple, who lost their turn because they left and just came back, to be seated first. We don't think this is a policy, otherwise people could just sign in, leave to do other stuff and then expect to be seated right away once they're back. I hate to mention the race issue, but the middle-aged couple were Japanese... so make your own conclusion.
author: Deck M.

description:
I am surprised about the low ratings I've seen on this page.  Really?  Did you guys order the udon?

I came here with the boyfriend on a Saturday night.  We were holed up in a nearby hotel doing thesis work and wandered around to get some study fuel.  I knew I'd food coma after Dojima Ann,but I went anyway.

He had the curry tonkatsu which I didn't try because I dislike curry, but he absolutely loved it.  It came with a side of hot udon and he was slurping it down like it was from heaven.

I had the tempura udon which was soooo good.  Believe what everyone says about the broth in this place:  Their udon broth is some of my favorite in the bay (the other being Norikonoko in Berkeley).   Hot udon on a cold night..ohh it was fantastic.  Just the right chewy texture in the noodle and enough scallions for each bite.

We also had sushi on the side because I can almost never just have noodles.  Always need something to switch up the taste.  We had the tekka maki and hamachi nigiri.  Both were great and the hamachi was surprisingly buttery.  

It reminded us of the standard restaurants around Japan.  No frills, just food.  They do have the California pre-requisite roll menu, but I wouldn't really bother with that.

They also have some combo specials (with hot udon and soba + unagi and rice...all this stuff) for really good prices.  Places like this make me so sad to live in the suburbs with bland food and inflated prices.

Will definitely come back if I'm randomly craving Japanese around Union Square.

P.S. Not sure why everyone goes into Japanese restaurants looking for chicken teriyaki and expecting it to be good.  REALLY?  I mean, really.  And then these restaurants get reviewed based on chicken teriyaki?  ARE YOU KIDDING ME.  It's cooked chicken drowned in teriyaki sauce.  It's like the culinary eyeroll to Japanese cuisine and it is by no means the measure of a restaurant.  You can tell a Japanese restaurant is good more by their miso soup than their chicken teriyaki.  ok /end rant.
author: J C.

description: I love Dojima-Ann; I rarely eat there (I'm a visitor) because there is always a line of people waiting to be seated.  I popped in there late last night after a 14 hour day of convention work; I placed a small take out order.  I was offered a seat while I waited, and a cup of tea.  How hospitable!  Their miso soup is delicious - big chunks of tofu and large pieces of seaweed.
author: Cookie C.

description: I like their soba dish. My friend also like their udon noodles. I would like to go back and try their other dishes. Its also not expensive. The place is just small and there could be a line during lunch time.
author: Elly G.

description: Gan Mai sencha tea was amazing. The salmon was especially fresh. Overall good
author: Lee S.
