description: Great sushi place in the midst of Union Square over-priced crappy restaurants. Doesn't look like much, and ambiance is nothing special, but sushi is very good.
author: E T.

description: This place didn't really impress me.  Over-priced combo.  There are a lot better Japanese restaurants in the area.  I'd write more but the experience was quite forgettable.
author: John B.

description: There is nothing better around Union Square in San Francisco for Japanese. This place is always crowded and you will most likely wait for a table. I love their Donburis with Mini Udon sets. It's very traditional Japanese food. The sushi and sashimi is very fresh and its priced very reasonably. Udon and Donburi for about 12 dollars, how can you beat that? Also, if you like curry, their curry rice plate with mini udon is highly recommended. We made a mistake going to Hana Zen while spending time in the city. Believe me, its Dojima Ann for us from now on.
author: James N.

description: The food is pretty good, the service is decent...but always crowded and always a wait.  A good place to eat but nothing too spectacular.  Not to say I won't return, because I've been a handful of times...just not a fav.
author: West P.

description: My gf and I ate here on Saturday evening. Since my gf is more the expert of this type of food, she said that it was worthy of two stars....
author: Ibvettguy T.

description:
The place is good but It seems the price has gone up over the years.

I had came here a couple of times in the past for a quick meal when I was in the area.  I remember the food being good and pretty cheap considering other Japanese restaurants I've been to around the Union Square.  I don't remember ever spending more than $15 when I came here.  

Well...

I was here a couple of nights ago and ordered a Tonkatsu-don, Tempura Appetizer, and a coke.  My total price was 38.16.  I asked my waitress if the price was right and she was pretty firm with telling me that it was.   Granted they were pretty busy with only two waitresses during dinner service.  I went along because I was in a hurry to met up with a friend but it surprised me how much I had to pay for what I got.  
Thinking back now I wished I had checked the menu again but I can sense they wanted to push me to go(when i asked for the check, she started to clean up everything, including the full cup of the soda I haven't even finished yet...) because a large party was waiting at the door.

I still think the food is good but that good for the price I paid for it. If I was rating purely for the food alone it would have been 4 stars.  But factoring in service and price, 3 stars is where it stands.

Maybe i just went at the wrong time or should have just gotten take-out...
author: Ken Y.

description: We need more of these around these parts. Fast, moderately priced, authentic Japanese lunch food. Everything from donburi, udon, appetizers to sushi and sashimi. I used to come here for lunch a lot when I worked in Union Square but even now that I don't, I'll make the trip when I have a craving. There's one waitress who's super sweet and remembers things. That's crucial!
author: Kanna L.

description: Satisfied my Gyudon craving today (which isn't on the menu ( Yeeeeeah, VIP son)).  Yum.  Big portions and it came w/ miso.  I'm full.
author: Casey F.

description:
four stars - purely for the very good nabeyaki udon.

their sushi is so so . 
the salmon sashimi is a hit and miss.
more misses than hits though.
author: Sheren H.

description: Just a mediocre restaurant, most likely busy because there aren't too many Japanese restaurants to choose from in the area. Not bad, but nothing special.
author: Jonas T.

description: When you think of Japanese food, where in the city comes to mind?  Naturally, UNION SQUARE! This little gem located across the street from the Union Square Sports bar has some of the best Japanese food.  I've eaten at all the joints within J-town, and this place for some reason just tastes better.  The Oyako-don (chicken with egg over rice) is slightly sweet and dee-lish.  Age-dashi tofu (fried tofu with grated radish on top) is cooked to perfection... a light brown layer, but so buttery-smooth in the inside... and they actually have Asahi black... looks like Guiness, but tastes like honey-beer...   waitresses are cute too! ;P
author: Dale K.

description: My Dojima Ann sob story: I ordered a tofu salad here, and when it came it was just iceberg lettuce, slabs of cold, uncooked tofu, and a really nasty vinegary dressing.  For the second time ever in my life, I send a dish back.    We got the bill and the salad was still on it, and when I asked the waitress she said since I ordered it, I had to pay for it.  Huh?  She was pretty rude about it too.  Also, our (empty) water glasses were never refilled, and the other dishes all came out at radically different times.  There are plenty of Japanese options in the area; you can bet I won't be back here.
author: Tovah S.

description: This place is small and gets crazy busy during dinner time. The wait wasn't too long even though there was a waitlist. I ordered the tonkatsu don that came with udon and a salad. It was freakin' delish. Granted I got a stomach ache after, I would do it again. I think I got a stomach ache from overeating, NOT food poisoning. My inner fat girl came out that night. :X
author: Kit K.

description: Conveniently located two blocks from Union Square, Dojima is pretty decent choice for Japanese cuisine in the heart of SF's shopping district. I've been here twice now and I must say that it isn't great but it isn't bad either. Both times, we had the Chicken Katsu. First time was so-so but my BF liked it. We went again today and it was much better. Haven't had sushi here yet because I know that Hana Zen Yakitori & Sushi Bar just a block away is a better choice.
author: Anne E.

description:
i love sushi and i love this place.  i think i would eat here every day if i could, but then again, i would probably eat just about any kind of sushi every day if i could.  the rolls are pretty generous, and their combo meals come w/ a decent amount of stuff (i'll get one to share w/ a friend).  

california rolls are my fave, and this place makes them just as good as any.

maybe it's just b/c i'm a white girl, but that tea they have (yah, i dunno what it's called) is pretty gross.  it tastes like dirt to me, but that's just a preference thing. 

and frequently there's a line out the door.  frustrating if you're starving but i think worth it =)
author: Alexis W.

description: We had a good and decently priced lunch here. Their bento lunch with salmon, chicken, rice, miso soup and salad was very good. Seems like an authentic Japanese restaurant. It was a bit busy, so we waited a few minutes to get seated.
author: Andres M.

description:
they get four for hamachi, good hamachi, consistently, three times, that was buttery and fresh. hamachi sashimi must be buttery & fresh.

miso=watery
tea=good
chicken katsu=average good
niku soba: watery broth is a staple here, good soba, beef=tender, more than sparse less than medium.

for where i am they there are and they fill the need at the time.

it is touristy, there are so many better places but never right there...

so i'll go again.


-j
author: Joe P.

description: All reviews depend on people.. But personally, I think the value for money of the restaurant is way too low. The first impression on the restaurant is not an authentic Japanese one...maybe run by other Chinese... Plus the atmosphere is like a cheap, crowed and low-quality restaurant but the price is actually elevated compared to the general state of the restaurant.
author: Pauline K.

description: I was not impressed. The sushi wasn't very fresh and the menu is overpriced. I can get fresher sushi in Bristol Farms down the street. Their food menu is okay. I will only come here if I can craving for Japanese food downtown, and other places are overbooked.
author: Helen L.

description: So my friends and I go to this Sushi place in downtown and we get seated right away.  Then after waiting for what seemed like forever to get any service...one of my friends yells out "Can we get some service?"  My other friends and me are so embarrassed at the yelling we all decide to leave and go to Betty Boops Diner across the way.  You will see a review of that too.  So in conclusion do not go there unless you have 3 hours of time to kill!
author: Rob P.

description: good lunch place if you want Japanese noodles (udon or soba) in the Union Square area (where the lunch places are generally mediocre) -- I had the udon noodles in soup with egg, chicken, beef, seaweed. Very delicious and healthy.
author: Esme V.

description: I love this place! The udon is amazing!!! I also enjoy the tumpura don which comes with a yummy sweet sauce that's sooo  good. The rolls are pretty good too, but simple. Their miso soup is really good and their potatoe croquets  were tasty. My boyfriend and I come here pretty often and the staff is pretty nice the only bad is the price, $50 for two people every time. My fav's are the Wakame udon with the seaweed and the Philly roll, and the seaweed salad is a great start to the meal.
author: Jess V.

description: This place is a gem. I always passed by thinking it was some touristy Japanese restaurant, until last year, when a friend came into town for her business trip and she wanted to go here because her clients from Japan would always take her here every time they're in SF. To my surprise, food here is great and very affordable price. Rolls are great (small amount of rice, perfect way to go) and soba is awesome. For a small restaurant, this place gets packed but they have enough servers to tend to everyone, always with a smile. Recently, I got here a little ahead of my friend, but the server sat me down anyway (most likely because it was just for a table of two, not like 8..so that's why it didn't matter everyone was here already..) but my friend ended up getting a lost a bit, but the server never rushed me to order or nothing.  Note: entrance is a bit tough to find for some reason (thus the reason why my friend got totally lost although she works in the area). It's on O'farrell between powell and mason. This is definitely my go-to spot if I want good Japanese food in downtown/union square area. Great service, Great food. Always see/hear plenty of Japanese from the customers..which is definitely a great sign. I'm not sure how good their sashimi quality is though, but based on the rolls, definitely great, but I'm not a sashimi snob so you can be the judge of that. 4 stars only because I've had some amazing authentic Japanese food in Japan before so I can't give 5, but in my book, definitely a great place to go :)
author: Karen H.

description: While visiting SF I yelped for a Japanese restaurant. I was very happy with the place; just good Japanese food. The Benito box was large and worth the money. I spent my time looking at what other persons had order. My eyes were growing larger than my stomach.
author: Luke M.

description:
We went here on New Year's Day after a fantastic night of NYE celebrations. I really needed a good bowl of noodles. My boyfriend, two friends, and I decided to try this sushi place out. We soon found out that not only was it conveniently located down the street from H&M (our next destination) but also a great place to grab great Japanese sushi and cuisine!

The place is small and was packed when we first stepped through the door. Luckily as we were coming, many patrons had finished their meals and were leaving. The four of us were seated within 5 minutes. We were quickly served piping hot green tea and for the dehydrated ones - iced water. I ordered a large bowl of soba noodle-udon-style soup with tempura and a salmon skin hand roll on the side. My boyfriend ordered the dragon roll, a tuna roll, a hamachi roll and a salmon skin hand roll as well. Our two friends ordered a teriyaki chicken bento box and chicken tonkatsu. We waited for less than 10 minutes before our food was served. My items were great. The soup broth was tasty but not too sweet. The noodles were cooked just right. I guess you can't really go wrong with soba/udon-style soup. My only complaint with that dish was that I ordered the one with tempura. I assumed it was going to be tempura vegetables and shrimp of some sort. Instead I got crumbs of tempura sprinkled on my soup. By the time I had my first spoonful of noodles and broth, the tempura flakes had already soaked up the broth and floated soggily on my noodles. Who really likes to eat soup with soggy flakes of tempura? I would suggest to order another noodle dish without the unnecessary tempura flakes. My salmon skin hand roll was tasty although it lacked sprouts and cucumber (it would have tasted better with these two ingredients). My boyfriend's hand roll had cucumber so a bit of inconsistency there. I tried some of my boyfriend's dragon roll and it was pretty good. 

Overall, the service was attentive and quick. Our tea and water were replenished at the right time. The food was tasty and "hit the spot". The prices were decent and lower than most Japanese sushi restaurants. Since it was technically a hole-in-the-wall eatery, there was little room for ambiance, but given the circumstances, Dojima Ann served our needs. I would definitely return to try more of the yummy items on their menu!
author: Judy P.

description: Reasonably priced for the area, though with an ambiance which isn't suprising considering the price (not nasty or anything, just small & packed in and kind of fast-foodish feeling).  Food was all reasonably good, though nothing to write home about.  Tempura was over-battered (should be very light, not massively caked on), but it wasn't over fried which was good, and it had good flavor.
author: Don H.

description: Pretty decent sushi given the location and price. The miso soup was good. Service was super quick even though the place was full, so that was a plus at lunch.
author: Leigh M.

description: Brightly lit and located in a touristy part of town, this place was surprisingly good. After a sake tasting, we wanted to dine nearby and happen to stumble across this place. We didn't have any sushi but WOW their agedashi tofu (completly agree with Dale) and katsu don (pork cutlets over egg over rice) were absolutely delicious - full of flavor, not overdone in any way. Service is prompt and friendly. Interesting crowd of art students, tourists and locals. Prices are very reasonable. We'll be back for more.
author: Lizelle G.

description: This place was crowded when we arrived. Though we did get seated pretty quick. I ordered teriyaki chicken, my sister ordered curry beef, and my mother ordered a egg rice dish. My food was fairly small though it did taste good but not amazing. The curry beef was really good and the portion was very good. My mother enjoyed her food, saying it wasn't too salty. The service was average. I liked the place but don't think it's amazing.
author: Kevin K.

description: This is a nice place to have a quick lunch or dinner. Prices are okay and service is quick, food tasty and if you sit at the window, great place to people watch. I've never been impressed by the sushi but I tried the rice dishes last 2 times and I love it! I guess it takes time to find a favorite item at any restaurant.
author: Hieu D.

description: I've been here a few times, and it's good food.  My partner is always testing out the tempura in sushi restaurants, and my sisters tests the tonkatsu and teriyaki chicken.  They were both impressed.  I'm voting four stars because the sushi rolls are decent, but nothing truly amazing.  The prices were reasonable and service was friendly, even though it was very busy.  Worth visiting at least a few times.
author: Argonaut A.

description: Not bad, not excellent.  Need a quick bite, sure you can go here but don't expect to be amazed.  You have limited Japanese choices in this price range in this area so go ahead and go.
author: Ryan P.

description: This is one of my favorite little lunch spots in the city.  I work nearby, so I frequent it often.  The Udon is tasty, and the lunch specials won't burn a hole in your pocket.  Just don't order the Orange Soda because you'll end up with something generic  la Shasta or A+ Cola.  The servers are sweet, but can be slow during peak hours, so be prepared to be patient if it's busy.  And be sure to order your bento with some potato croquettes that are pure YUM.
author: Marie S.

description: This is my favorite lunch place, but is really best with only two persons as half of their tables only seat two.  Oyako donburi would probably be me last lunch before dying.
author: Erin G.

description: I've passed by here many times, but was always kind of hesitant to inside because the prices were kind of too high for me before I started working. I had no idea what I was missing out on. I mean, this place isn't fantastic, but it's nice. I had the Tenzaru cold udon (wasn't bad). I also had fun watching some Filipino trannies conversing.
author: Alex Y.

description: We ordered sushi for lunch and it was ok, but the service was painfully slow, even though the place was less than half full and there were plenty of servers just standing around.  Even though we weren't in a hurry, I was still super annoyed by the time we left because the quality of food was not worth the ridiculous wait.
author: Christina S.

description: It may not be the MOST authentic Japanese food in SFO but damn, this restaurant has given me great memories....savoring a steamy hot bowl of noodles and spicey tuna with my husband....cold rain coming down hard, outside the glass window....watching my little girl's eyes open wide at the hearty curry and rice placed in front of her (as she is desperately craving Japanese rice after potatoes & pasta!)....laughing with a group of special friends, including my very-much-missed sweet friend from Hawaii.  Wish I knew the name of the waitress, but she is always friendly.. Call it good feng shui....we always leave with full tummies and happy thoughts....
author: KJ N.

description: I stumbled upon this play Friday night with my wife. We had a rainbow roll and spicy tuna roll appitizer and a bowl of chicken udon.   We were both impressed with the freshness, presentation and overall experience.  There were a lot of Japanese diners and the place was busy.  If you're looking for good Japanese inbetween shopping definately check this place out.
author: Brian B.

description: I think they used to be better. I went a couple days ago and my Tendon (by that I mean Tempura Donburi) was borderline edible. The tempura was crispy, to the point that they were more like chips than fried veggies. The sushi rolls have always been just okay, not bad, not great. However, my friend didn't even finish her soft shell crab roll because it sucked so bad. Yeah, it's definitely in the touristy part of town, which may be why they are still in business even when the food isn't all that great.
author: lisa m.

description: A friend recommended Dojima-Ann while I stayed in San Fran, and I was quite pleased.  I'm not a huge fan of Japanese food, but the soups here are fabulous.  I ate here twice while in the city for a week.  The DonBuri noodles were a little more "earthy" in taste and texture, but with great flavor.  Udon noodles were great.  I had some sushi rolls which were okay.  The decor is not fancy, but comfortable and homey.  Nice family run business with great friendly staff.  Would highly recommend for lunch or light dinner.
author: Alex C.

description: i think Dojima ann is perfect for lunch at union square.  The price for the lunch menu i think is a pretty good deal for being at union sq.  I have to admit, for dinner, it might be a little bit on the pricey side.  I LOVE their chicken karaage.  I always had something else before, but man.. the karaage is super good. The sushi isn't bad, but would go there primarily for their bento boxes.
author: Young K.

description: This place is allright.  Nothing too memorable, I have to say, though.  Packed with tourists.  It is close to Union Square though, so hey, that's expected.  I had some sushi here, and it was pretty good.  Had some beer here, and it was also pretty good.
author: Sarah F.

description: I've been to this restaurant a few times in the past 10 years.  I feel that the food is good; it's not great and it's not bad.  However, what holds me back from going more often is the wait time.  The wait time is unbelievably long and I am not really sure why that is.  Every time that I've been there, I felt that the wait time was wayyyy too long.
author: Max M.

description: This may not be a Michelin star restaurant, but whenever someone treats me to lunch and asks me where I would like to go, this is the spot!  It's a little tiny place, it has no atmosphere, but to me, the food is amazing, especially the chicken katsu meal.  The portions are perfect, the food is simple but absolutely delicious.  It's like a home cooked meal (if I cooked Japanese!) Everytime I've gone there it's packed, so that says a lot.  The prices are reasonable and it's in a good area of SF.  It's perfect for lunch, probably not dinner though.
author: Liz V.

description:
This is definitely a place for Katsudon (pork)or Oyakudon (chicken).   They make it just like the ones in Japan.  But besides the cooked comfort food, I don't think much about their sushi or soup......
The combo is definitely good if you are hungry.

Just keep in mind "cooked" food is better in this place.  Otherwise the price is okay, not cheap, but not outragous for it's location.
author: Millie K.

description:
This is not a sushi bar. They serve sushi but their strength is really on other Japanese food. They put a lot of effort into it, the cold soba comes with a quail egg, they have natto and other stuff you won't find most places.

My favorite thing there is the curry rice, I've had the tonkatsu curry twice and it's the closest curry to Tokyo I've had in the city.

For this price don't expect much in the way of ambiance or even legroom but the food is so good who cares?
author: James D.

description: good. i love the sashmi don.
author: Lisa F.

description: i had some time to spare before my spa day, and was debating over having a sandwich at foley's, or japanese food at dojima-ann.  japanese curry seemed appealing to warm me on that windy day, and dojima-ann did not disappoint.  i had the pork katsu, which was quite flavorful and delicious.  they move fast to cater to the lunch crowd.
author: Sheri N.

description: Came here again with a friend on friday for lunch.  Had the curry tonkatsu and it was pretty good.  I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Katniss B.

description: donko-domburi....just sad...sad...sad.... you'd think they could do a little better with a location here, but que pasa...senor chef---
author: miriam b.

description:
i got off work early today and had 2 hours to kill before my hair appointment with david at cowboys & angels.
i remembered seeing reviews of this place on yelp, so since i was in the area i decided to check it out.  i've been having insatiable cravings for japanese food and sushi lately... just can't get enough... 
i enter the restaurant and the man by the door directs me to where i should go and sit.  
a cozy little table close to the window.
i browse through the menu and decide on some seaweed salad and a bento box with tonkatsu and tempura.
after my order was taken i get some water and my seaweed salad that i enjoy while scanning the rest of the dining room.  some tourists, a group of japanese business men, some english language students practicing their conversational english with eachother, and a few lone diners like myself.
seaweed salad is tasty and refreshing.
just in time, my bento arrives and i'm quite pleased.  i loved the green bean tempura!  yummm...
next time i'll have to try some of their udon~
yeay good food does exist in union square
author: charlotte s.

description: ok, so, it can be hard to find good japanese food in my neighborhood.  there's a lot of mediocre sushi, but until i'd visited dojima-ann, i had believed this area to be completely devoid of tasty donburi and udon.  thankfully, i was wrong.  this place serves up tasty bowls of soup, fat maki, and delectable tempura.  perhaps it's not the most refined of japanese restaurants, but it'll make you full and happy, which is really all i need some nights.  slurp.
author: genevieve g.

description: For lunch, this is an excellent choice. The tori karaage is exceptionally good. And when you're extremely hungry, or craving a bit of udon along with your don katsu, you can add a mini udon for $2. You can have a very filling and tasty japanese lunch for about $10 and change. It's one of the best taste-to-dollar ratio in the city.
author: Daniel C.

description: Being Japanese and being constantly disappointed by tourist traps in the city, this is a real authentic Japanese restaurant. Its decor is not anything to be wowed by, and it's service is also not 5-stars, so if you're looking to be impressed by the surroundings, this is not the place. However, if you'd like noodles, they are al dente like they should be, whether you order udons or sobas. Also, if you like Tonkatsu, then Katsudon is the best in the bay area and I agree with someone that said that it beats some mediocre katsudons in Japan. The menu is odd, in that it has almost everything for everyone, but overall, this is real casual diner food in Japan, and if you're Japanese, you won't be disappointed.
author: Mori K.

description: i used to eat here almost every other day, i work in the neighborhood and they use to give us discount, beyond the discount, i think it is one of the best japanese restaurant in the city, very reasonably price, great food. i always get the bento, the broiled macarel (sp), tori karaage are my fave..and yes it is always packed esp during lunch time...and service gets a slow..but  it is worth it!
author: Jo Z.

description: Your typical Japanese comfort food, fast and cheap. All female wait staff =). Close to union square, perfect for lunch. Try the tonkatsu.
author: M. W.

description: I tried the beef curry here.  It was pretty good. Nothing spectacular.  Price is decent.  The place is a little small, and it gets pretty busy at lunch time...so make sure you try to get there a little early before lunch hour rush.
author: Connie Y.

description: My family and I had a terrible experience with our waitress at Dojima-Ann last night. I ordered Today's special, changing Katsudon to Tentoji. Instead, Tanin-donburi came. So, when I told her that I had ordered Tentoji, she insisted loudly that I ordered Tanin over and over, and she said that I could get Tentoji if I pay $2.00 more. She was very rude. It made me really angry, and wanted to talk to the manager, but she refused. In the end I got what I wanted, but the experience made us very uncomfortable. I do not want to go back there. It is unfortunate because I like their foods.
author: Kaz J.

description: i love japanese food and dojima-ann has been kind off my go-to after work.  i usually meet my best friend there and order some donburi or the salmon.  this place isn't phenomenal, but i love going because it feels removed from whatever it is i'm trying to remove myself from when i go there.  sometimes the service lags, but i don't need much to keep me happy.  as long as you keep filling up my green tea.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
not sure why my previous post was not on.  so i say it very simply.
1) the worst service: I concur with others complaining the horrible service of waitress.
2) Cheap terrible junk Japanese foods 
3) Japanese tourist central
4) their spoon smells like bleach (and taste like it)
author: k s.

description: i have to say, i've never seen this place or heard of it. but walked by with friends and decided to go it. and what a SURPRISE! one of the best sushi i had in a long time. not only is it fresh, the pieces are huge.  not just long and thin like some restaurants, but thick cuts and long pieces. and the best, the unagi is warm and juicy and great!  price is also a plus as well.  located downtown, great for work days.  so glad we found it. will definitely go back. by the way, don't know what people are saying when they say this place is $, in union square, this is not expensive. and if you like hamachi-kama (grilled hamachi grilled color), it's great here, for $10, it's a pretty big piece and that is not pricey.  place is small though. so go early, although we have no problem and people don't linger so not too bad.  service was good too, they were nice. and it was our first time.
author: Silver C.
